Proposed Seagirt Marine Terminal, MPA

%





Promote the development of
Baltimore as a major world port.

99



Maryland Port Administration

The Port of Baltimore ranks in the top
five ports in this country. Exporting over 12
million tons of coal in 1981 it is second
only to Newport News on the East Coast.
The port is a major exporter of grain and
importer of ore. Several times during the
past decade the Port of Baltimore has led
all other East Coast ports in the shipment of
autos and is the 2nd largest handler of con-
tainer shipping, on the East Coast. In 1982
the total foreign commerce moving through
the port was 32.6 million tons and was
valued at over 15 billion dollars.

While the Port of Baltimore continues
to grow in a number of key areas, other
ports are also making improvements to
their facilities. Many East Coast and Gulf
ports have committed large sums of public
and private dollars for renovation and
expansion of their marine terminals and
transportation systems. If the port of Balti-
more is to maintain its competitive position
there are several actions which are neces-
sary to undertdke. There are listed below:
field_edited_text_value:
Proposed Seagirt Marine Terminal, MPA

%





Promote the development of
Baltimore as a major world port.

99



Maryland Port Administration

The Port of Baltimore ranks in the top
five ports in this country. Exporting over 12
million tons of coal in 1981 it is second
only to Newport News on the East Coast.
The port is a major exporter of grain and
importer of ore. Several times during the
past decade the Port of Baltimore has led
all other East Coast ports in the shipment of
autos and is the 2nd largest handler of con-
tainer shipping, on the East Coast. In 1982
the total foreign commerce moving through
the port was 32.6 million tons and was
valued at over 15 billion dollars.

While the Port of Baltimore continues
to grow in a number of key areas, other
ports are also making improvements to
their facilities. Many East Coast and Gulf
ports have committed large sums of public
and private dollars for renovation and
expansion of their marine terminals and
transportation systems. If the port of Balti-
more is to maintain its competitive position
there are several actions which are neces-
sary to undertdke. There are listed below:

field_edited_text_processed:
Pol icy:
Complete the approved Federal 50’
project as rapidly as possible.

.“

Policy:

The Maryland Port Administration,
working with other state agencies,
federal and local governments
should develop a comprehensive
plan for the disposal and
management of dredge materials
generated from both public and
private sector projects in Maryland
waters over the next 20 years.

The U.S. Army Corps of Engineers
recommended in June, 1969, that channels
in the harbor be deepened to 50 feet to
accommodate the ever-larger bulk carriers
which transport such sizable volumes of
commodities to and from the Port. Cur-
rently most bulk goods, coal, iron ore, grain
and petroleum products are moved in
40,000 to 60,000 dead weight ton ships.
Often these ships and even larger cargo
carriers cannot be filled to capacity because
of the 42-foot channel. This requires the
ships to make an additional stop at another
port to be loaded to full capacity or “top-
off”’. The proposed 50" channel will allow
larger ships to call on the port and existing
ships to be loaded to capacity. This will
lower the cost of shipping bulk goods. It is
estimated that the 50" channel will produce
an average annual savings of over $150 mil-
lion in the export and import of goods.
Failure to complete the previously autho-
rized 50" channel and make other improve-
ments can result in the loss of bulk cargos
to other ports.

Over 97 million cubic yards of material
must be dredged during the next 20 years
from Baltimore Harbor channels alone. The
State of Maryland, if it is to deepen and
maintain the Ports’ channels, must assume
responsibility for developing a long term
plan for spoils management including
methods and sites for disposal. This must
include material which is expected to be
generated by private projects. The State has
constructed the Hart/Miller Islands disposal
site to handle the 50" channel project. This
project will cost over $60 million and
accommodate approximately 55% of the
total harbor dredge material. However,
methods to accommodate the remaining
45% of dredge material expected over the
next twenty years must also be identified by
the MPA. This is especially critical for long
range maintenance dredging and for private
projects. The MPA should not only explore
a wide range of alternatives including over-
boarding clean material, recycling, creating
wetlands and developing upland sites but

~must also identify funding techniques for

both the public and private sector.



100

field_edited_text_processed:
. &
@
Pol icy
The State must identify funding
sources and techniques for the
construction of an improvement to
marine terminals in the Port.

Policy:

The State should provide adequate
funding to upgrade and provide
improvements to the transportation
system required by port operations.

The development of a single general

~ cargo/container berth costs between $20

and $40 million for bulkheading, filling,
paving and equipment. This does not
include the cost of dredging new access
channels or improvements to local streets to
connect a terminal to major transportation
systems. This cost has increased dramati-
cally from 5 or 10 years ago and is expected
to continue to increase. The MPA currently
plans to develop the Canton/Seagirt spoil
disposal site into a major general cargo ter-
minal. Beginning in 1984-1985 MPA will
spend approximately $24 million to stabilize
the site and nearly $100 million in the fol-
lowing years for complete development as a
marine terminal. By the early 1990’s con-
struction should begin on another major
MPA project, the 4 berth Masonville Marine
Terminal. Estirates in 1982 called for a total
development cost of over $250 million.
While the MPA is encouraging increased
investment in terminal development and
operation by the private sector, between
$350 and $500 million (in current dollars)
will be required over the next 20 years to
build facilities to keep the Port competitive.
This figure does not include the costs of
continued improvement to existing facilities
or major construction of highways to service
the new terminals.

A comprehensive program must be
developed by the State in cooperation with
local governments and the private maritime
community to insure adequate funding for
expandion and improvements to existing
facilities and the construction of major new
cargo terminals.

‘
*
w

A port is only as strong as the landside
transportation network that meets its water
transport. The City worling closely with
State and Federal funding sources must
continue to commit funds to major trans-
poration projects serving the port and
industries. There are a number of improve-
ments which must be funded if the port is
to function at its maximum. These are as
follows:

=

1) Fairfield — Construction of the Mason-
ville Marine Terminal in the 1990’s will
greatly increase auto and truck traffic
in a currently congested area. Entrances
and exits to and from the 250+ acre ter-
minal will be required onto local
streets. Improved connectors to major
highways, including the Harbor Tunnel
Thruway, will be needed.



101

field_edited_text_processed:
Policy:

The City, State, railroads and coal
companies must work to reduce any
conflicts between local traffic and
coal trains caused by increased coal
traffic.

i



2) Canton — The construction of the Can-
ton/Seagirt Marine Terminal in the late
1980’s, completion of Fort Holabird
Industrial Park and Foreign Trade Zone
and the anticipated expansion of other
industries will likely tax Broening
Highway, local streets and connectors
into 1-95 during peak hours. This may
require improvements at several loca-
tions to meet peak demand.

Perhaps the most complex transporta-
tion issues will be generated by the
increased rail traffic from coal export at®
several major grade crossings. Not only will
auto and truck traffic serving businesses be
delayed but in several locations emergency
services, such as fire engines, ambulances
and police, could be temporarily cut off
from several areas. There are also locations
in the City that may benefit from grade
separations or improved traffic control
techniques. The planned grade separation at
Boston Street in Canton will cost approxi-
mately $15 million. A full program involving
grade separations at a number of locations,
as well as signal improvements, improve-
ments to crossing surfaces, and other
related up gradings could cost up to $50
million for the port area.

An equitable formula for sharing the costs
of grade separations and other major
iImprovements required as a result of
increased coal shipment must be developed
between the City, State, railroads and coal
companies.

At-grade rail crossing blocking traffic

field_edited_text_processed:
o

Goal:

Realize the full potential of the
harbor’s shoreline and water
area for recreational uses and
public access.



2

Inner Harbor, public plaza and shoreline promenade

With the industrialization of the har-
bors shoreline during the late 19th and
early 20th centuries most of the public
recreational facilities were displaced by fac-
tories, bulk storage or marine terminals.
Riverview Rark in Canton disappeared in
the late 1920’s as Western Electric devel-
oped its plant; Canton Race Track is now
Exxon’s storage yards; Fletchers Fish House
and Beer Garden constructed in 1809, dis-
appeared under railyards and highways in
the Middle Branch in the 1850’s. In virtually
every area of the harbor large, public recre-
ational facilities have been replaced by
industrial development. As industrial and
port uses grew, communities were isolated
from the waterfront and public access to
the shoreline became virtually non-existent.
By the mid 1940’s, Baltimore’s citizens who
had once looked to the Bay, and the water
for a major recreational pastime had few
opportunities to use this resource. Less
than one mile of the Port’s 28 mile long
shoreline was available to public access.
With so few opportunities for public access
the City must work carefully to see that
each public park and shoreline access
opportunity:is developed and maintained
to serve the greatest number of people
possible.



103

field_edited_text_processed:
Policy:
Expand and improve the City’s
shoreline park system.

"9

#
Policy:
Expand opportunities for the
development of marinas and-safe
recreational boating on the harbor
consistent with the operation of a
working port.

The City is undertaking a number of
projects to use available shoreline for pub-
lic access, recreation and boating. These
projects range in size from small street end
parks for specific communities like Hull
Street in Locust Point to larger city and
regional facilities like Forts Smallwood and
Armistead and the Middle Branch Park
System.

The Middle Branch Park is a major
addition to the City’s park system. Located
on the Patapsco River it touches the South
Baltimore, Westport, Cherry Hill and Brook-
lyn communities. The park combines over
150 acres of completed landfills, existing
City parks and acquisition of derelict shore-
line uses. While initial steps are being taken
now, full development is expected to take
over ten years. The City began in 1978 mak-
Ing improvements to the shoreline, build-
ing new recreational facilities and public
boat launches and encouraging a clean-up
of the shoreline by private owners. When
completed the park will offer residents a
unique recreational resource stretching
from the harbor almost 30 miles up the
Patapsco River State Park System.

The City is working with private devel-
opers on Boston Street and in Fells Point to
develop a continuous public waterfront
walk stretching from the Canton shoreline
to the Inner Harbor. When completed the
public walk will extend over 2 miles con-
necting the Inner Harbor’s many activities
to communities, Fells Point’s historic water-
front, and new residential and recreational
development along Boston Street and in
Canton.

Fort Smallwood, in Anne Arundel
County and Fort Armistead in the Hawkins
Point area of the City will have major
improvements made through the 1980’s.
Both will offer a variety of active recrea-
tion, beaches, walkways, boat launches and
natural areas when completed. Both also
offer the potential for excursion boat access
from the City’s Inner Harbor.

There is considerable demand for
recreational boating and existing facilities
offered by marinas in the harbor. The Inner
Harbor Marina with almost 170 slips has a
waiting list. Reservations for berthing along
the promenade and Piers 4, 5, and 6 are
required in the boating season. Over 1,000
additional slips have been approved in con-
junction with residential development
along the Fells Point/Boston Street
shoreline.

Realizing the tremendous increase in
boating and the potential for conflicts with
commercial shipping the Mayor established
a task force to review applications for mari-
nas, offer suggestions as to control of boat



Baltimore City Marine Police



104

field_edited_text_processed:
Policy:
Identify and develop new access

points for the public to the
waterfront.

Policy:
Develop continuous public access

along the shoreline in residential and
commercial areas where feasible.

Policy:

Create increased opportunities for
the public to view shipping and
industrial activities located on the
harbor.

Policy:

The City should work with owners of
shorefront land to remove derelict
piers and structures, clear debris,
rectify shoreline erosion, improve
existing buildings and landscape
edges where feasible.

Access to the shoreline can take on
many forms and sizes. While the City will
continue to develop large scale plans for
promenades in the Inner Harbor and Falls
Harbor, there are numerous sites in the har-
bor to develop small scale access points.
Two such sites are under development. At
Hull Street and Boston Street the City has
developed small boating piers and
improved the water’s edge for local resi-
dents. The City will continue to identify
small scale opportunities for public access
to the shoreline.

The City should seek to provide public
access along the shoreline in new or rehabil-
itated residential projects and commercial
buildings on the harbor. This policy has
been successfully implemented in the Inner
Harbor and plans are under development to
continue access in new projects along Piers
4,5, and 6 and to the east in Falls Harbor.

This policy has already been incorpo-
rated into development proposals and the
Federal permits for several projects in Fells
Point and along Boston Street. Public access
to the water has become an important con-
sideration in the review of all residential
and commercial projects along the harbor’s
shoreline.

Other port cities have found that many
people are fascinated by port and industrial
operations and have provided facilities from
which they can view activities safely. The
City has requested the MPA to include such
a facility, perhaps an observation tower, in
its proposed Masonville Marine Terminal.
Other opportunities should be identified
and developed.

An increasing number of people visit
or tour our City via its harbor and a greater
effort must be undertaken to clean-up the
water’s edge. Debris from unkept shorelines
and piers is not only unsightly but provides
a hazard to boaters and shipping. Erosion
causes both landside problems as buildings
and roads are undermined and problems in
the water as sediment fills in channels and
reduces water quality. In cases where ero-
sion or derlict piers are a navigation or pol-
lution problem the City should assist owners
in working with the appropriate State or
Federal agency. Many industrial buildings
located on the waterfront are now highly
visable from the water. It is in their best
interest to improve buildings and shoreline
visable to the public. The City may also
secure funds to remove piers and sunken
boats if they present a hazard to navigation.







Public shoreline walk, Fort Armistead



106
field_edited_text_value:
Policy:
Identify and develop new access

points for the public to the
waterfront.

Policy:
Develop continuous public access

along the shoreline in residential and
commercial areas where feasible.

Policy:

Create increased opportunities for
the public to view shipping and
industrial activities located on the
harbor.

Policy:

The City should work with owners of
shorefront land to remove derelict
piers and structures, clear debris,
rectify shoreline erosion, improve
existing buildings and landscape
edges where feasible.

Access to the shoreline can take on
many forms and sizes. While the City will
continue to develop large scale plans for
promenades in the Inner Harbor and Falls
Harbor, there are numerous sites in the har-
bor to develop small scale access points.
Two such sites are under development. At
Hull Street and Boston Street the City has
developed small boating piers and
improved the water’s edge for local resi-
dents. The City will continue to identify
small scale opportunities for public access
to the shoreline.

The City should seek to provide public
access along the shoreline in new or rehabil-
itated residential projects and commercial
buildings on the harbor. This policy has
been successfully implemented in the Inner
Harbor and plans are under development to
continue access in new projects along Piers
4,5, and 6 and to the east in Falls Harbor.

This policy has already been incorpo-
rated into development proposals and the
Federal permits for several projects in Fells
Point and along Boston Street. Public access
to the water has become an important con-
sideration in the review of all residential
and commercial projects along the harbor’s
shoreline.

Other port cities have found that many
people are fascinated by port and industrial
operations and have provided facilities from
which they can view activities safely. The
City has requested the MPA to include such
a facility, perhaps an observation tower, in
its proposed Masonville Marine Terminal.
Other opportunities should be identified
and developed.

An increasing number of people visit
or tour our City via its harbor and a greater
effort must be undertaken to clean-up the
water’s edge. Debris from unkept shorelines
and piers is not only unsightly but provides
a hazard to boaters and shipping. Erosion
causes both landside problems as buildings
and roads are undermined and problems in
the water as sediment fills in channels and
reduces water quality. In cases where ero-
sion or derlict piers are a navigation or pol-
lution problem the City should assist owners
in working with the appropriate State or
Federal agency. Many industrial buildings
located on the waterfront are now highly
visable from the water. It is in their best
interest to improve buildings and shoreline
visable to the public. The City may also
secure funds to remove piers and sunken
boats if they present a hazard to navigation.







Public shoreline walk, Fort Armistead

field_edited_text_processed:
Policy:
Filling in of the harbor’s water
should be limited.

-

’( ®
Policy:
Enforcement agencies must

aggressively enforce existing laws
prohibiting illegal fill.

Policy:

Where fill is found to be
appropriate, the project sponsor
should create alternate resources in
the harbor.

Harbor filling has long been used as a
way to create real estate. Rather than pur-
chase adjacent property many land owners
simply pushed earth, rubble and wastes
into the harbor. This practice has a number
of negative impacts on the harbor. Filling
decreases the harbor’s ability to absorb pol-
lutants, alters and decreases the tidal flush-
ing ability of the harbor and removes a con-
siderable volume of water where aquatic
habitat could be established. Often, wastes
have leached back into the harbor causing
localized pollution problems. Many fill sites
were not well constructed and have settled
or caused waves of mud generated by the
fill displacing the soft bottom. In all instan-
ces the volume of water in the harbor has
been reduced. Although fill projects were
often small in amount, if all fill projects over
the past 50 years are totalled, several thou-
sands of acres of water have been removed
from the harbor’s system. Every effort
should be made to propose fill which is
only absolutely essential to a projects func-
tion and viability.

Because the harbor has been thought
of as less valuable as an environmental
resource enforcement proceedings against
illegal fill are often given a low priority rel-
ative to more environmentally sensitive
areas of the bay. While this may be justified
to some degree in comparative environ-
mental importance this often relegates the
harbor to simply maintaining the status quo.
Local, State and Federal enforcement agen-
cies must:

1) designate adequate staff for monitoring
and enforcement,

2) assign a high priority to resolving cases
of identified violaters.

There are some projects which may jus-
tify filling of limited areas of the harbor.
Marine terminals and water dependent
industries or industries which have no land-
ward alternative for expansion may qualify
for a permit to fill. These cases are limited
in number, however, and only the actual
area needed will be considered for a per-
mit.

After local, State and Federal agencies
have reviewed and approved a fill project,
there must be some effort to compensate
the harbor’s water system for the lost habi-
tat and resources. This can take the form of
creating wetlands, removing fill from areas
which were once open water, developing
artificial reefs, checking shoreline erosion or
cleaning up a degraded shoreline and open
water area. Alternatives have been clearly
identified in the Baltimore Harbor Environ-
mental Enhancement Plan and must pass
local, State and Federal review.

108







Maryland Port Administration

field_edited_text_processed:
Policy:

Existing enforcement procedures
should be modified to immediately
correct damage and prevent further
destruction caused by illegal fill.

Goal:

The City should receive
equitable reimbursement for
local revenues lost to tax exempt
uses in the port.

Current procedure against illegal fill is
directed more to pursuing the violater
rather than correcting and preventing fur-
ther damage to the harbor’s water quality.

There have been a number of projects
around the harbor which have started with-
out installing approved erosion and sedi-
ment control devices. This has resulted in
sediment being washed into the harbor.
Although violation notices have been
issued, lengthy court battles, inadequate
enforcement staff, disputes over the respon-
sibility of constructing the control devices,
etc. have caused long delays in the resolu-
tion of the violation. During this period
there is little or no action taken to control
the erosion problem. This allows sediment
to continue to wash into storm drains,
streams and.the harbor and only increases
the negative impact of the project to the
water body, adjacent properties and esca-
lates the cost of correcting the problem.

Regulations should be developed by
the State which not only identifies the viola-
tion but also requires action to prevent any
further damage which might occur during
the enforcement procedures.

Because the City has a limited tax base
it has pursued an economic development
program to retain and attract industry which
maximizes, in terms of jobs and taxes, the
use of the industrial land adjacent to the
harbor. Of the approximately 6,100 acres of
industrial land around the harbor over 1,300
acres are exempt from property taxes
because of ownership by the State (Mary-
land Port Administration) and the railroads.
If just the 1,300 acres of land owned by the
railroads and MPA were assessed and taxed
at the same rate as other private industrial
land, over $2,300,000 in property taxes
would be generated each year. Meanwhile,
the City must incur the cost of services to
these facilities: police and fire protection,
roads, etc. An example of this can be found
in the operation of the harbor’s fire boats.
The City purchases, maintains and operates
fire boats which must protect ships in the
harbor and mgrine terminals. While it costs
the City approximately $3.1 million each
year to provide this service to the port it
received only $1.8 million from the state in
1982 towards covering that cost.

In addition to direct outlays that the
City must assume there are also indirect
loses. In several instances the MPA leases its
terminals to private operators. These facili-
ties function as private terminals although
they enjoy the unique advantage of paying
either limited or no taxes to the local juris-
diction. Only a small payment-in-lieu of
taxes, just over $100,000 from terminal oper-
ations, is passed on annually to the City
from the MPA.



109

field_edited_text_processed:
Policy:

The City, State, and private seCtor
should work together to put vacant
and underutilized port, industrial
land to its highest and best use in
terms of taxes and jobs.

[ 4

Maryland Port Administration





There are also costs incurred by the
operation of railroads and marine terminals
which must be bourne by the City however
are not as obvious. Major port terminals
generate large volumes of truck traffic
which must travel over local streets and at
time through commercial and residential
areas. The cost for repairing streets and
bridges is the responsibility of the local
jurisdiction.

The City believes that both real and
hidden costs of State operated and leased
facilities must be calculated and addressed
by the appropriate State agency or user.

&

While the majority of land owned by
the State, railroads and the private sector is
in active, port related uses there are parcels
which are vacant or used only occassionally
for temporary storage. This underutilization
of land yields few jobs, often less than one
employee for every four acres. For every 50
acres of vacant or underutilized land the
potential is lost to create 750 jobs in an
intensive manufacturing use or 200 jobs as a
marine cargo facility.

Because land adjacent to the harbor is
so limited the development and marketing
efforts of the City, State and private sector
should be jointly utilized to attract indus-
tries or port operators which will yield the
highest level of employment possible.

Baltimore City fireboat at work

field_edited_text_processed:
Baltimore’s

Harbor:

Providing for
the Future

Baltimore’s harbor has been an evolving,
changing resource for over two-hundred
and fifty years. Beginning as a minor port
in the early 18th century, within a hundred
years it had become the front-door to one
of America’s largest cities, a gateway to the
west, home of the clipper ships, and the
birthplace of the railroading industry.
Through the late 19th and early 20th cen-
turies the port experienced expansion of its
industrial base, overland trade, and ship-
ping. However, by the the 1940s and 1950s
the port began to suffer from deteriorated
infrastructure, changes in transportation
methods, and obsolete shipping tech-
niques. A turning point occurred in the
1960s when the Maryland Port Administra-
tion, the City, and the private sector
realized that the waterfront held the poten-
tial to offer a variety of resources to the
public. Changes were initiated to take
advantage of these resources: The port
grew in its ability to meet the changing
demands of world trade. In less than fifteen
years the port had developed over 600
acres of modern, general cargo terminals,
coal export capacity was trebled, and an
interstate highway system tied the port to
the entire east coast and the midwest. But
another, even more remarkable change un-
folded through the 1970s. Residents of the
City, the State of Maryland, and visitors
were reintroduced to the water’s edge. The
redevelopment of the Inner Harbor, Fells
Point, and Canton brought people back to
shop, relax, and live by the harbor, an
opportunity that had been largely missing
for over seventy years. As you have read in
previous chapters, not only was the com-
mercial port rebuilding, but an entire City
and State rediscovered its waterfront and
with it a large part of its history.

With this renewed interest in the harbor
grew another concern, one which had
been reflected in other parts of the
Chesapeake Bay for many years. That is an
interest in recreation at the shore’s edge
and a concern for the quality of the water.
Residents found concern not only in the
economic stability of the port, but began to
insist that the quality of the harbor’s water
and shoreline, also were improved. Resi-
dents and visitors wanted the water clean,

they wanted access to the shoreline when
reasonable, they wanted industry to
improve their respective waterfronts, and
they wanted a variety of experiences at the
water’s edge. Residents celebrated at the
Inner Harbor’s promenade and piers, it has
become the new town square. They wanted
to walk around the edge, watching others,
observing industry, and port activities. They
also wanted to find small public spaces,
near their communities to experience the
waterfront alone or with their neighbors
and families. Boaters wanted the water to
be open and safe. Children and adults
wanted a harbor that could support a
variety of aquatic life. By the 1980’s new
expections were held for Baltimore’s
harbor.

Clearly, the harbor has expanded dramat-
ically as a resource. The traditional methods
of viewing the harbor’s capabilities have
been broadened. But if we are to continue
to utilize the harbor for an ever expanding
number of interest groups then we must
challenge all those involved to become
increasingly responsive to both the issues
concerning this water body and the many
opportunities it offers.

In 1984, Mayor Schaefer, responded to this
need by taking several actions.

Baltimore Fish and Wildlife

Commission -

The Harbor, and in fact the entire City, had
been for many years overlooked as a
resource for wildlife. As water and air
quality improved, as the City upgraded the
public waterfront and parks, as we gained
experience in“wildlife management, and as
wetlands were created to provide habitat
there was a need to develop a comprehen-
sive approach to working with the many
resources at hand. In 1984, Mayor Schaefer
appointed a Fish and Wildlife Commission
to develop this aspect of the City’s
resources. The Commission plans to expand
existing programs, develop new opportuni-
ties, and involve citizens and specialists in
broadening wildlife habitat in the City of
Baltimore and its holdings around the
reservoirs. .

Bay Opportunities for Baltimore

(B.O.B.) -

Bay Opportunities for Baltimore (B.O.B.) is
a public/private partnership, created by
Mayor Schaefer, to specifically address
issues and opportunities for Baltimore’s
harbor. The Bay Opportunities for Balti-
more committee concentrates on five
major areas:

1. Shoreline and harbor clean-up with
improvements to public and private
waterfront properties,



111

there was a need to develop a comprehen-
sive approach to working with the many
resources at hand. In 1984, Mayor Schaefer
appointed a Fish and Wildlife Commission
to develop this aspect of the City’s
resources. The Commission plans to expand
existing programs, develop new opportuni-
ties, and involve citizens and specialists in
broadening wildlife habitat in the City of
Baltimore and its holdings around the
reservoirs. .

Bay Opportunities for Baltimore

(B.O.B.) -

Bay Opportunities for Baltimore (B.O.B.) is
a public/private partnership, created by
Mayor Schaefer, to specifically address
issues and opportunities for Baltimore’s
harbor. The Bay Opportunities for Balti-
more committee concentrates on five
major areas:

1. Shoreline and harbor clean-up with
improvements to public and private
waterfront properties,



111

field_edited_text_processed:
2. expanding educational opportunities
and public involvement,

3. increasing recreational opportunities
and public involvement,

4. improving water quality and wildlife
habitat in concert with the Fish and
Wildlife Commission, and,

5. identifying special projects for the
harbor.

B.O.B., which has representatives from City,
State, and Federal agencies, members of
conservation groups, port industry, and the
private sector began work in the summer
of 1984 and has identified a number of
projects to be pursued in 1985-8nd beyond.
These include a specific clean-up program
for the shoreline of the harbor extending
from Ft. McHenry/Lazaretto Point into the
Inner Harbor, endorsement and support for
the Water Resources Educational Center
Middle Branch, development of the Canton
Waterfront Park, working with the Park
Board on improvements to Fort Smallwood,
an active role in support of the City’s
Marina Master Plan, and involvement in
Harbor Expo ’'85.

Marina Master Plan -

Baltimore’s harbor is one of the largest and
most active ports in the country. Over three
thousand commercial vessels call on the
port each year. The introduction of a new
water activity, recreational boating, in a
largely commercial port has raised a number
of concerns regarding congestion, boating
safety, and the standards by which marinas
and other support facilities are developed.
For many years zoning regulations allowed
marinas to develop virtually anywhere along
the shoreline even adjacent to active port
facilities.

The City understands that it is important to
have guidelines for marina development in
order to maintain safety, to support City
redevelopment efforts, and to minimize
impacts on commercial port operations.

Two actions were taken in early 1985 to
address the issue of the safe development
of marinas in the harbor. The first, a Marina
Master Plan was approved by the Planning
Commission. All marina proposals must be
consistent with the master plan. Secondly,
the Mayor and City Council enacted
changes in the Zoning Code which made.
marinas conditional uses in all zoning
districts. Marina proposals must be reviewed
by the Board of Municipal Zoning and
Appeals.

These two actions are important steps
toward keeping the harbor viable for
commercial shipping and providing

opportunities for recreational boating.

Baltimore Harbor Expo ’85 -

The City of Baltimore and much of the State
of Maryland have looked to Baltimore’s
harbor for over 250 years for employment,
housing, recreational activities, and as a tie
to the rest of the world. To celebrate Balti-
more City’s bond with the harbor and the
Chesapeake Bay, Harbor Expo ’85 has been
planned for August 2nd - August 4th, 1985.

Harbor Expo ’85 will focus on the diversity
of the roles that Baltimore’s harbor plays in
the City, State, and nation. Special events
will highlight the Port’s shipping and
manufacturing interests with tours of the
industrial shoreline and visits to marine |
terminals. Citizens will learn of the harbor
and bay’s ecological and natural resources
through two days of Baysic Training, with
courses ranging from testing water quality
to fishing to crabbing and environmental
awareness. Fishing tournaments, crew row-
ing, boating regattas, and waterfront picnics
will reintroduce the public to the harbor’s
sports and recreational potential. Through-
out Harbor Expo ’85 special events, tours,
and activities will provide a unique insight
to Baltimore’s harbor for residents and
visitors. It is anticipated that Harbor Expo
will become an annual celebration.

Baltimore Harbor Endowment -
Created in 1985 initially to support Harbor
Expo '85, the Baltimore Harbor Endowment,
is a non-profit organization which will fund
a variety of programs and projects to
expand the public’s knowledge and use of
the harbor. Directed by the Bay Opportuni-
ties for Baltimore committee, the Baltimore
Harbor Endowment, will provide ongoing
support for Harbor Expo and allow the
private sector to financially support
iImprovements to water quality, public
access projects, and educational programs.

The above programs represent a major
expansion of the resources of Baltimore’s
harbor available to the public. Coupled with
an aggressive port community, economic
development, and new residential and
commercial projects, the water’s edge, the
harbor, and the Chesapeake Bay present a
diversity of opportunities few cities and
states have. Our challenge is to work with
these resources, to develop them carefully _
and with wisdom, and to pass them on to &=
new generations. =

field_edited_text_processed:
Few Baltimoreans have seen the treasures of nature which lie

along the ten-mile Jones Falls Valley. The Valley has long been
‘hidden’ from the view of passers-by. Now, as the Jones Falls
Expressway opens up the once-hidden vistas, we are conjfronted
with a great opportunity. The concepl of The Valley as a con-
tinuous urban Park -- a peaceful retreat for city dwellers -- has
been proposed, hoped for, talked about, for sixty years. Dreams

were dreamed, but translation of the vision to reality was always
blocked by the lack of a detailed plan and a vivid image of what

the Jones Falls Valley could become. Now here is a Plan. From

it we can create a marvelous asset for all of Baltimore to enjoy.

Round Falls in Jones Falls Valley s a cool,
quiet retreat. Have you ever been ther

The natural beauty of Bend Hill. Do you know where it is?

The dreams of our fathers had a solid foundation: the exciting physiography of the
Jones Falls Valley. Even today, amid towering bluffs, expansive meadows, deep
ravines, rushing rapids, and quiet pools, if you look hard you can see visions of a "
scenic valley that brings a bit of the country into the city. Think of living in a tower ‘
apartment or a hillside home along thexedge of the Valley .. / just a pleasant, edsg/“
drive from Downtown! Think of Lobster Lowisa in an elegant restaurant overlooking

a waterfall! Think of trout snapping at a fly in a quiet pool just fifteen minutes ]%m il
Charles Center! Think of finding the first anemone of spring, spotting the nest of

an oriole, or skating on a frozen pond! This is the Jones Falls Valley that can be.

within the City, detailed in four sections.

In 1910, Theodore Marburg, one of the men with the early vision, said: “There are
many elements which go into the making of a livable and attractive city. . .and when
the city does become attractive, then your return on the money you have spent is
manifold.” His statement reveals the practicality that underlay the vision drawn up
by the Olmsted Brothers, the leading firm of landscape architects in the nation in
1902. What remains to be done is to turn their dream of a stream-valley wrban park
wnto a reality. This report spells out the basic concept in detail and presents a two-
stage program of action. The first stage can be accomplished in a series of steps over
the next five years. Completion of the second stage may take as long as twenty years.

But the concept is feasible. What follows is the Plan to convert that concept to reality.

In 1910, Theodore Marburg, one of the men with the early vision, said: “There are
many elements which go into the making of a livable and attractive city. . .and when
the city does become attractive, then your return on the money you have spent is
manifold.” His statement reveals the practicality that underlay the vision drawn up
by the Olmsted Brothers, the leading firm of landscape architects in the nation in
1902. What remains to be done is to turn their dream of a stream-valley wrban park
wnto a reality. This report spells out the basic concept in detail and presents a two-
stage program of action. The first stage can be accomplished in a series of steps over
the next five years. Completion of the second stage may take as long as twenty years.

But the concept is feasible. What follows is the Plan to convert that concept to reality.

field_edited_text_processed:
SECTION A: PENN STATION TO 29TH STREET

1. Gateway Park: Development of the two blocks between
Lafayette- and Lanvale Streets, from Charles Street to the
Fallsway, will create a southern gateway to the Jones Falls
Valley. As a second stage, this park can be extended east to
Guilford Ave., and serve as a major entrance to Downtown.

2. Commercial Potential — The Station: The air rights over the
Pennsylvania Railroad tracks can be developed with motels,
offices, distribution centers, residences, parking garages, and
a heliport. These can extend from North Avenue to Mt. Royal
Avenue and can incorporate a new station, and parcel post
and Railway Express depots as integral parts of the Plan.

3. Residential Potential — Mt. Royal Heights: The high ground
from Mt. Royal Avenue northeast to the Valley has a great
potential for high-rise residential and town house development
when the Plan is put into effect.

4. Landscaped Tracks: The City can acquire a right-to-plant in
railroad areas where land between the tracks is available for
screening planting. Views from the expressway would be
vastly improved, and railroad operations would not be im-
paired.

5. Druid House Restaurant: The southeast promontory of Druid
Lake commands an exciting view of the Valley to the north
and south and of the fascinating 28th-29th Street interchange.
The promontory can be leased by the City for development of
a fine restaurant. The Penn Station area — as seen from
above the Howard Street Bridge

6. Ma and Pa Pond: Realignment of the present Falls Road will — has an exciting commercial potential.
provide space for the pond and for landscape development.
The pond would be stocked with trout. Small boys would By o

come here to sail boats. A sculpture garden would be created ' =
along the edges. =t

7. Highway Link: The City’s Master Street Plan shows a pro-
posed major collector street following the old Maryland and
Pennsylvania Railroad right-of-way, up Wyman Park and
Stony Run from Sisson ,Stre'et north to Lake Avenue. This
highway would be tied into the Jones Falls Valley Road via
the existing tunnel under Sisson Street, thus affording a relief
route for Charles Street down to Maryland Avenue Bridge.

8. Round Falls: This beautiful water display is little known to
Baltimoreans, even though it is only a stone’s throw from
Falls Road. With selective cutting and planting, the view on
page 1 would be opened to travellers of the Jones Falls Valley.
This is part of the natural beauty of the Valley which can be
a treat to the eye of resident and motorist alike.

field_edited_text_processed:
SECGTION B: 29TH STREET TO 41ST STREET

9. The Mill Cafe: Part of the old Mount Vernon Mills can be
remodeled as a restaurant. It now overlooks a delightful ter-
race and another lovely falls. A water wheel could be recon-
structed. Two charming small buildings, dated 1873-79, can
be used as a textile museum.

10. Residential Potential — Falls Cliff: The magnificent view of
the Falls, the Valley, Druid Hill Park, and a skyline backdrop
of the very heart of Downtown from this high bluff gives the
Falls Cliff area an intensive residential potential. The “Mill
Town” across the ravine to the southeast is a handsome ex-
ample of company-built houses, the value of which will in-
crease as the Plan is carried out.

11. Hamden Hill: This promontory has a direct view down the

Valley to the heart of the City. On it is the historic Carroll
House. The top of the hill should be added to Roosevelt Park.

12. The Scenic Road: From Maryland Avenue to the point at

which the present Falls Road leaves the Valley at Hamden,

the road is to be widened under a current City program. The
new portion of the scenic route begins, then, where the pre-
sent Clipper Mill Road continues north from Falls Road.
From this point all the way to Prettyboy Reservoir, the road
will be a small-scaled, steep and winding one, a true scenic
route such as San Martin Drive in Wyman Park or Falls Road
in the county. With removal of the old and obsolete mill build-
ing in this area, the Jones Falls Valley Road underpasses the
expressway and rises on the other side to meet the hill in
Druid Hill Park.

13. Residential Rehabilitation and New Construction: Here
another promontory overlooks the Valley. With the Valley
Park below, a rapid transit station adjacent, Druid Hill Park
across the way, and Roosevelt Park nearby, this area will be
ripe for more intensive development, consistent with the Park
environment and transit and highway access.

14. Park Addition: This area is a logical part of Druid Hill Park
and the Valley concept. It is important visually as well as
locationally that this slope and the small stream at its bottom
be under Park protection. To the east, Brick Hill is another
natural portion of the Park. The houses are old, in many cases
in poor repair, and can be acquired gradually as they come
on the market. A new road connecting the Druid Hill Park
network and the Scenic Road is shown on Brick Hill. From
this height the road can overpass Union Avenue and continue
north along Clipper Avenue. Here a second group of stone
company houses stand close on the west side of the Road. The
City can acquire these over a period of time, lease them back
to present owners, or utilize them for Park purposes. An



O

|
l|
A
\‘ 0 U

" Woodberry Meadow . . . a focus for residences on the surrounding ridges.

agreement with the Woodberry Methodist Church should be
made so that its property could not change its present use or
pass to ownership other than that of the City.

15. Mill Recreation Area: The flood plain upon which the old
Mount Vernon Woodberry Mill #2 stands is ideal for active
recreational purposes such as lacrosse and football. The Olm-
sted Brothers pointed this out in 1902; it still holds true in
1961. The mill buildings have changed hands several times
in the past few years; the City should take advantage of the
next opportunity to acquire the property. The tower with its
handsome cupola could be preserved as a landmark.

16. Woodberry Meadow: Here the Valley concept sinks or
swims. The expressway is hemmed in closely as it narrowly
misses the unsightly factories; the Scenic Road borders the
western edge. This low-lying meadowland will give forth
quickly with moisture-loving plant life. It would be supple-
mented by landscape development so that the meadow will
become a focus for residential neighborhoods on the surround-
ing ridges.

An unimproved 8.8-acre tract in the Jones Falls flood plain at
the 41st Street viaduct should be acquired immediately. The
substantial industry now in this part of the Valley—including
the rag plant, the foundry, the envelope and rubber plants—
shoutd be acquired and razed as the buildings go out of use,
are partly or wholly lost due to natural circumstances or
calamities, or become obsolete. Their eventual elimination is
necessary to the Valley concept.

17. Residential Potential: This area is now partially improved
by small and light industrial concerns, but is still predomi-
nantly open land. The eastern slopes of the Valley rise to give
good views both north and south. The area has good access
to 41st Street, Falls Road, 36th Street, and an existing play-
ground. The industrial traffic and use at this location is in-
compatible with and damaging to the good housing near it.

field_edited_text_processed:
SECTION C: 41ST STREET TO CYLBURN PARK

18. New Apartments and Houses: Open land at the crest of the
Valley wall will serve high-density residential needs, both
apartments and homes.

19. Meadow Park: To the expressway traveller, the wide Wood-
berry Meadow under the 41st Street viaduct will be in pleas-
ant contrast to the narrower confines and steep-sloped views
elsewhere in the Valley. Because the expressway is elevated
at this point, people on the Valley floor can walk under it
easily to the quarry area or to the south and Druid Hill Park.

20. Residential Development: The present light manufacturing
use on this hillside area is almost surrounded by school, play-
ground, and park. The area has greater, higher, and better
use in intensive residential development. {

21. Bend Hill Recreation Area: The Arundel Quarry is not a
very pretty sight today. However, through the eyes .of a
landscape architect can be seen wonderful transformations:
a boating and fishing pond on the lower level ; trees springing
from the now denuded slopes; an observation tower rising
against the 100-foot precipice to thrilling heights overlooking
the Valley and the City; and a restaurant, incorporated in the
design of the tower, to be reached from a parking area on
the upper level just off the Scenic Road. Ice skating and a
sled and ski slope would make the area a year-round enter-
prise. Many of these facilities could be leased out to private
operators thereby absorbing some of the development costs.

22. Camping: The flat hilltop just north of the quarry is an
unusually isolated spot due to its height and steep slopes on
three sides. It is an ideal site for camping. Scouts might find
a good base here from which to hike to Lake Roland and
beyond.

23. Street Improvement: The City has proposed that Shirley
Avenue be extended to Cold Spring Lane. This would become
a natural boundary of the Valley development. The Scenic
Road would connect with it, and park land would reach out
to Greenspring Avenue for pedestrian access. Y

24. Junior High School: The City is now acquiring land for this
school. Both as protection for the school site and as an entry
to the Valley, a minimum of 80’ on each side of Cold Spring
Lane should be acquired and landscaped.

25. Potential Residential Area: This open hilly tract of some
eight acres will be highly desirable residential land overlook-
ing the Valley. Near three public schools, adjacent to an ex-
pressway interchange, and close to the rapid transit line, its
logical use will be for good residences.



Bend H:ll 'recrea,tzon area

26. High Schools: This 69-acre area has been approved for the
use of two new high schools. Again, a minimum width of 80’
should be landscaped on each side of the new Cold Spring
Lane, from Falls Road into the Valley, to provide a sense of
entry as well as to buffer the schools from the highway. The
preservation of the remainder of the high hill just north of
Cold Spring Lane will provide a breath-taking lookout point
for the public. Retaining the hillside will, at the same time,
absorb expressway noise before it reaches classrooms.

27. Camp Small*‘— An Historic Site: The meadow was the site of
a Union Army Camp permanently established early in the
Civil War to protect the railroad bridge over the Jones Falls;
the bridge had been blown up during the Riots of Baltimore.
The area might appeal to the Boy Scouts for the erection of a
permanent camp site. Although it, and a few other areas,
appear to have potential for industrial use, they are even more
important as part of the visual continuity of the Valley Park.

28. Residential Development: A lovely open hillside tract of
some 37 acres, surrounded by public and semi-public uses, this
area is ideal for residential development.

field_edited_text_processed:
14

SECTION D: CYLBURN PARK TO CITY LINE

29. Bird Refuge — Country Club Pond: With very little effort,
the area between the relocated Jones Falls and the original
stream bed can be made into a delightful pond and bird
refuge. The connection to Falls Road affords an access on the
east to pedestrian traffic.

30. Country Club Apartments: Over 40 acres of rolling, golf
course can be developed for residential use. Highrise towers
would meet many objectives made particularly logical by the
rapid transit and expressway. The hilltop at the northern end
of the site offers views and lookout development possibilities
that should not be lost to the public.

31. Parkway and Potential Development: Northern Parkway,
from Falls Road to Greenspring Avenue, should have parkway
treatment on both sides in order that it might serve as an
entry to the Valley. The slopes are steep on the north side
from Rogers Avenue to Greenspring Avenue, and the stream
in that area needs protection.

32. Private Recreation: The Valley floor reaches out to Falls
Road in this stretch. The area should be scheduled for ac-
quisition as the owners wish to sell. The future use might be
additional privately-operated recreational facilities similar to
those to the north.

33. Stream Conservation: The ravine and creek flowing into the
Valley proper from the west is again an integral part of the
Valley. The terrain is too rough for easy development and
much too beautiful not to be preserved.

34. Meadowbrook: The Mt. Washington Lacrosse Club and the
Meadowbrook swimming pool and skating rink are highly
desirable recreational uses; however, the City should work out
adequate means of assuring future land use control of this
part of the Valley. In the long run, similar recreational
facilities might be developed north of the Kelly Avenue via-
duct. The Mount Washington Methodist Church is of historic
and architectural interest and should be preserved.

35. Western Run Park: The junction of Western Run and Jones
Falls extends back along the Run to the Kelly and Sulgrave
Avenue intersection. This well-travelled intersection is an
important visual focal point for the Park. Retention of the
charming library building on Smith Avenue and the landscape
development of the remainder will make a meaningful junc-
ture of the Jones Falls Valley and Western Run. Along the
Run itself, the City should quickly acquire the remaining por-
tions indicated in Olmsted’s Plan.

36. Rapid Transit: The Northern Central Railway Line makes a
natural route for a rapid transit commuter line. This should
be studied at an early date by the newly instituted Metropoli-
tan Transit Authority. With rapid transit, the intensive
development along the Valley edges makes sense; and vice
versa.

37. Scenic Road: After underpassing the Kelly Avenue viaduct,
the Scenic Road will cling to the lower slopes below Mount
St. Agnes College out to the City Line. A few evergreens in
among the beautiful existing planting on this campus will put
the Road completely out of view from the College.

38. Lake Roland Connection: The stream valley, from the City
Line to Lake Roland, is relatively undeveloped, is almost en-
tirely in the flood plain, and is a vital link in the Valley Plan.
The 450-acre Robert E. Lee Park, known as Lake Roland,
is now owned by the City. It will become a natural destina-
tion for City hikers or riders making use of the Valley.

AREAS NORTH AND SOUTH OF DETAILED STUDY SECTIONS

39. County Extension: The Scenic Road should be extended into
the County, up the draw north of Mount St. Agnes, where the
size and beauty of the beech trees is breath-taking. The road
could have a connection with Smith Avenue. Winding on
through open country, it can join Old Pimlico Road where
that route will underpass the new expressway. Where Old
Pimlico meets Falls Road, a new access into Lake Roland
would be made, thus opening that rugged and beautiful park
to the public.

40. Scenic Road: From the new junction of Old Pimlico and
Falls Roads, the Scenic Road takes advantage of the existing
route of Falls Road, which needs only to have protection ex-
tended along its already beautiful borders. It will make a
magnificent scenic route all the way to Prettyboy Reservoir.
The County can realize this important regional facility with
the acquisition of scenic easements and development rights.

41. Inner Harbor: From Penn Station south to the Harbor are
chances for planting and enhancement of the expressway by
acquisition, by right-to-plant in railway areas, and by careful
control of future developments—both private and public—
adjacent to the expressway. The Harbor itself will eventually
be the dramatic and appropriate terminus for the Jones Falls
Valley. The potential of this area is unlimited. It must be
the subject of a study unto itself. As a natural resource of
historic and visual preeminence, the Inner Harbor is of great
importance to the City of Baltimore.
field_edited_text_value:
14

SECTION D: CYLBURN PARK TO CITY LINE

29. Bird Refuge — Country Club Pond: With very little effort,
the area between the relocated Jones Falls and the original
stream bed can be made into a delightful pond and bird
refuge. The connection to Falls Road affords an access on the
east to pedestrian traffic.

30. Country Club Apartments: Over 40 acres of rolling, golf
course can be developed for residential use. Highrise towers
would meet many objectives made particularly logical by the
rapid transit and expressway. The hilltop at the northern end
of the site offers views and lookout development possibilities
that should not be lost to the public.

31. Parkway and Potential Development: Northern Parkway,
from Falls Road to Greenspring Avenue, should have parkway
treatment on both sides in order that it might serve as an
entry to the Valley. The slopes are steep on the north side
from Rogers Avenue to Greenspring Avenue, and the stream
in that area needs protection.

32. Private Recreation: The Valley floor reaches out to Falls
Road in this stretch. The area should be scheduled for ac-
quisition as the owners wish to sell. The future use might be
additional privately-operated recreational facilities similar to
those to the north.

33. Stream Conservation: The ravine and creek flowing into the
Valley proper from the west is again an integral part of the
Valley. The terrain is too rough for easy development and
much too beautiful not to be preserved.

34. Meadowbrook: The Mt. Washington Lacrosse Club and the
Meadowbrook swimming pool and skating rink are highly
desirable recreational uses; however, the City should work out
adequate means of assuring future land use control of this
part of the Valley. In the long run, similar recreational
facilities might be developed north of the Kelly Avenue via-
duct. The Mount Washington Methodist Church is of historic
and architectural interest and should be preserved.

35. Western Run Park: The junction of Western Run and Jones
Falls extends back along the Run to the Kelly and Sulgrave
Avenue intersection. This well-travelled intersection is an
important visual focal point for the Park. Retention of the
charming library building on Smith Avenue and the landscape
development of the remainder will make a meaningful junc-
ture of the Jones Falls Valley and Western Run. Along the
Run itself, the City should quickly acquire the remaining por-
tions indicated in Olmsted’s Plan.

36. Rapid Transit: The Northern Central Railway Line makes a
natural route for a rapid transit commuter line. This should
be studied at an early date by the newly instituted Metropoli-
tan Transit Authority. With rapid transit, the intensive
development along the Valley edges makes sense; and vice
versa.

37. Scenic Road: After underpassing the Kelly Avenue viaduct,
the Scenic Road will cling to the lower slopes below Mount
St. Agnes College out to the City Line. A few evergreens in
among the beautiful existing planting on this campus will put
the Road completely out of view from the College.

38. Lake Roland Connection: The stream valley, from the City
Line to Lake Roland, is relatively undeveloped, is almost en-
tirely in the flood plain, and is a vital link in the Valley Plan.
The 450-acre Robert E. Lee Park, known as Lake Roland,
is now owned by the City. It will become a natural destina-
tion for City hikers or riders making use of the Valley.

AREAS NORTH AND SOUTH OF DETAILED STUDY SECTIONS

39. County Extension: The Scenic Road should be extended into
the County, up the draw north of Mount St. Agnes, where the
size and beauty of the beech trees is breath-taking. The road
could have a connection with Smith Avenue. Winding on
through open country, it can join Old Pimlico Road where
that route will underpass the new expressway. Where Old
Pimlico meets Falls Road, a new access into Lake Roland
would be made, thus opening that rugged and beautiful park
to the public.

40. Scenic Road: From the new junction of Old Pimlico and
Falls Roads, the Scenic Road takes advantage of the existing
route of Falls Road, which needs only to have protection ex-
tended along its already beautiful borders. It will make a
magnificent scenic route all the way to Prettyboy Reservoir.
The County can realize this important regional facility with
the acquisition of scenic easements and development rights.

41. Inner Harbor: From Penn Station south to the Harbor are
chances for planting and enhancement of the expressway by
acquisition, by right-to-plant in railway areas, and by careful
control of future developments—both private and public—
adjacent to the expressway. The Harbor itself will eventually
be the dramatic and appropriate terminus for the Jones Falls
Valley. The potential of this area is unlimited. It must be
the subject of a study unto itself. As a natural resource of
historic and visual preeminence, the Inner Harbor is of great
importance to the City of Baltimore.

Camp Small during the Civil War.

The vision our fathers saw, some sixty years ago,was a marvelous natural stream-
valley park . . .a small-scaled scenic road . ..commuter trains from the country to the
Uity ...recreation of all kinds . ..a valley filled with beauty and edged by residences.
This concept fit not only the topography of the Valley, but took into consideration
the history of the stream as well. ¥or the past three hundred years the activity
of Baltimore has centered about Jones Falls and its Valley. No wonder that by
1926, the year of a second Olmsted Report, the most important single recommen-

dation was the development of Jones Falls Valley. The Report said that it had “the

finest scenic features on the largest scale” of all the valleys of the Baltimore region.

field_edited_text_processed:
In the beginning: This glittering, bubbling, sometimes violent
stream has, over the past three hundred years, acted as a mag-
net for the establishment of towns and turnpikes. It continues
to play a prominent role in the history of Baltimore City.

Its namesake, one David Jones, settled 380 acres along the
eastern banks of the stream in 1661; his settlement, Jones’
Town, is identified today as Old Town. Directly across the
Falls, along its western slopes, Baltimore Town was estab-
lished in 1729. By 1745, the two were jointed as the City of
Baltimore.

The available water power at the frequent falls, combined
with the early Jones Falls Turnpike, opened the Valley to
commerce. Flour mills and foundries were built where ter-
rain allowed. But the rugged side walls of the Valley and the
frequent flooding of the meadows have, from the beginning,
placed severe limits upon the Valley’s industrial development.

The coming of the railroad produced the incentive for major
textile mills; the Washington Cotton Manufacturers (now
Maryland Bolt and Nut) led the way in 1804. Horatio Gam-

Jones Falls Turnpike in the early nineteenth century.

Geological section, Green Spring Valley to Federal Hill.

briel built the Mount Vernon Mill near Cedar Avenue in 1847.
The Woodberry, Druid, and Clipper Mills followed in short
order. Baltimore soon became the world center for cotton
duck. The Clipper ships figure prominently in this mid-
nineteenth century era.

At the time of the Baltimore Riot in 1861, the Melvale rail-
road bridge over Jones Falls (just above Cold Spring Lane)
was burned. Because of its importance as the major supply
route south from Pennsylvania, this portion of the then
Maryland and Susquehanna Railroad was guarded by Union
Soldiers stationed at Camp Small throughout the Civil War.

Since the mid-nineteenth century, the trend of activity in the
Valley has been significantly directed toward public and in-
stitutional use. Some 1500 acres in park lands border the
Valley; a golf course, semi-public institutions, and private
recreational facilities have been built. The Jones Falls Ex-
pressway, another public facility for which planning began
almost thirty years ago, is the most recent event in the Valley
history.

field_edited_text_processed:
Planning for the Valley began in 1902. The Municipal Art
Society, an organization devoted to civic betterment, and
newly created by Theodore Marburg, retained the Olmsted
Brothers, the top landscape architects of that era, to make a
report on the development of public grounds in Baltimore.
Their report, published in 1904, continues to this day as the
framework for open space and park planning for Baltimore
City and its environs. The Approved Park Plan of the City is
based upon the Olmsted Plan as updated by that firm in 1926.

Much of the Olmsted Plan was realized by the City. Herring
Run Park in East Baltimore and Gwynn’s Falls Park in West
Baltimore are substantially complete. The third major stream-
valley system recommended by the Olmsteds for Jones Falls
Valley, serving the north and northwest part of the City, has
never been completed.

Today, active construction on the Jones Falls Expressway has
refocused attention on this forgotten valley. The amazing
fact is that a tremendous amount of open land still exists. It
seemed more important than ever that the Valley, through
which some 65-70,000 Baltimore motorists would travel daily,
be studied to determine its future.

As a result, the Board of Recreation and Parks of the City of
Baltimore, and the same Municipal Art Society, authorized the
Planning Council of the Greater Baltimore Committee to
explore the proper land uses, and development potential of
the Valley. Major emphasis was to be on the possibility of
carrying out the early park concept.

While the 1904 report proposed a continuous park from Mary-
land Avenue to Lake Roland, the 1926 proposal eliminated
the strip park south of Bend Hill, the north side of Woodberry.
This represented a weakening of the concept. On detailed
study the continuity of the Valley’s park-like character was
seen to be essential from Penn Station to Lake Roland and on
to the Beltway. Interrupt this continuity at any point, and the
concept will cease to have validity.

Though detailed analysis in the present study was limited to

the area between Penn Station and the city line, it is obvious

that the Valley’s significance — both as a City landmark and
regional geographic feature — does not stop at these points.
South to the harbor, an extension of green could be placed
along the edges of the expressway as the continuity of the
concept and as a pleasant, visual edge for Downtown. North
of the city line, the connection into Lake Roland is absolutely
necessary for the pedestrian linkage to this City-owned, 450-
acre park. The Scenic Road, utilizing existing Falls Road
north to the Prettyboy Reservoir, is still unspoiled and a great
opportunity for the taking.



In 1904 the Olmsted Brothers had a plan for Jones Falls Valley.

field_edited_text_processed:
APPROVED PARK PLAN PART OF THE MASTER PLAN
FOR THE CITY OF BALTIMORE: The latest revision of
the Master Park Plan, dated February 21, 1961, shows
clearly the contrast in realization to date of the three
major stream-valley parks—Gwynn’s Falls, Jones Falls
and Herring Run. The loss of the stream-valley con-
cept along the Jones Falls south of Bend Hill is evi-
dent. It is obvious from the illustration above, that
Baltimore made a fine start toward achievement of a
strong, green pattern woven into the City development.
The City and the County are but a short step away
from the ‘“humane city”’* that offers parks, open
squares and playing fields, sunlight, fresh air and free
movement, the sight of grass, bushes, flowers and trees
in addition to the technological necessities. One of the
demands of the future will be that cities be beautiful,
that living as well as working places be in attractive
surroundings, and that the increased public leisure
time be satisfied both close at hand as well as a few
hours’ drive away.

*as described by Lewis Mumford in “The Social Function of

Open Spaces,” a paper delivered to the International Federation
of Landscape Architects in Brussels, 1960.

...........







CALYERY COUNTY



4ARFORD COUNTY

REGIONAL PLAN FOR OPEN SPACES: The recent pro-
posal by the Baltimore Regional Planning Council for
Metropolitan and Regional Separator Belts around the
City of Baltimore is of tremendous importance to the
early future of this Region as an attractive and desir-
able area in which to live. It is absolutely essential
that rapid action be taken to preserve the open spaces
from scatteration and irresponsible destruction of the
uniquely beautiful Maryland countryside. The addi-
tion of the Jones Falls Valley to this system of parks
and preservations increases the value of the system as
green separators and creates an ideal connection to the
very heart of the City. It is a significant addition to
the regional scheme. Federal and State legislation may
soon provide assistance for such open space proposals.

field_edited_text_processed:
THE GASE

for the Jones Falls Valley Plan

The conservation and development of Jones Falls Valley is not without precedent.
Washington has ’z'ts Rock Creek Park; P/ziladelblzia, the Wissahickon, delight of
nature lovers and motorists alike. Even Baltimore -- on d smaller scale -- has its
Herring Run and Gwynn’s Falls. Jones Falls Valley today still remains a dream--
but a dream on paper. In essence, the Plan for Jones Falls Valley would combine
scenic natural beauty - similar to that in Washington’s Rock Creek Park -- with
man-made expressway landscaping - like that along the Henry Hudson Parkway
in New York City - creating a pleasant valley where urbanites could indulge in

the complete range of leisure activities, from peaceful revery to strenuous recreation.

23

field_edited_text_processed:
24

Analysis A great deal of planning analysis underlies the Valley
Plan. What will be the impact of the Expressway? Should
the Valley be used for industry? Must the entire Valley be
cleared to provide continuity for the Park? What would be
the costs and benefits? How could the Plan be implemented?
These questions and many others were studied and considered
before the Plan could be completed. Though only a summary
can be shown here, careful scrutiny of details by the City is
necessary.

The Impact of the Expressway on the Valley Impact studies of
expressways elsewhere have shown great increases in develop-
ment at the interchanges, particularly in industrial uses where
open, level land was available. The actual design of the
expressway was studied. Its impact could be good, or could
be very damaging to the adjacent land uses. The result of not
putting the Valley Plan into effect will mean some increases
in industrial use, but industry on the same hit-or-miss basis
as in the past.

Alternative Land Uses The predominant land use in the Valley
is already public. City-owned property — including parks,
playgrounds, schools, and the expressway — outstrip all other
uses by a tremendous margin. Other significant uses are resi-
dential and institutional. Primarily open and undeveloped
land still numbers in the hundreds of acres; much of it still
has great natural beauty.

How much of the Valley could be developed for new industry?
When the flood plain, steep topography, and land-locked sites
are all considered, there are only about 50 really good acres

for potential industrial use. These are scattered among 11
or 12 locations. Even some of these are partially within the
flood plain or in residential zones.

The present industry was examined. Although some concerns
are substantial, together they provide less than 2500 jobs. In
the course of the next 20 years of the Plan, many of the indus-
tries will move through need for more space, changes in
ownership, and obsolescence of structures. Therefore it was
considered not impractical to gradually retire the Valley from
industrial use.

The facts are that industrial opportunity here is a pittance.
And, in the overall picture of the Valley, industry is not a
large existing use. With planned industrial parks opening else-
where in the City, the marginal sites offered by the Valley
will continue to suffer from their historic competitive disad-
vantage in spite of the expressway.

Continuity of the Concept The big decision in the planning
process was that the Valley had to be continuous to be feasible
as a Plan. Schemes in which the Park was interrupted were
tried and rejected. They fell apart as mere spot park pro-
posals. The concept of a stream valley park from the Inner
Harbor to Lake Roland and beyond has integrity, historic
significance, and validity in both City and regional aspects of

‘geography and planning.

Costs While the study does not purport to contain a detailed
cost analysis, the general magnitude of costs is felt to be
realistic. For acquisition cost, recent comparable sales were
used for unimproved land. For improved parcels, 1960 assess-
ments were multiplied by a conservative factor. Costs are esti-
mated for the City portion only.

The ¥irst stage, a five-year plan, is'estimated to cost $10 mil-
lion; of this, $8.2 million is for acquisition and $1.8 million
for development. It will add 262 acres to the City’s park
system. The total 1960 assessment of real property of this
stage is less than $2 million.

The final stage, over 20 or more years, would add an additional
91 acres to the Park system at a cost of about $12.3 million;
$2.7 million is estimated for park and recreational develop-
ment. The 1960 assessment of real property of the final stage
is slightly over $5 million. Together, the two stages return
about $256,000 a year to the City in property taxes.
field_edited_text_value:
24

Analysis A great deal of planning analysis underlies the Valley
Plan. What will be the impact of the Expressway? Should
the Valley be used for industry? Must the entire Valley be
cleared to provide continuity for the Park? What would be
the costs and benefits? How could the Plan be implemented?
These questions and many others were studied and considered
before the Plan could be completed. Though only a summary
can be shown here, careful scrutiny of details by the City is
necessary.

The Impact of the Expressway on the Valley Impact studies of
expressways elsewhere have shown great increases in develop-
ment at the interchanges, particularly in industrial uses where
open, level land was available. The actual design of the
expressway was studied. Its impact could be good, or could
be very damaging to the adjacent land uses. The result of not
putting the Valley Plan into effect will mean some increases
in industrial use, but industry on the same hit-or-miss basis
as in the past.

Alternative Land Uses The predominant land use in the Valley
is already public. City-owned property — including parks,
playgrounds, schools, and the expressway — outstrip all other
uses by a tremendous margin. Other significant uses are resi-
dential and institutional. Primarily open and undeveloped
land still numbers in the hundreds of acres; much of it still
has great natural beauty.

How much of the Valley could be developed for new industry?
When the flood plain, steep topography, and land-locked sites
are all considered, there are only about 50 really good acres

for potential industrial use. These are scattered among 11
or 12 locations. Even some of these are partially within the
flood plain or in residential zones.

The present industry was examined. Although some concerns
are substantial, together they provide less than 2500 jobs. In
the course of the next 20 years of the Plan, many of the indus-
tries will move through need for more space, changes in
ownership, and obsolescence of structures. Therefore it was
considered not impractical to gradually retire the Valley from
industrial use.

The facts are that industrial opportunity here is a pittance.
And, in the overall picture of the Valley, industry is not a
large existing use. With planned industrial parks opening else-
where in the City, the marginal sites offered by the Valley
will continue to suffer from their historic competitive disad-
vantage in spite of the expressway.

Continuity of the Concept The big decision in the planning
process was that the Valley had to be continuous to be feasible
as a Plan. Schemes in which the Park was interrupted were
tried and rejected. They fell apart as mere spot park pro-
posals. The concept of a stream valley park from the Inner
Harbor to Lake Roland and beyond has integrity, historic
significance, and validity in both City and regional aspects of

‘geography and planning.

Costs While the study does not purport to contain a detailed
cost analysis, the general magnitude of costs is felt to be
realistic. For acquisition cost, recent comparable sales were
used for unimproved land. For improved parcels, 1960 assess-
ments were multiplied by a conservative factor. Costs are esti-
mated for the City portion only.

The ¥irst stage, a five-year plan, is'estimated to cost $10 mil-
lion; of this, $8.2 million is for acquisition and $1.8 million
for development. It will add 262 acres to the City’s park
system. The total 1960 assessment of real property of this
stage is less than $2 million.

The final stage, over 20 or more years, would add an additional
91 acres to the Park system at a cost of about $12.3 million;
$2.7 million is estimated for park and recreational develop-
ment. The 1960 assessment of real property of the final stage
is slightly over $5 million. Together, the two stages return
about $256,000 a year to the City in property taxes.

field_edited_text_processed:
Benefits Many financial as well as aesthetic benefits will accrue
to the City to compensate for the out-of-pocket costs, the loss
in taxables, and the maintenance expenses of the Park.

190 acres in potential development areas along the edges of
the Valley are shown. 138 of these are now vacant; the
remainder are underdeveloped or badly developed. Once the
Park Plan is adopted, they will have an investment potential
of over $85,000,000. This would return to the City in excess
of $2 million a year in taxes. While some of this might be
developed anyway, no estimate has been made of the
undoubted increase in value of other property adjacent to the
Valley.

In addition, the 58-acre tract over and adjacent to Penn Sta-
tion alone has a potential of $100,000,000 in investment. This
is sound municipal arithmetic.
