Implementation and Financing The Plan can be achieved through
a step-by-step process of implementation. That process is
itemized under Recommendations.

Various techniques and sources of funds are available. Out-
right acquisition of property is indicated for most of the Val-
ley within the City. For some portions in the City, the pur-
chasing of development rights, made possible by recent State
legislation, may be appropriate. Such uses as the Woodberry
Methodist Church, the Mt. Washington Methodist Church, the
Meadowbrook Club, and the Mt. Washington Lacrosse Club
can be ensured by this method, or by purchase and lease-back.
Many of the houses can be acquired in the same manner. Most
of the land for the Park in Baltimore County can be protected
as open park space by acquisition of scenic easements or
development rights.

Major financing of the Valley Park in the City must be by a
local bond issue. However, 50-50 Federal funds may be avail-
able for portions of the Jones Falls Valley Road. Federal
money ig already available under the 90-10 ratio for landscap-
ing the expressway.

In addition to these Federal funds, there is likely to be a new
and direct aid for the Valley Plan. The Williams Bill (S. 858,
87th Congress sponsored by Senator Harrison A. Williams, Jr.
(D., N.J.)) was introduced in the Senate on February 9, 1961.
It calls for the authorization of grants up to 25-35% of acqui-
sition costs to help finance the preservation of open-space land
“which is of regional or area-wide importance . . .” President
Kennedy called for passage of this bill in his message to Con-
gress. When the bill is enacted into law, Baltimore can be
ready with one of the first qualifying plans. Recently Senator
Williams said to a meeting of the Maryland Governor’s Con-
ference on Recreation and Parks: “We must start making our
parks serve the larger effort of improving the whole quality
of urban and metropolitan living.” Hear, Hear!

field_edited_text_processed:
RECOMMENDATIONS

Yes, Jones Falls Valley can become a tremendous asset to Baltimore. Interceptor sewers
already have cleaned the stream. It can be stocked with trout. The great expressway
opens up new possibilities for the Valley’s highest and best development. In many areas
the stream and valley are simply waiting the touch of a green thumb, the impact of an
imaginative mind. But time won’t stand still. If we act now, the expressway-generated,
uhplanned, haphazard development can be avoided. The great stands of trees will not
be felled. The adjacent houses will turn their fronts--not their backs, as they do now--
to the Valley. To realize the true potential of the last remaining site for a great urban

park, we must have a schedule, a timetable for action. Here is how it can be done.

27

Step two

field_edited_text_processed:
. 30





Time is running out. Truly this is a time of decision. Shall the Jones Falls Valley
continue to be a rubbish heap -- an object of catch-as-catch-can speculation and
abuse? Will we travel on the Jones Falls Expressway, past derelict factories with
bricked-up winddws, through a treeless landscape with billboards glaring at us from
every conceivable angle? Or will the Valley become, by one master stroke, a great
Valley Parkway, making travel on it--by expressway, by scenic road, by commuter
train, on foot--a pleasure and relief for the daily traveller? “To delay our decision

will mean that the opportunity will be lost forever. Jones Falls Valley must be saved!
field_edited_text_value:
. 30

bricked-up winddws, through a treeless landscape with billboards glaring at us from
every conceivable angle? Or will the Valley become, by one master stroke, a great
Valley Parkway, making travel on it--by expressway, by scenic road, by commuter
train, on foot--a pleasure and relief for the daily traveller? “To delay our decision

will mean that the opportunity will be lost forever. Jones Falls Valley must be saved!

26 April, 1961

Dr. Frank C. Marino, President
Board of Recreation and Parks

Mr. Douglas H. Gordon, President
Municipal Art Society of Baltlmore
Baltimore, Maryland

Dear Sirs:

In accordance with our contract dated 26
October, 1960, The Planning Council has
completed its study of the Jones Falls Valley.





The accompanying report substantiates the
Council’s strong feeling that herein lies a
critical and timely opportunity for the Balti-
more Region. Positive action toward realiza-
tion of this plan will place Baltimore in the
forefront of a national awakening to the
aesthetic and practical value of parks and
open spaces.

The Planning Council believes that this Plan
is feasible. It will, in the long run, benefit
the City and Region increasingly with the
years, creating an environment we will all be
proud to pass on to our descendents.

Respectfully submittéd,

J ofm E. Motz, Chairman

Chree Centuries of Busiress

Trade routes of the world—by water, by
land and by air—are arteries carrying a con-
tinual flow of business through the “‘heart”
which is Baltimore. More than fifty steam-
ship lines move twenty million tons of cargo
annually: mainline railroads carry still other
millions of tons; additional millions of tons
flow in all directions by highway transport:
even the air is made to carry a vast commerce
to and from Baltimore . . . a commerce parti-
cipated in by some two thousand manufac-
turing plants, extensive wholesale and retail
establishments . . . in short, BIG BUSINESS
for Baltimore.

Business was here before Baltimore—and
Baltimore has grown mighty through de-
votion to business. A century before the
establishment in 1729 of a custom-house,
occasion for the founding of Baltimore, one
Capt. Henry Fleet engaged in the fur trade
in this area. Later, the dominant business
was in tobacco. As crop, merchandise, cur-
rency—tobacco was the life of trade. Agricul-

ture, industry, commerce and finance all met

and mingled in tobacco. Valued at a penny
a pound, it was legal tender for taxes or
debts; currency for making any purchase. If
that seems a primitive economy, listen to
this:

““In 1666 Nathaniel Utie was one of the
commissioners appointed to effect an agree-
ment between Virginia, North Carolina, and
Maryland to suspend the planting of tobacco
for a year, so as to enhance its value!”

There were giants in those days. Men had
to be. Surrounded by a wilderness, with
slow transportation and communications,
water wheels their
only power—yet,
men founded manu-
facturing and milling

businesses, entered



into shipping which circled the world, bring-
ing its wealth here to their warehouses.
They fought for and established our nation

~and served it generously and still had time for

gracious, leisurely living! No wonder, with
such a tradition, Baltimore is a great indus-

Chree Centuries of Busiress

Trade routes of the world—by water, by
land and by air—are arteries carrying a con-
tinual flow of business through the “‘heart”
which is Baltimore. More than fifty steam-
ship lines move twenty million tons of cargo
annually: mainline railroads carry still other
millions of tons; additional millions of tons
flow in all directions by highway transport:
even the air is made to carry a vast commerce
to and from Baltimore . . . a commerce parti-
cipated in by some two thousand manufac-
turing plants, extensive wholesale and retail
establishments . . . in short, BIG BUSINESS
for Baltimore.

Business was here before Baltimore—and
Baltimore has grown mighty through de-
votion to business. A century before the
establishment in 1729 of a custom-house,
occasion for the founding of Baltimore, one
Capt. Henry Fleet engaged in the fur trade
in this area. Later, the dominant business
was in tobacco. As crop, merchandise, cur-
rency—tobacco was the life of trade. Agricul-

ture, industry, commerce and finance all met

and mingled in tobacco. Valued at a penny
a pound, it was legal tender for taxes or
debts; currency for making any purchase. If
that seems a primitive economy, listen to
this:

““In 1666 Nathaniel Utie was one of the
commissioners appointed to effect an agree-
ment between Virginia, North Carolina, and
Maryland to suspend the planting of tobacco
for a year, so as to enhance its value!”

There were giants in those days. Men had
to be. Surrounded by a wilderness, with
slow transportation and communications,
water wheels their
only power—yet,
men founded manu-
facturing and milling

businesses, entered



into shipping which circled the world, bring-
ing its wealth here to their warehouses.
They fought for and established our nation

~and served it generously and still had time for

gracious, leisurely living! No wonder, with
such a tradition, Baltimore is a great indus-

DESCRIPTION OF THE PLAN

The purpose of the General Development Plan presented here is to pro-
vide information and guidance for the many public and private decisions
which will determine the future form of Baltimore’s metropolitan area.
This plan envisions a more desirable environment for living which this
Region might offer. It is a general suggestion for encouraging sound de-
velopment of our environment. It is long-range, looking ahead twenty to
twenty-five years. The plan recommends a land use pattern and major
public facilities. It is not a zoning map; the power to zone is exercised by
local government.

The plan is the culmination of years of study and research by the
Regional Planning Council, local planning bodies, and other representatives
of governments in the Region. It consists of a set of recommendations,
prepared pursuant to state law, to provide assistance to units of local
government and the state government in meeting the challenge of inevitable
growth. It focuses on problems and opportunities which are common to
several units of government or which affect more than one unit of govern-
ment. ' Its success depends on local action by local units of government,
both as they act individually and as they act through their representatives
on regional and state bodies.

The Regional Planning Council, in cooperation with the planning staffs
of the local and state governments, is undertaking further analyses of the
major elements of the General Development Plan. These studies will be
made public from time to time as they are completed.

The major elements of the plan reflect goals for the future physical
development of the area. The plan provides for well-coordinated develop-
ment of these elements, designed to make the best use of the land. These
elements are briefly described below.

Residential Development

Where and how well people live is the most important aspect of planning.
The residential framework of the plan proposes a variety of residential
development, planned in relation to physical characteristics, open space,

MILES

MILITARY, AIRPORTS



The basic highway network includes both interregional and intraregional .
facilities. Only freeways, expressways, and major urban and rural arterial
roads are shown in the plan. The network has been planned to encourage
development where it would be least costly to provide public services, and
to deter development where it would destroy prize open-space areas or
would be undesirable in other ways.

The principal additions to the existing system acknowledge the major
growth expected toward Columbia and Washington to the southwest, and
toward Wilmington and Philadelphia to the northeast. The new roads
include a new and better U. S. Route 1 extending northeast from the city;
Northwest and Liberty Expressways into the northwest part of the Region;
I-70N westerly in the general location of U. S. Route 40; an improved Route
29 and a continuation of I-95 through Howard County; and the Arundel
Freeway facilitating transportation in the urban portion of Anne Arundel
County and connecting with the Bay Bridge. Other major features include
links from the Beltway into the waterfront and industrial areas of Marley
Neck, Sparrows Point, Back River, and White Marsh; a future second
harbor crossing; and three connector freeways across the southern part of
the Region. In the future, major rural highways could connect the fringes
of the Region from Annapolis to Westminster, and then east across the
northern area to Aberdeen.

The mass transit system will provide vastly improved transportation
service for people travelling within the Region. The 65-mile rail portion
of the transit system consists of a loop surrounding the core of Baltimore,
and radial lines reaching from the inner-city loop outward along six major
development corridors. Subsequent transit extensions are possible to
Aberdeen, Annapolis, Columbia, and Washington when patronage warrants.

The rail rapid-transit system would be supported by a complex of
modern commuter express buses on exclusive rights of way and on the
freeways, and improved feeder bus lines from suburban residential areas
to the rail transit stations.

ANNES good transportation facilities, and convenient shopping areas. The plan Centers for the Region

beyond the high density areas and extending along principal transportation
corridors; and wider low density areas. Rural areas identify land recom-
mended to remain predominantly farmland.

These density proposals refer to overall intensity of development within
a sizable area. Many areas might contain not just one form of housing but
a reasonable and practicable variety of housing types.

Not every area shown will actually be developed. The plan leaves ade-
quate room for choice.

Open Space

The open space element of the plan provides many benefits for the
Region’s inhabitants. First, it recognizes the rural values of the Region.
In addition, it preserves features of the natural environment to make the
area more beautiful, protect natural resources, safeguard the water supply,
and provide land for recreation and leisure. One of its major purposes is
to serve as the background for more livable communities which will be
developed within the open space pattern.

There is still much open land because pressures for development have
not reached all of it. However, there is limited open space which is now
permanently reserved for the future. The plan provides a guide for the
public action which is needed to safeguard this natural heritage.

The plan defines three categories of open space. One is the primary
system which requires either acquisition or some form of public protection
of land which is subject to early development pressures, or which protects
public water supply watersheds, or contains unique natural features. The
primary system provides an interconnected series of reserves and recreation
areas which link together major existing recreation areas and open spaces,
areas of exceptional natural beauty, scenic and historic sites, and flood
plains. It generally follows the major stream and river valleys. Other parts
of the primary system include other water bodies, smaller scenic valleys and
historic sites, available open space around the headwaters of other rivers,
and scattered but significant public recreation sites along the bay.

activities, educational facilities, and numerous other aspects of daily urban
living.

The plan shows a development pattern which can improve these oppor-
tunities and make them more available to more people.

A strong central core for the Region is explicit in the plan — from the
strengthened highway network and the rail mass-transit system to the
revitalized high-density residential districts in the central area. These

. features work to reinforce the core as a thriving financial, business, resi-
dential, and cultural center supporting the economy of the Region, and
serving as a vital center of activity around the clock.

In addition to a strong downtown, a number of town centers are proposed
to serve as secondary concentrations of business and other activity. These
centers will offer a variety of urban opportunities including retail, com-
mercial services, and entertainment facilities. They can include govern-
ment, educational, institutional, and residential complexes. Many, like
the centers .of Towson and Annapolis, exist today. They are all located
amid large existing and future communities and are closely coordinated
with the transportation system, both highway and transit.

As the growth of the area continues, new carefully planned centers
should be created in presently undeveloped areas to serve these new com-
munities.

Industrial Land

Good industrial land is essential for the economic growth of any populous
region. Thousands of additional acres of land must be reserved for indus-
trial expansion in coming decades. At the present time, the largest in-
dustrial establishments are located around the Patapsco waterfront. Smaller
industrial developments are located throughout the Region.

Good transportation, water and sewer facilities, and other services are
necessary for industry. Areas proposed for industrial use in the plan are
along major highway and rail networks, at critical transportation intersec-

Most of the secondary system, and practically all of the conservation areas,
would remain in private ownership.

Transportation

The transportation network provides mobility for the citizens and visitors
of the Region. It determines how quickly and conveniently people can
travel within the Region. It guides growth by providing access to land
areas, and it represents the largest single public capital investment in the
Region. The two major features in the system are highways and mass
transit, both bus and rail.

and Baltimore-Washington Parkway.

Much of the success of the General Development Plan depends on the
people who live in the Region. Through their day-to-day decisions of where
to shop, where to build an apartment development, how to get to work,
where to build an industrial park, what to do on the weekend, the people
who live here, work here, invest here, and shop here will provide the
demand for which the public agencies will make their decisions.

This plan can offer a long-range guide to aid the people who must make

these decisions. G33q d

of governments in the Region. It consists of a set of recommendations,
prepared pursuant to state law, to provide assistance to units of local
government and the state government in meeting the challenge of inevitable
growth. It focuses on problems and opportunities which are common to
several units of government or which affect more than one unit of govern-
ment. ' Its success depends on local action by local units of government,
both as they act individually and as they act through their representatives
on regional and state bodies.

The Regional Planning Council, in cooperation with the planning staffs
of the local and state governments, is undertaking further analyses of the
major elements of the General Development Plan. These studies will be
made public from time to time as they are completed.

The major elements of the plan reflect goals for the future physical
development of the area. The plan provides for well-coordinated develop-
ment of these elements, designed to make the best use of the land. These
elements are briefly described below.

Residential Development

Where and how well people live is the most important aspect of planning.
The residential framework of the plan proposes a variety of residential
development, planned in relation to physical characteristics, open space,

HOWARD COUI

0 5 10

MILES

MILITARY, AIRPORTS



The basic highway network includes both interregional and intraregional .
facilities. Only freeways, expressways, and major urban and rural arterial
roads are shown in the plan. The network has been planned to encourage
development where it would be least costly to provide public services, and
to deter development where it would destroy prize open-space areas or
would be undesirable in other ways.

The principal additions to the existing system acknowledge the major
growth expected toward Columbia and Washington to the southwest, and
toward Wilmington and Philadelphia to the northeast. The new roads
include a new and better U. S. Route 1 extending northeast from the city;
Northwest and Liberty Expressways into the northwest part of the Region;
I-70N westerly in the general location of U. S. Route 40; an improved Route
29 and a continuation of I-95 through Howard County; and the Arundel
Freeway facilitating transportation in the urban portion of Anne Arundel
County and connecting with the Bay Bridge. Other major features include
links from the Beltway into the waterfront and industrial areas of Marley
Neck, Sparrows Point, Back River, and White Marsh; a future second
harbor crossing; and three connector freeways across the southern part of
the Region. In the future, major rural highways could connect the fringes
of the Region from Annapolis to Westminster, and then east across the
northern area to Aberdeen.

The mass transit system will provide vastly improved transportation
service for people travelling within the Region. The 65-mile rail portion
of the transit system consists of a loop surrounding the core of Baltimore,
and radial lines reaching from the inner-city loop outward along six major
development corridors. Subsequent transit extensions are possible to
Aberdeen, Annapolis, Columbia, and Washington when patronage warrants.

The rail rapid-transit system would be supported by a complex of
modern commuter express buses on exclusive rights of way and on the
freeways, and improved feeder bus lines from suburban residential areas
to the rail transit stations.

beyond the high density areas and extending along principal transportation
corridors; and wider low density areas. Rural areas identify land recom-
mended to remain predominantly farmland.

These density proposals refer to overall intensity of development within
a sizable area. Many areas might contain not just one form of housing but
a reasonable and practicable variety of housing types.

Not every area shown will actually be developed. The plan leaves ade-
quate room for choice.

Open Space

The open space element of the plan provides many benefits for the
Region’s inhabitants. First, it recognizes the rural values of the Region.
In addition, it preserves features of the natural environment to make the
area more beautiful, protect natural resources, safeguard the water supply,
and provide land for recreation and leisure. One of its major purposes is
to serve as the background for more livable communities which will be
developed within the open space pattern.

There is still much open land because pressures for development have
not reached all of it. However, there is limited open space which is now
permanently reserved for the future. The plan provides a guide for the
public action which is needed to safeguard this natural heritage.

The plan defines three categories of open space. One is the primary
system which requires either acquisition or some form of public protection
of land which is subject to early development pressures, or which protects
public water supply watersheds, or contains unique natural features. The
primary system provides an interconnected series of reserves and recreation
areas which link together major existing recreation areas and open spaces,
areas of exceptional natural beauty, scenic and historic sites, and flood
plains. It generally follows the major stream and river valleys. Other parts
of the primary system include other water bodies, smaller scenic valleys and
historic sites, available open space around the headwaters of other rivers,
and scattered but significant public recreation sites along the bay.

activities, educational facilities, and numerous other aspects of daily urban
living.

The plan shows a development pattern which can improve these oppor-
tunities and make them more available to more people.

A strong central core for the Region is explicit in the plan — from the
strengthened highway network and the rail mass-transit system to the
revitalized high-density residential districts in the central area. These

. features work to reinforce the core as a thriving financial, business, resi-
dential, and cultural center supporting the economy of the Region, and
serving as a vital center of activity around the clock.

In addition to a strong downtown, a number of town centers are proposed
to serve as secondary concentrations of business and other activity. These
centers will offer a variety of urban opportunities including retail, com-
mercial services, and entertainment facilities. They can include govern-
ment, educational, institutional, and residential complexes. Many, like
the centers .of Towson and Annapolis, exist today. They are all located
amid large existing and future communities and are closely coordinated
with the transportation system, both highway and transit.

As the growth of the area continues, new carefully planned centers
should be created in presently undeveloped areas to serve these new com-
munities.

Industrial Land

Good industrial land is essential for the economic growth of any populous
region. Thousands of additional acres of land must be reserved for indus-
trial expansion in coming decades. At the present time, the largest in-
dustrial establishments are located around the Patapsco waterfront. Smaller
industrial developments are located throughout the Region.

Good transportation, water and sewer facilities, and other services are
necessary for industry. Areas proposed for industrial use in the plan are
along major highway and rail networks, at critical transportation intersec-

Most of the secondary system, and practically all of the conservation areas,
would remain in private ownership.

Transportation

The transportation network provides mobility for the citizens and visitors
of the Region. It determines how quickly and conveniently people can
travel within the Region. It guides growth by providing access to land
areas, and it represents the largest single public capital investment in the
Region. The two major features in the system are highways and mass
transit, both bus and rail.

and Baltimore-Washington Parkway.

Much of the success of the General Development Plan depends on the
people who live in the Region. Through their day-to-day decisions of where
to shop, where to build an apartment development, how to get to work,
where to build an industrial park, what to do on the weekend, the people
who live here, work here, invest here, and shop here will provide the
demand for which the public agencies will make their decisions.

This plan can offer a long-range guide to aid the people who must make

these decisions. G33q d

/1982



When the Regional Planning Council was established in 1963 by the State Legislature, it was charged with
preparing a General Development Plan for the Baltimore Region. The purpose of this plan is best stated by the Act
which established the Council: ”An opportunity must be provided for the several units of government within the area
to work together with the State and private agencies toward the solution of their problems. In order to deal with these
matters on a rational and sound basis, they must be considered within the framework of a general development plan
for the area.” (Article 78D, Section 1.) Additionally, the Act establishes the general contents of the plan, as follows:
”The plan shall be based upon comprehensive surveys and studies of land use, transportation, public utilities,
governmental facilities and services, and natural resources. It shall take into account social and economic factors,
conditions, and trends that are relevant to the probable future development of the area.” (Article 78D, Section 12, (a).)

All three prior General Development Plans have followed this general outline while varying in thrust and de-
tail to meet the major issues of regional importance at the time of their preparation. The 1982 General Development
Plan is no exception and addresses the problems of implementing necessary programs in a time of reduced fiscal
resources, declining growth and a sluggish economy. The how and what to implement is the single most important
issue facing the state, region, and local governments at this time. Establishment of priorities, both in terms of
programs and facilities, is critical and must be matched by the means to secure the funds to pay for them. High
interest rates are making it more difficult for the state and local governments to raise funds for capital projects and
have also affected business expansion and formation with depressing effects on tax revenues. Additionally,
decreasing federal financial assistance is placing increased burdens on state and local resources.

Unfortunately, while revenue sources are decreasing or becoming more expensive to obtain, demands for
government expenditures are as high, or higher, than ever. In the era of rapid suburban growth following the Second
World War, enormous expenditures for new public facilities of all kinds were required to keep pace with needs, while
funds for maintenance of existing facilities were reduced. The facilities built during the fifties and sixties are in need
of repair and, in some cases, enlargement, while the other facilities on which maintenance had been deferred are in
great need of repair and, in many cases, replacement. Additionally, many older communities need revitalization and
new facilities.

In addressing these and other problems, many of which are not related to the physical facilities of the region but
to the social and economic needs of the residents, the Regional Planning Council has concentrated on seven major
areas of concern, i.e., Transportation, Economic Development, Housing, Land Use, Energy, Environment, and
Human Services. Each area of concern defines the most critical problems, examines program and project priorities,
and suggests a number of ways by which the necessary funding can be obtained. Following this analysis, a series of
goals are established with accompanying policies and strategies to achieve these goals. In many respects, the point of
view of this GDP is shorter than the usual 20 year range of previous plans as it is more involved with the short range (5
-10 years) view associated with plan and program implementation. However, many of the goals are long range in
nature and will require a considerable length of time before they can be achieved. On May 27, 1982, Governor Hughes
issued an Executive Order containing 72 major policies which will be used by state agencies as they make decisions
affecting development in Maryland. The goals and policies of the General Development Plan are consistent with and
serve to reaffirm and support the policies of the Executive Order.

In the following discussion, each of the areas of concern will be summarized with particular reference to the
issues and goals. These summaries are necessarily very brief and contain only the most critical issues, goals, and
findings. The reader interested in the policies and strategies developed to reach the recommended goals is referred to
the pertinent volumes which accompany this summary or to the volume of goals and policies which contains all of

the policies and strategies recommended by the Regional Planning Council.

J. Hugh Nichols
Chairman, Regional Planning Council

The Regional Growth Management Policy Map serves toillustrate a number of
the goals and policies of the 1982 General Development Plan. Major policy areas,
shown in color, are:

s
2.

3.

6.

Existing Development - existing urban areas regardless of land use type. &
Suburban Service Area - planned future urban growth areas with
necessary public facilities.

Open Space and Recreation - public parks, natural areas, and other
permanent open space.

Rural Service Area - intended for exclusion of urban growth and reserved
for agriculture, forestry, and related activities.

Agricultural Preservation Districts - areas within the Rural Servicé Area
where local governments are acquiring easements to preserve
agricultural land. '

Military Establishments

Superimposed, in black, upon these major areas are a number of special areas.
While seemingly unrelated, all of these special areas have an impact on the type or
form of development which can be accommodated. These special areas are:

il
2.

State Critical Areas - designated by the Department of State Planning.
Water Resources Protection Areas - development should be carefully
controlled to protect quality of surface water reservoirs or ground water
resources.

Airport Noise District - restrictions required on development due to
aircraft noise.

Air Quality Management Area - non-attainment area for particulate (dust)
standards with restrictions on industrial development.

Historic Preservation Districts - historic and/or architecturally
significant areas.

Water Quality Growth Caution Areas - portions of the Suburban Service
Area requiring particular care to prevent pollution of surface or ground
water resources.

A number of existing or planned transportation facilities are also shown:

1

Highway and Transit Facilities - new interstate and other highway and
transit projects on new locations which are programmed for construction
or project planning; does not include widening, resurfacing, or similar

improvements.



In contrast to prior General Development Plans which
contained major land use analyses and recommendations, the
1982 Plan restricts itself to an examination of the degree to which
local and regional plans are being implemented. Since 1977, all
of the jurisdictions in the region have revised or adopted plans
containing the concepts of centralized development and growth
management which were the major precepts of the 1977 General
Development Plan. As a result, the major land use goals were
considered to be valid and are included in the 1982 Plan. The
basic development goal is as follows:

THE REGION’S RESOURCES SHOULD BE
MANAGED TO PROMOTE AND ACHIEVE A MORE
CENTRALIZED DEVELOPMENT PATTERN.
SIMULTANEOUSLY, PUBLIC ACTIONS SHOULD
BE DESIGNED TO ENHANCE, MAINTAIN, AND
REVITALIZE EXISTING COMMUNITIES. PUBLIC
POLICIES SHOULD ENCOURAGE THE GROWTH
OF METROCENTER AND OTHER TOWN AND
COMMUNITY CENTERS. THE RURAL SERVICE
AREA SHOULD BE PRESERVED FOR FARMING
AND FORESTRY, PUBLIC WATERSHED
PROTECTION AND MAJOR PUBLIC PARKLAND,
AND NEW WELL-PLANNED DEVELOPMENT
SHOULD UTILIZE LAND RESOURCES WITHIN
EXISTING COMMUNITIES AND IN CAREFULLY
STAGED NEW GROWTH AREAS IN SEQUENCE
WITH THE ORDERLY PROVISION OF PUBLIC
SERVICES AND FACILITIES. BALTIMORE CITY
SHOULD RECEIVE A GREATER SHARE OF THE
REGION’S GROWTH.

With general agreement as to development form and
location, the critical element is the degree to which this
development pattern is being achieved, with particular reference
to the provision and scheduling of public facilities. The ability
to acquire the necessary capital resources to provide these
facilities is also a key issue addressed by the 1982 General
Development Plan. These issues were addressed by examining
the means by which the local governments in the region are
considering or are using innovative techniques to provide
capital resources including greater cooperation with the private
sector, and by examining the degree to which the plans and
programs for sewerage and transportation facilities serve to meet
the development goals of the local jurisdictions.

A wide range of development policies exists in the region
together with measures designed to implement them. In
implementing these policies local governments have become
dependent, to varying degrees, on infusion of federal and state
financing required to subsidize urban renewal and support the
construction, reconstruction, and maintenance of public facility
systems. The withdrawal, or substantial reduction of federal aid,
threatens severe cutbacks in development policy
implementation. This analysis represents an initial attempt to
define how the various jurisdictions intend or are coping with

these realities. The following observations have resulted from
this preliminary investigation:

B ILarger amounts of private capital may become
available to help undertake all phases of land
development, including basic infrastructure, than in
the past. Developers with access to large sources of
investment funds, coupled with a vested interest in
the region, can open varied new routes to community
development. This has occurred in the past and is
currently the best potential source of private
assistance.

B Public support and participation in development
ventures, through traditional as well as innovative
activities, will continue as a basic requirement.
Coordinated planning and programming within and
among public facility systems are requisites to the
staging and financing of growth.

B Opportunities for coventuré between local
governments and representatives of the private sector
should be solicited. Negotiation of individual and
joint responsibilities are critical to all phases of such
undertakings, including the creation of mechanisms
to handle features such as multi-source funding and
cost-sharing arrangements.

B Measures for recovery of capital investments
equitably, without devastation of the market, are
essential. Return to some forms of long term, below
marketing financing, with recovery spread over a
broad revenue base, seems preferable to short term
loading of capital costs solely on new homebuyers.

B Careful use of innovative capital financing
techniques, such as sale-leaseback, can relieve public
financial problems in some cases, releasing
traditional governmental powers to assume fiscal
obligations elsewhere.

Baltimore City occupies a unique position in the
metropolitan area and its problems are those normally
associated with renewal and revitalization. Great strides have
been made in meeting many of these needs using combinations
of federal, state, local, and private funds as well as varied
institutional arrangements. These efforts are exemplified by
Charles Center, the Inner Harbor and Harborplace, and the
Convention Center. A great deal remains to be done throughout
the city and particularly with the vast system of sewer and water
lines, roads, and bridges. As an example of the magnitude of this
problem, some $600 million will be required for wastewater
system maintenance and replacement alone without considering
any other portions of the infrastructure. The city intends to use a
number of ”creative capital funding” measures to meet these
needs including ”sale-leaseback” in which the city will sell a
particular facility to a private investor then lease it back. The
investor is able to benefit from tax write-offs, credits, and
depreciation allowances. No matter how creative, however, most
programs will still be dependent upon state and federal
assistance as well as the traditional fiscal operations.

Another section of the land use analysis “Coordination of
Sewerage and Transportation Investments for Regional
Development” investigates the degree to which major public
investments in sewerage and transportation facilities serve to
support and enhance regional and local development policies.
This work is intended to identify those planned growth areas in
the region which will need new or enlarged facilities in order to
meet local development goals.

The analysis used Regional Planning Districts (RPD) as
the means of identifying growth areas, although in many cases
only a portion of those rather large areas would contain planned
urban growth. A total of 38 RPDs (out of a total of 94 RPDs in
the region) were selected for analysis. Together they account for
89.7% and 76.1% of the projected 1980-1990 population and

employment growth respectively. Existing development
activity, 1978-1980, was then examined using Baltimore Gas and
Electric Company connection data and Regional Planning
Council employment data. The final step was to analyze the
adequacy of both the sewer and transportation systems to
support the demands of the projected growth.

This analysis was done on a very general level and
included planned and programmed facilities and their
approximate times of completion, in order to arrive at general
levels of adequacy to meet growth needs. It must be remembered
that this provides only a guide to facility needs and will be most
useful in future studies to determine project priorities.

Findings of this study indicate that only five of the thirty-
eight RPDs selected for analysis have severe sewerage and/or
transportation system deficiencies. These areas are not evenly
spread throughout the region but are concentrated in Anne
Arundel and Carroll counties, and while they account for only
15.5% of the region’s projected population growth they are
planned to contain 32% of Anne Arundel County and 46% of
Carroll County’s growth.

The bulk of the RPDs examined (26) show problems from
either sewerage system or transportation facility inadequacy and
are fairly evenly distributed throughout the region. Due to the
fact that these areas account for 60.6% and 76% of the region’s
projected population and employment growth respectively, it is
important to carefully program the facilities necessary to correct
system deficiencies.

Results of this study indicate that there are a number of
critical facility problems which must be addressed if the region
and its local governments are to realize their development
objectives. Additionally, it will not be possible to eliminate all of
these deficiencies in the next few years due to funding and other
constraints. While this analysis, which is only a first look at
these problems on a regional level, is by no means definitive it
should prove to be a valuable tool in assisting the state, regional,
and local governments in better defining their facility
construction priorities in the future.



Since the preparation of the 1977 General Development
Plan, there have been some very significant changes in
conditions underlying Baltimore’s future economic prospects.
Some have been positive:

B The transformation of Baltimore’s Inner Harbor
from an wurban eyesore to an internationally
recognized revitalization site.

® The opening of the Convention Center, Harborplace,
and the National Aquarium generated new
employment and further diversified the local
economy.

B Major construction projects, such as the Baltimore
Metro and Ft. McHenry Tunnel, will enhance the
movement of people and goods throughout the
region.

B Worldwide energy demand has enhanced Baltimore’s

position as one of the leading United States coal ports
with a multi-million dollar infusion of capital into
the Port.

Some have been negative:

m The long term trend away from the production of
goods is accelerating with continued dislocation of
workers from economic sectors long basic to this
area’s economy.

B Government service employment, which once served
to cushion declines in industry, has been declining
since the late 1970s.

B The consequences of new economic policies in
Washington, featuring tight monetary policy and
shifting of responsibility from federal to state local
governments are still uncertain.

® Unemployment has continued to increase
particularly among blacks.

As a result of these and other changes, the 1982 General

Development Plan has focussed on a few important issues which
can be effectively addressed by state and local decision makers.

Issue: Capturing a Share of Growth Industries

/1982



When the Regional Planning Council was established in 1963 by the State Legislature, it was charged with
preparing a General Development Plan for the Baltimore Region. The purpose of this plan is best stated by the Act
which established the Council: ”An opportunity must be provided for the several units of government within the area
to work together with the State and private agencies toward the solution of their problems. In order to deal with these
matters on a rational and sound basis, they must be considered within the framework of a general development plan
for the area.” (Article 78D, Section 1.) Additionally, the Act establishes the general contents of the plan, as follows:
”The plan shall be based upon comprehensive surveys and studies of land use, transportation, public utilities,
governmental facilities and services, and natural resources. It shall take into account social and economic factors,
conditions, and trends that are relevant to the probable future development of the area.” (Article 78D, Section 12, (a).)

All three prior General Development Plans have followed this general outline while varying in thrust and de-
tail to meet the major issues of regional importance at the time of their preparation. The 1982 General Development
Plan is no exception and addresses the problems of implementing necessary programs in a time of reduced fiscal
resources, declining growth and a sluggish economy. The how and what to implement is the single most important
issue facing the state, region, and local governments at this time. Establishment of priorities, both in terms of
programs and facilities, is critical and must be matched by the means to secure the funds to pay for them. High
interest rates are making it more difficult for the state and local governments to raise funds for capital projects and
have also affected business expansion and formation with depressing effects on tax revenues. Additionally,
decreasing federal financial assistance is placing increased burdens on state and local resources.

Unfortunately, while revenue sources are decreasing or becoming more expensive to obtain, demands for
government expenditures are as high, or higher, than ever. In the era of rapid suburban growth following the Second
World War, enormous expenditures for new public facilities of all kinds were required to keep pace with needs, while
funds for maintenance of existing facilities were reduced. The facilities built during the fifties and sixties are in need
of repair and, in some cases, enlargement, while the other facilities on which maintenance had been deferred are in
great need of repair and, in many cases, replacement. Additionally, many older communities need revitalization and
new facilities.

In addressing these and other problems, many of which are not related to the physical facilities of the region but
to the social and economic needs of the residents, the Regional Planning Council has concentrated on seven major
areas of concern, i.e., Transportation, Economic Development, Housing, Land Use, Energy, Environment, and
Human Services. Each area of concern defines the most critical problems, examines program and project priorities,
and suggests a number of ways by which the necessary funding can be obtained. Following this analysis, a series of
goals are established with accompanying policies and strategies to achieve these goals. In many respects, the point of
view of this GDP is shorter than the usual 20 year range of previous plans as it is more involved with the short range (5
-10 years) view associated with plan and program implementation. However, many of the goals are long range in
nature and will require a considerable length of time before they can be achieved. On May 27, 1982, Governor Hughes
issued an Executive Order containing 72 major policies which will be used by state agencies as they make decisions
affecting development in Maryland. The goals and policies of the General Development Plan are consistent with and
serve to reaffirm and support the policies of the Executive Order.

In the following discussion, each of the areas of concern will be summarized with particular reference to the
issues and goals. These summaries are necessarily very brief and contain only the most critical issues, goals, and
findings. The reader interested in the policies and strategies developed to reach the recommended goals is referred to
the pertinent volumes which accompany this summary or to the volume of goals and policies which contains all of

the policies and strategies recommended by the Regional Planning Council.

J. Hugh Nichols
Chairman, Regional Planning Council

The Regional Growth Management Policy Map serves toillustrate a number of
the goals and policies of the 1982 General Development Plan. Major policy areas,
shown in color, are:

s
2.

3.

6.

Existing Development - existing urban areas regardless of land use type. &
Suburban Service Area - planned future urban growth areas with
necessary public facilities.

Open Space and Recreation - public parks, natural areas, and other
permanent open space.

Rural Service Area - intended for exclusion of urban growth and reserved
for agriculture, forestry, and related activities.

Agricultural Preservation Districts - areas within the Rural Servicé Area
where local governments are acquiring easements to preserve
agricultural land. '

Military Establishments

Superimposed, in black, upon these major areas are a number of special areas.
While seemingly unrelated, all of these special areas have an impact on the type or
form of development which can be accommodated. These special areas are:

il
2.

State Critical Areas - designated by the Department of State Planning.
Water Resources Protection Areas - development should be carefully
controlled to protect quality of surface water reservoirs or ground water
resources.

Airport Noise District - restrictions required on development due to
aircraft noise.

Air Quality Management Area - non-attainment area for particulate (dust)
standards with restrictions on industrial development.

Historic Preservation Districts - historic and/or architecturally
significant areas.

Water Quality Growth Caution Areas - portions of the Suburban Service
Area requiring particular care to prevent pollution of surface or ground
water resources.

A number of existing or planned transportation facilities are also shown:

1

Highway and Transit Facilities - new interstate and other highway and
transit projects on new locations which are programmed for construction
or project planning; does not include widening, resurfacing, or similar

improvements.



In contrast to prior General Development Plans which
contained major land use analyses and recommendations, the
1982 Plan restricts itself to an examination of the degree to which
local and regional plans are being implemented. Since 1977, all
of the jurisdictions in the region have revised or adopted plans
containing the concepts of centralized development and growth
management which were the major precepts of the 1977 General
Development Plan. As a result, the major land use goals were
considered to be valid and are included in the 1982 Plan. The
basic development goal is as follows:

THE REGION’S RESOURCES SHOULD BE
MANAGED TO PROMOTE AND ACHIEVE A MORE
CENTRALIZED DEVELOPMENT PATTERN.
SIMULTANEOUSLY, PUBLIC ACTIONS SHOULD
BE DESIGNED TO ENHANCE, MAINTAIN, AND
REVITALIZE EXISTING COMMUNITIES. PUBLIC
POLICIES SHOULD ENCOURAGE THE GROWTH
OF METROCENTER AND OTHER TOWN AND
COMMUNITY CENTERS. THE RURAL SERVICE
AREA SHOULD BE PRESERVED FOR FARMING
AND FORESTRY, PUBLIC WATERSHED
PROTECTION AND MAJOR PUBLIC PARKLAND,
AND NEW WELL-PLANNED DEVELOPMENT
SHOULD UTILIZE LAND RESOURCES WITHIN
EXISTING COMMUNITIES AND IN CAREFULLY
STAGED NEW GROWTH AREAS IN SEQUENCE
WITH THE ORDERLY PROVISION OF PUBLIC
SERVICES AND FACILITIES. BALTIMORE CITY
SHOULD RECEIVE A GREATER SHARE OF THE
REGION’S GROWTH.

With general agreement as to development form and
location, the critical element is the degree to which this
development pattern is being achieved, with particular reference
to the provision and scheduling of public facilities. The ability
to acquire the necessary capital resources to provide these
facilities is also a key issue addressed by the 1982 General
Development Plan. These issues were addressed by examining
the means by which the local governments in the region are
considering or are using innovative techniques to provide
capital resources including greater cooperation with the private
sector, and by examining the degree to which the plans and
programs for sewerage and transportation facilities serve to meet
the development goals of the local jurisdictions.

A wide range of development policies exists in the region
together with measures designed to implement them. In
implementing these policies local governments have become
dependent, to varying degrees, on infusion of federal and state
financing required to subsidize urban renewal and support the
construction, reconstruction, and maintenance of public facility
systems. The withdrawal, or substantial reduction of federal aid,
threatens severe cutbacks in development policy
implementation. This analysis represents an initial attempt to
define how the various jurisdictions intend or are coping with

these realities. The following observations have resulted from
this preliminary investigation:

B ILarger amounts of private capital may become
available to help undertake all phases of land
development, including basic infrastructure, than in
the past. Developers with access to large sources of
investment funds, coupled with a vested interest in
the region, can open varied new routes to community
development. This has occurred in the past and is
currently the best potential source of private
assistance.

B Public support and participation in development
ventures, through traditional as well as innovative
activities, will continue as a basic requirement.
Coordinated planning and programming within and
among public facility systems are requisites to the
staging and financing of growth.

B Opportunities for coventuré between local
governments and representatives of the private sector
should be solicited. Negotiation of individual and
joint responsibilities are critical to all phases of such
undertakings, including the creation of mechanisms
to handle features such as multi-source funding and
cost-sharing arrangements.

B Measures for recovery of capital investments
equitably, without devastation of the market, are
essential. Return to some forms of long term, below
marketing financing, with recovery spread over a
broad revenue base, seems preferable to short term
loading of capital costs solely on new homebuyers.

B Careful use of innovative capital financing
techniques, such as sale-leaseback, can relieve public
financial problems in some cases, releasing
traditional governmental powers to assume fiscal
obligations elsewhere.

Baltimore City occupies a unique position in the
metropolitan area and its problems are those normally
associated with renewal and revitalization. Great strides have
been made in meeting many of these needs using combinations
of federal, state, local, and private funds as well as varied
institutional arrangements. These efforts are exemplified by
Charles Center, the Inner Harbor and Harborplace, and the
Convention Center. A great deal remains to be done throughout
the city and particularly with the vast system of sewer and water
lines, roads, and bridges. As an example of the magnitude of this
problem, some $600 million will be required for wastewater
system maintenance and replacement alone without considering
any other portions of the infrastructure. The city intends to use a
number of ”creative capital funding” measures to meet these
needs including ”sale-leaseback” in which the city will sell a
particular facility to a private investor then lease it back. The
investor is able to benefit from tax write-offs, credits, and
depreciation allowances. No matter how creative, however, most
programs will still be dependent upon state and federal
assistance as well as the traditional fiscal operations.

Another section of the land use analysis “Coordination of
Sewerage and Transportation Investments for Regional
Development” investigates the degree to which major public
investments in sewerage and transportation facilities serve to
support and enhance regional and local development policies.
This work is intended to identify those planned growth areas in
the region which will need new or enlarged facilities in order to
meet local development goals.

The analysis used Regional Planning Districts (RPD) as
the means of identifying growth areas, although in many cases
only a portion of those rather large areas would contain planned
urban growth. A total of 38 RPDs (out of a total of 94 RPDs in
the region) were selected for analysis. Together they account for
89.7% and 76.1% of the projected 1980-1990 population and

employment growth respectively. Existing development
activity, 1978-1980, was then examined using Baltimore Gas and
Electric Company connection data and Regional Planning
Council employment data. The final step was to analyze the
adequacy of both the sewer and transportation systems to
support the demands of the projected growth.

This analysis was done on a very general level and
included planned and programmed facilities and their
approximate times of completion, in order to arrive at general
levels of adequacy to meet growth needs. It must be remembered
that this provides only a guide to facility needs and will be most
useful in future studies to determine project priorities.

Findings of this study indicate that only five of the thirty-
eight RPDs selected for analysis have severe sewerage and/or
transportation system deficiencies. These areas are not evenly
spread throughout the region but are concentrated in Anne
Arundel and Carroll counties, and while they account for only
15.5% of the region’s projected population growth they are
planned to contain 32% of Anne Arundel County and 46% of
Carroll County’s growth.

The bulk of the RPDs examined (26) show problems from
either sewerage system or transportation facility inadequacy and
are fairly evenly distributed throughout the region. Due to the
fact that these areas account for 60.6% and 76% of the region’s
projected population and employment growth respectively, it is
important to carefully program the facilities necessary to correct
system deficiencies.

Results of this study indicate that there are a number of
critical facility problems which must be addressed if the region
and its local governments are to realize their development
objectives. Additionally, it will not be possible to eliminate all of
these deficiencies in the next few years due to funding and other
constraints. While this analysis, which is only a first look at
these problems on a regional level, is by no means definitive it
should prove to be a valuable tool in assisting the state, regional,
and local governments in better defining their facility
construction priorities in the future.



Since the preparation of the 1977 General Development
Plan, there have been some very significant changes in
conditions underlying Baltimore’s future economic prospects.

from an wurban eyesore to an internationally
recognized revitalization site.

and the National Aquarium generated new
employment and further diversified the local
economy.

B Major construction projects, such as the Baltimore
Metro and Ft. McHenry Tunnel, will enhance the
movement of people and goods throughout the
region.

B Worldwide energy demand has enhanced Baltimore’s

position as one of the leading United States coal ports
with a multi-million dollar infusion of capital into
the Port.

Some have been negative:

m The long term trend away from the production of
goods is accelerating with continued dislocation of
workers from economic sectors long basic to this
area’s economy.

B Government service employment, which once served
to cushion declines in industry, has been declining
since the late 1970s.

B The consequences of new economic policies in
Washington, featuring tight monetary policy and
shifting of responsibility from federal to state local
governments are still uncertain.

® Unemployment has continued to increase
particularly among blacks.

Development Plan has focussed on a few important issues which

A MESSAGE FROM MAYOR WILLIAM DONALD SCHAEFER

Great opportunity awaits you in Market Center downtown. Here
in the heart of Baltimore, we have turned plans into successful results
which will generate a good return on your future investments. The
Charles Center complex and our Inner Harbor are internationally
acclaimed proof that the Baltimore development process works.

Our newest venture, Market Center, is a continuation of our other
important development successes. Handsome buildings, many quali-
fying for tax credits, are available for retail, residential, and commer-
cial rehabilitation. Prime sites for new single use and mixed-use
development are available throughout the District. Currently, close
to $250 million in public/private construction is underway or com-
pleted with much more coming on stream this year.

We have worked very hard in Baltimore to make it easy for business
people to achieve their development goals. The City has poured
millions of dollars into needed public improvements and necessary
public financing for projects. A vital ingredient in the Market Center
development mix has been the active participation of a Project Area

Committee whose 800 members have critiqued and endorsed the
planning process. Among the more unique approaches are a promo-
tion fee used to advertise retail and special events and an upgrading
of 650 area facades, perhaps the most ambitious such undertaking
in the nation.

Market Center’s success is the result of a combination of impor-
tant elements: a positive partnership between all levels of government,
a vibrant private sector involvement, and the support and good will
of the Market Center business people, the media, and principally,
the citizens of Baltimore. It is a stunning example of a progressive
vision in urban development producing opportunities and results!

I cordially urge you to visit us and discover these unique oppor-
tunities for your future growth.

Sinc

THE CROSSROADS OF BALTIMORE

The Crossroads at Howard and Lexington Streets has long
been the heart of Baltimore. Within two blocks of this vital
location, over 2,000 new employees now work in more than
600,000 square feet of new and rehabilitated office/retail
space.

The Crossroads is the center of downtown transportation
modes. The new Howard Street Transit Mall intersects with
Lexington Mall, the busiest pedestrian corridor downtown.
This tree-lined, brick promenade links the Charles Center
office cluster with the world-famous Lexington Market.
Along the way are three department stores and scores of
specialty shops.

As the name implies, The Crossroads is the focus of
downtown activity. Within a few minutes’ walk are various

office, residential and recreational options, as well as approx-
imately one million square feet of retail space. Many of
Baltimore’s world-class cultural and educational institutions
are no more than a 10 to 15 minute walk away. Many of
Baltimore’s famous restaurants and hotels are within an easy

walk of The Crossroads.

The major station stop on the Baltimore Metro, less than
a block away, runs ahead of ridership projections. Some
three-fourths of all Metro buses stop on or just off Howard
Street. Over 4,000 off-street spaces are within a two-minute
walk. Super highway access is just down the street, providing
an easy drive time to Washington, DC.

MARKET CENTER IN DOWNTOWN BALTIMORE D,

The transformation of Baltimore from dowdy, old
port city to international urban magnet is an
unparalleled development success story. While the
development of Charles Center and the Inner
Harbor is justly acclaimed, Baltimore continues to
offer sound development opportunities downtown.
Market Center is where the action is and will be.

Market Center is where downtown started in
Baltimore. This traditional retail core of one million
square feet is surrounded by vital clusters of business,
medical, cultural, educational and residential uses.

These include a favorite Baltimore attraction, the
204 year old Lexington Market; the University of
Maryland Graduate Professional Schools, the

MARKET CENTER
DEVELOPMENT

internationally acclaimed Shock Trauma Center,
University Hospital, Social Security Administration
Complex, the Charles Center office cluster, the
specialty shops and galleries on Charles Street, the
State of Maryland office complex, the Mt. Royal
cultural district, and new residential neighborhoods
in Seton Hill and the Loft District.

Market Center offers distinct advantages for
developers and investors. First, there is the Baltimore
talent for creative public/private financing. Second,
developers can depend on a predictable municipal
process. Third, within the 225-acre Market Center
area are handsome buildings which will generate
rehabilitation tax benefits. New construction poten-

and small projects.

volunteer business community and citizenry endors-
ing development action through the Market Center
Project Area Committee; the unique, non-profit,
quasi-public Market Center Development Corpora-
tion of Baltimore, and the full cooperation of
municipal agencies and boards.

Improve Physical
Appearance of Market

¢ Implement public improvements to complement private

graphics, banners, street furniture and other elements to

and to create a sense of place.

facade improvement program with private property
owners, consistent with required rehabilitation
standards.

Rehabilitated Buildings

building, and to provide the climate for expanding office
use by the State of Maryland.

tation and development of new mid to high-rise

Recent and Current
Development

16. Saratoga State Center: Rehabilitation by Baltimore
City of the old Hutzler’s Department Store into
120,000 square feet of office space for a major State
agency and 20,000 square feet retail.

17. One Market Center: UMTA Joint Development
project at the Lexington Market Metro Station involv-
ing 200,000 square feet of office and retail, including
70,000 square feet for Hutzler’s new department store.

18. Hecht Company Department Store: Rehabilitation
of 129,000 square feet of the store’s interior and
exterior, plus renovation of 75,000 square feet on the
top three floors for office use.

19. Epstein’s Department Store: Interior and major
exterior rehabilitation of a 90,000 square foot depart-
ment store.

20. Lexington Market Arcade: Major addition to the
204 year old Lexington Market with food stalls, a
restaurant, entertainment area and sit down eating
space. The existing 88-stall Lexington Market East
building was also rehabilitated.

21. Lexington Mall: One block expansion of the existing
two-block pedestrian mall.

22.Howard Street Transit Mall: Twelve-block
streetscape and utility reconstruction project with
emphasis on a two-block pedestrian/transit mall at
the Lexington Mall crossing.

23. Market Center Garage: 740-car parking structure
featuring direct access into the Lexington Market.
24.100 N. Eutaw Street: A rehabilitated 30,000 square

foot building for State office use.



25. Master Hosts Inn: Complete renovation of a
120-room hotel.

26. Baltimore Street Garage: Privately developed new
garage structure for 500 cars.

27.Department of Education Office Building:
Rehabilitation of an 11-story building into headquarters
for this major State agency.

28. Murdock Place-Professional Center: Rehabilita-
tion of a 25,000 square foot historic building for head-
quarters and professional office.

29. Charles Center: Park Charles, a mixed-use project,
the last to be completed in nearby Charles Center, and
One Center Plaza, a new 180,000 square foot office
building.

30. Lexington Mall — Liberty Street Crossing:
Reconstruction of this link between Market Center
and Charles Center, including major public art work.

Future Opportunities

e Parcel I-C: UMTA Joint Development Project site
adjacent to the Metro Station for a 500,000-1,000,000
square foot office tower, retail, and garage.

e Parcel II: Development of 200,000-400,000 square foot
office towers above retail and sub-surface garage abut-
ting the Lexington Market Arcade.

¢ Hotel-Conference Center: Potential for new
development, including the rehabilitation of two
historic register quality banks and a movie palace for
conference, entertainment and meeting facilities.

¢ (Clay Street Mixed-Use Development: Potential
for high-rise residential, retail, and office adjacent to
Charles Center.

MARKET CENTER IN DOWNTOWN BALTIMORE D,

The transformation of Baltimore from dowdy, old
port city to international urban magnet is an
unparalleled development success story. While the
development of Charles Center and the Inner
Harbor is justly acclaimed, Baltimore continues to
offer sound development opportunities downtown.
Market Center is where the action is and will be.

Market Center is where downtown started in
Baltimore. This traditional retail core of one million
square feet is surrounded by vital clusters of business,
medical, cultural, educational and residential uses.

These include a favorite Baltimore attraction, the
204 year old Lexington Market; the University of
Maryland Graduate Professional Schools, the

MARKET CENTER
DEVELOPMENT

internationally acclaimed Shock Trauma Center,
University Hospital, Social Security Administration
Complex, the Charles Center office cluster, the
specialty shops and galleries on Charles Street, the
State of Maryland office complex, the Mt. Royal
cultural district, and new residential neighborhoods
in Seton Hill and the Loft District.

Market Center offers distinct advantages for
developers and investors. First, there is the Baltimore
talent for creative public/private financing. Second,
developers can depend on a predictable municipal
process. Third, within the 225-acre Market Center
area are handsome buildings which will generate
rehabilitation tax benefits. New construction poten-

NORTH MARKET CENTER e



tial is here as well, with sites available for both large
and small projects.

Many feel the priceless advantage of doing business
in Market Center is the powerful role played by
results-oriented leadership. There are four elements:
a strong and committed Mayor, an enthusiastic
volunteer business community and citizenry endors-
ing development action through the Market Center
Project Area Committee; the unique, non-profit,
quasi-public Market Center Development Corpora-
tion of Baltimore, and the full cooperation of
municipal agencies and boards.

R

tion on the Potomac, midway between the North and the South,

the word tidewater was a good one to conjure with, and naviga-
~ tion meant the largest means of commerce, for waterways then

- afforded the easiest mode of travel and transportation. Other

~ to swift and casy riding; and steel rails that lead nortl, south,
. east, and west bear well-loaded trains which move at a speed

or incredible.: Even the air has now become a thoroughfare,
~and aircraft may daﬂy be seen flying afar from an dviation field
- at Wasliington. :
Tidewater nawgatmn may have lost some of its appeal in our

day, yet from time to time light-draft war vessels of the United

States and of other nations ecome from' all the world’s seas to
anchor by the United States Navy Yard at Washington. The
Potomac is still the same noble river that was ferried by George
Washington—far more majestic than the Thames, the Seine, or
the Tiber, on which stand great capitals of the Old World—
and its glamour is now glogiously enriched by sacréd memories.
The Arlington Mangion, which was built on a site familiar to
George Washington and which before the Civil War was the
home of a great Southerner, stands to-day among thirty thou-

sand graves as a shrine of national devotion and a pledge of

national unity: From the portals of the mansion the visitor

may see the river gleaming. just below, and beyond it liesa
scene that Lafayette, when a guest there, pronounced the
finest in the world, now made still finer by a beautified city
thwt has become a place of pilgrimage for all Americans.

“A few miles downstream from Arlington stands historic
Alexandria, where Washington worshiped, a eity much older
thau the Capital, lying midway between it and Mount Vernon,

x the home of Washington, another American Mecca.

* Annapolis, the capital of Maryland, thirty miles east of Wash -
_mv\ton, stands at tidewater on the Severn, close to Chesapeake
Bay, the largest and perhaps the most attractive body of water
of its kind along the Atlantic coast. Annapolis is proud of a
history that extends far back into Colonial times. There once
sat the Continental Congress, and there George Washington
resigned his commission as Commander in Chief. Future
officers of our warships receive training at Annapolis, at the
United States Naval Academy.

The country around Washington shown on the other side of
this sheet is full of historic memories. Bladensburg, a few
miles northeast of the city, remembered for its old dueling
ground, recalls to mind the death there of Commodore Decatur,
“the hero of Tripoli.” There also was made a feeble defense of
the city against British-invaders who burned both the Capitol
and the White House in our second war with England. We
.remembeér, too, that later in that same war an American held
for a time as a prisoner on a British vessel in the harbor of
Baltimore gave us in an hour of stress “The Star-Spangled
Banner.”

~ The Civil War also left here its marks and its memories.
‘Through the streets of Frederick, forty miles northwest of
Washington, on that *‘cool September morn” sung by Whittier,
“Stonewall” Jackson’s men marched, menacingly, too near the
Capital. Later a small force under -the eommand of Jubal
Early achieved the nearest approach ‘to the city made by the
“soldiers of the Southern Confederacy, in a battle whose site is
marked by gravestones to be seen only a few miles north of
Washington. The curious traveler may stand to-day, if he
will.just where Lincoln stood under fire in ’64 on the ram-
parts of an earthen fort to survey the scene of that buttle.
Remnants of similar forts that then made a chain around the
city may still be found here and there in the suburbs. Sites
of battle fields dot the country southwest of Washington, across
the Potomac. There on the map we may see the suggestive
names Bull Run, Manassas, and Chantilly.

Sinee the days of the Civil War Washington has grown in
population fromeless than 100,000 to nearly 450,000 and
Baltimore from about 250,000 to more than 770,000, each
'spreadmg far beyond its war-time limits, and scores of villages
have sprung up in the countrysrde between and around the
two cities.

This region recalls also some events of history of quite
another kmd One of the earliest railroads operated in the

- United States was _that between Washington and Baltimore,

and the first telegraph line in the world carried words between
those cities. Samuel Pierpont Langley, Secretary of the

Smltheeman Institution, tried out on the Potomac near Wash-

ington, 1, amid general glbes and derision, hrs expenmental flying

- that are linked with this region the subtle yet effective work of i _ Chesapeake Bay is a fine example of what is called a “drowned. .

‘natural forces on the face of the earth has here been carried
along unceasingly. The natural features of the region shotm
on the map are those which are peculiar to the country that lies

along what is called the “fall line”—the line or zone in which

the streams of the southern Atlantic slope fall in cataracts - .

or rapids. from the Piedmont Plateau to the Coastal Plain.
Washington, Baltimore, and other cities farther north or south

stand in this zone, which marks the head of navigation and .

so determined their location. In the area northwest of this
zone the streams flow swiftly or turbulently in rather narrow
channels; in the area southeast of it, at least in this region, they
become broad tidal estuaries. The Potomac makes its largest
leap at Grreat Falls, about 16 miles above Washington, and it
foams in a smaller cascade at Little Falls, about 5 miles above
the city. Those who may journey to Great Falls will find
there, on the Virginia side, a half-ruined stretch of a part of
a canal built under the direction of George Washington as a
link in a projected chain of waterways designed to connect the

“East and the West of his day. This canal was replaced by

the Chesapeake and Ohio Canal, on the Maryland side of the

river, which extends from Washingfon to Cumberland. The
- seene at the falls is impressively wild and rugged. Here the

river has long been wearing its way into hard rocks—gnelss
and schist—and in a deep gorge thus made below the falls its
waters surge swiftly forward in their course to the sea.

At Washington the Potomac is joined by the Anacostia— -

the “Eastern Branch” — on which, it is said, boats once
ascended on tidewater to Bladensburg. In the Piedmont
country we can see how stream beds are cut; here, on the
Coastal Plain, ‘'we can see how, by similar slow yet ceaseless

-natural processes, stream beds are filled up; and we have
learned, too, that the crust of the earth, seemlngly so stable, -

is really always in' quivering motion and that regions are raised

or lowered by subterranean forces which . from age to Hge -

transform land to sea and sea to land.

It is by just such erosion and deposition and by such ups
and downs that geologic formations are made: Areas that
are uplifted or that stand high are gradually worn down
by rain and rill and slide and stream, rocks are broken up
by frost and chemical action into fragments; and the waste
thus formed is carried down and deposited elegwhere at one

‘or another period of time as gravel and sand and mud in

great patches or in widely extended deposits to make forma-
tions. A formation is thus merely a deposit or a series of

deposits laid down, generally in water, at a certain time and

place; the stuff of which it is made is @s old as the earth.
‘The record of the time in which it was formed—its geologic
age—can be learned best from the remnants of once living
beings that made it their graveyard for every age bas its
characteristic fossils. :

The rocks that lie northwest of the fall line are in general
old and hard—rocks like granite—and evidently once lay far
beneath the surface; those that lie southeast of that line are in
general younger and softer, including sand and clay. The
gource .of the softer deposits was, of course, the harder, older
rocks, and the way in which these rocks are broken down
into fragments may be seen in any natural or artificial cut that
exposes them to weatherir g, such as a streamway or a road cut.

Where the granitic rocks are thus disintegrated the minerals of -

which they are composed-—quartz, mica, and feldspar, for ex-

ample—become loose sand and clay and, being then subject to -

movement by running water, are gradually carried downstream
toward the sea—in this region southeastward. The oldest of

these southeasterly deposits were laid down in "Cretaceous-

time, in what has been called the age of reptiles—not snakes,
for snakes were rare in that age—but lizard-like and other
forms, some of them huge and unwieldy, much larger than

alligators, others smaller, and still others having wings and -
Birds with teeth were among the strange

the power of flight. .
beings of that age. The plants of Cretaceous time, which are
recorded mainly by innumerable impressions of leaves, included
the precursors of our present trees and shrubs. :

Upon submerged Cretaceous deposits later formations were
laid down by the combined action of erosion and deposition—
forces still here in operation.

The largest tree in the region is the oak, many specles of
