very existence is now threatened by a widespread blight whose
ravages have not yet been stopped by the most devoted scien-
tific study and effort. The beech, more beautiful, perhaps, than
any other, adorns the woodland here and there, its smooth,
well-rounded trunk tempting defacement by the carved initials
of loiterers and lovers.

The native flora is well preserved in Rock Creek National

field_edited_text_processed:
The sponsors of this folder present to the motorist, fast scenic
bridge and ferry routes through sections replete in historic

and picturesque beauty.

Listed below are a few of the numerous places of interest that may be

visited enroute:

1—Havre de Grace, Maryland.—Originally called Susque-
hanna Lower Ferry. General Washington stopped here
many times: also site of the Susquehanna River Bridge,
adjudged the most beautiful large bridge built in the
. United States during 1940.
2—"Tudor Hall”. Birthplace of Edwin Booth and John Wilkes
Booth.
3—Birthplace of William Paca, signer of the Declaration of
Independence. R s 7
4—Baltimore, Maryland. Birthplace of the “Star Spangled
Banner” and seventh largest city in the United States,
third largest seoport in total waler borne commerce, wast
industrial center, manufacturing a wide variety of
products.
5—Annapolis, capital of Maryland. Untouched by restora-
tion Annapolis has been adjudged the finest example of
a colonial city in America. Particularly interesting to
visitors are: the United States Naval Academy (1845),
Chase House, Hammond Harwood House, St. John’s Col-
lege (1696), St. Anne’s Church (1699) are but a few of
them.,
6—Site of home and grave of Dr. Beanes whose arrest by
the British in 1814 was the cause of.Francis Scott Key
writing the “Star Spangled Banner”. :
7—"Mount Airy”. The home of Benedict Calvert whose
daughter married Washington’'s stepson. ;
8—"De La Brooke Manor”. Surveyed in 1650 for Robert
Brooke, Commander of Charles County.
9—The birthplace of Roger Brooke Taney., Chief Justice of
the United States, 1836-64.
10—"The Cliffs of Calvert”. One of the most picturesque spots
in Maryland.
11—"Dr. Mudd’'s House”. Home of Dr. Mudd, who set the
broken leg of John Wilkes Booth.
12—"La Grange”, the home of Dr. James Craik, Washington’s
lifelong friend and physician.
13—"Samuel Cox's Fdarm"”, where John Wilkes Booth and his
accomplice hid for several days.
14—"Laidlow’s Ferry”. Washington crossed here many times
on his way to Williamsburg. Practically the present site
of the Potomac River Bridge.
15—Wakefield, Virginia. Birthplace of George Washington.
Now a National Monument, the estate is under the super-
vision of the National Parks.
16—Saint Mary's City, Maryland. Siter of Maryland's pro-
vincial government for more than sixty years, after which
the capitol was moved to Annapolis in 1695. There now
stands on the original site a replica of the original
State House, made from brick brought over from England.
17—Richmond, Virginia. A typical city of the South and its
traditions. The capitol of Virginia and its largest city,
in and near this city are some of the country’s most noted
shrines.
18—Petersburg, Va. In and around this city ebbed and
flowed the tide of battle in the last days of the great
fratricidal strife, in 1865. Many fine monuments have been
erected on the scenes of many of the engagements and
this battlefield is one of the national shrines. f

19—Jamestown, Va. It was here in May 1607, that the Susan
Constant, Goodspeed and Discovery discharged their
cargoes of human freight and supplies, which resulted in
the first permanent English settlement in America.

20—Williamsburg, Va. This historic city, the colonial capitol
of Virginia, has been restored to its original appearance.
Among the many historic buildings that may be seen here
are the Governor’s Palace and extensive forry 1 gardens,
the capitol and the Raleigh Tavern. Here too stands the
Wren Building, oldest academic structure in English
America. The College of William and Mary was esiab-
liched in 1693,

21—Gloucester, Va. The very quaint Courthouse here was
erected in 1766. Here is buried Mildred Warner the grand-
mother of General Washington. Also near here is the
place where the Indian Princess, Pocahontas, rescued
Captain John Smith.

22—Yorktown, Va. The object of the siege which ended the
American Revolution with the surrender of Cornwallis to
Washington, October 19, 1781.

23—"Mariner’s Museum”. Situated in an extensive park and
game sanctuary. Is educational in purpose, world-wide
in scope, aiming to display maritime accomplishments
of all times and every nation.

24—Chestertown, Md. The seat of Washington College among
the oldest in the country, founded in 1782. Also the birth-
place of Charles Willson Peale, one of America’s most
famous artists.

25—Matapeake, Md. Site of the Eastern terminus of the
Annapolis Ferry. Here on “Kent Island” William Claiborne
established a trading post settlement and fort in 1631.

26—"Bloomingdale”, an interesting example of Georgian
architecture. This house has a two-story hexagonul por-
tico, the only one of its kind in Maryland. The oldest
part of Bloomingdale is the litile kitchen wing built in
1660.

27—"Wye Oak”, the largest white oak in America. This
tree over 400 years old was probably just a hearty
sapling when Columbus discovered America.

28—Near Easton, Md., are located many famous Colonial
homes such as: “Wye House” home of the Lloyd family
for over 200 years, here, lived Mary Taylor Lloyd, wife
of Francis Scott Key. “The Mannour of Ratcliffe”, Col-
onial home of the Holliday Family. Also “Old Friends
Meeting House”, visited by William Penn in 1682, the
cldest frame meeting house in America.

29—OId “Trinity Church”, built prior to 1670, located on
Church Creek a few miles below Cambridge. This place
of worship ranks as one of the most historic churches in
Maryland.

30—Birthplace of Samuel Chase, a signer of the Declaration
of Independence.

31—Ocean City, Md. The very name of Ocean City brings a
thrill to thousands of young and old, who have dis-
covered the countless advantages and delights offered
by this picturesque little city overlooking the broad
Atlantic,

MAPGOLEECTION







Wiy

NORTH - SOUTH ROUTES
by
BRIDGES AND FERRY

Two North-South routes illustrated by the
map in this folder may be followed, both
of modern construction and both famed
for their safety and of average possible
speed.

BA—The North-South route over the Sus-
quehanna River Bridge and Potomac
River Bridge following U. S. 1 from New
York to Philadelphia thence U. S. 13 which
leads into U. S. 40 over the Susquehanna
River Bridge, continue on U. S. 40 to
Baltimore, pick up and follow MD. 2 to
Glen Burnie, here turn right to U. S. 301
leading direct to the Potomac River Bridge.

B—From New Brunswick follow U. S. 130
(after crossing the Delaware River) pick
up U. S. 13 that leads into the Del-Mar-Va
Peninsula. Continue on U. S. 13 to Smyrna,
Delaware, turn right here into DEL. 300,
continue on DEL. and MD. 300 to Church
Hill, then U. S. 213 to Centerville, MD. 18
to Queenstown and MD. 404 to the Mata-
peake-Annapolis Ferry. From Annapolis
follow U. S. 50 to Priest Bridge, or MD. 2
to MD. 214, both routes lead to Upper
Marlboro, here take U. S. 301 direct to
the Potomac River Bridge. After crossing
the Potomac River Bridge one may fol-
low U. S. 301* to Port Royal thence U. S.

TO MARYLAND'S EASTERN SHORE
by
CHESAPEAKE BAY FERRY SYSTEM
ANNAPOLIS-MATAPEAKE FERRY

The Easteirn Shore is a Vacationland of
infinite variety and charm. On the Eastern
side, the Atlantic Ocean thrills the surf
bather with its broad, safe, sandy shore
and the ever luring Marlin off Ocean
City has now well established for this
enchanting resort a world-wide reputa-
tion for record catches of this piscatorial
king.

On the West side of this “Peninsula of
Plenty” the Chesapeake Bay. rightfully
called “A Fishing Hole 120 Miles Long”,
seldom refuses an offering to the disciples
of Izaak Walton. “Rock” or “Striped Bass",
“Croaker” or “Hardhead”, and “Trout”
or “"Weakfish” frequent this vast body of
water in abundance.

To supplement the bountiful pleasures
found on Maryland’s Eastern Shore, the
ferry trip between Annapolis and Mata-
peake is an especially enjoyable feature.
The crossing only takes 40 minutes, yet
this delightful break in driving gives all
a renewed vigor and too the mileage
saved between the Eastern and Western
Shores of Maryland is an added induce-
ment,

NORTH - SOUTH ROUTES
by
BRIDGES AND FERRY

Two North-South routes illustrated by the
map in this folder may be followed, both
of modern construction and both famed
for their safety and of average possible
speed.

BA—The North-South route over the Sus-
quehanna River Bridge and Potomac
River Bridge following U. S. 1 from New
York to Philadelphia thence U. S. 13 which
leads into U. S. 40 over the Susquehanna
River Bridge, continue on U. S. 40 to
Baltimore, pick up and follow MD. 2 to
Glen Burnie, here turn right to U. S. 301
leading direct to the Potomac River Bridge.

B—From New Brunswick follow U. S. 130
(after crossing the Delaware River) pick
up U. S. 13 that leads into the Del-Mar-Va
Peninsula. Continue on U. S. 13 to Smyrna,
Delaware, turn right here into DEL. 300,
continue on DEL. and MD. 300 to Church
Hill, then U. S. 213 to Centerville, MD. 18
to Queenstown and MD. 404 to the Mata-
peake-Annapolis Ferry. From Annapolis
follow U. S. 50 to Priest Bridge, or MD. 2
to MD. 214, both routes lead to Upper
Marlboro, here take U. S. 301 direct to
the Potomac River Bridge. After crossing
the Potomac River Bridge one may fol-
low U. S. 301* to Port Royal thence U. S.
17 to Yorkiown, Williamsburg, Jamestown
and the South or follow through on U. S.
301 to Bowling Green, Richmond, Peters-
burg and Southern points.

*Three miles south of Potomac River Bridge
U. S. 301 temporarily under construction
(July, 1941). Avoid this by using VA. 206
to VA. 3 then turn left to intersection of
UL Se301;

Courtesy extended to: U. S. Naval Academy, Virginia
Conservation Commission and Mr. Aubrey Bodine for use
of their photographs in this publication.

Of prime consideration in proposing

tives: integration of development with
natural physiographic characteristics;

A continuing process should be devel-
oped for implementation of the regional
General Development Plan.

The Regional Planning Council can
serve an important role in this process,
working with agents of local, state and
national governments, with private enter-
prise and the citizens of the region.

advisory committee can prove helpful to
the efforts of organizations to enhance
socio-economic development of the
region.

A preliminary solid waste disposal plan
was completed in February, 1972.
Further planning, now underway, should
seriously consider all resource recovery
possibilities.

A preliminary plan for handling storm
drainage problems is now being pre-
pared, but additional funds will be
needed to complete a detailed plan and
program.

The services and utilities described
above all have interjurisdictional impli-
cations. It is recommended that the
local governments in the region formally
cooperate in planning, financing, and
operating water, sewer, storm drainage,
and solid waste disposal services.

Estimated costs for water and sewer
facilities to 1990 is $930 million in
constant dollars. The 1980 annual cost
for debt retirement and operating these
facilities is estimated at $104 million.



Energy: ransmission

i r

Transportation: A high level of service
for the movement of people and goods
and the efficient transmission of

~ energy, consistent with enhancement

of the esthetic, physical, economic
and social environment.

By 1990 travel within the region will
double to more than 4.5 million person
trips per day.

People relying on public transportation
often are very limited as to where they
can go for medical, education, and
recreation services. About 450,000
people in the region live in households
without an automobile.

The ab'ility of the region to maintain
and expand its economic base will
depend to a large degree on the ability
of the transportation system to move
people to employment centers, which
are becoming increasingly decentral-
ized.





The transportation system must also
accommodate significant increases in
the amount of freight to be moved.
Freight movement facilities, including
highway and rail connections between
freight terminals and their markets are
particularly important to the Port of
Baltimore and Friendship, International
Airport.

An adequate supply and distribution of
energy must be provided in order to
sustain and enhance the quality of life.
Two of the most important energy
challenges facing the region are: to meet
the growing needs and to meet them in
a manner that will minimize harmful
effects to the environment.

Recommendations

An integrated public transportation
system costing $1.8 billion centered on
a regional rapid transit system is essen-
tial to meet the needs of people not
having access to an automobile, to
provide mobility in high density areas
which cannot be adequately served by
highways alone, and to encourage in-
vestment and development at key activity
centers. Two types of rapid transit are
proposed—trains operating in excess
of 75 miles an hour and express and
limited service buses.

Expansion and improvement of the
highway system at a cost of $2.4 billion
is recommended. Almost 85 percent of
the cost of the recommended con-
struction would be in the urban areas
of the region.

Actions should be taken to reduce
travel demand by instituting more
restrictive parking policies, modifying
shift patterns, and improving bus
service. ;

In order to keep the Port of Baltimore
competitive with other east coast ports,







improvements to both terminal facilities
and highway and rail connections are
essential,

Major improvements are required at
Friendship International Airport, and
general airports will be needed in Anne
Arundel, Carroll, Harford and Baltimore
Counties.

Taxation policies which penalize the
added cost of placing transmission lines
underground, in order to protect the
environment, should be eliminated.

Transportation facilities and energy
transmission corridors should be so
designed and constructed as to mini-
mize disturbance to the natural environ-
ment and residential communities.





Goal

Shelter and Community Development:
Adequate choice from a sufficient
supply of decent homes in suitable
environments within economic reach
of all citizens of the region.

While housing is generally adequate for

‘most people in the Baltimore Region,

it is not yet a reality for a substantial
number of households. The region’s
primary housing problem is a shortage
of adequate units, particularly for low
and moderate income families. For
minority group citizens, equal housing
opportunity is still more hope than
reality.

Some 90,000 of the region’s housing
units are now inadequate and must be
rehabilitated or replaced. The largest
portion of this deficit exists in Baltimore
City. However, some of the more rural
counties contain a substantial percent-
age of inadequate housing.

The cost of housing, particularly for
home buyers, has skyrocketed in recent
years. This has been a major factor in
the growing trend toward the develop-
ment of multi-family rental housing.



There is an increasing awareness that
not only the house, but also its environ-
ment, with attendant public services,
must be improved before the nationally
adopted goal of a “‘decent home in a
suitable living environment’ can be
achieved for all residents of the Balti-
more area.

Patterns of racial and economic dis-
crimination remain in the Baltimore
Region, despite some progress during
the past decade. :

Recommendations

Adequate and suitably located housing
for all of the region’s residents can be
achieved before 1990 provided the
following conditions are met and main-
tained: high volume production and re-
habilitation; realistic income gains and -
housing cost stability; intensified con-
cern about the environment and the
ability of local governments to cope
with urban development pressures;
realization of equal opportunity in both
housing and employment.

Of major importance is closing still
evident gaps in the supply and location
of low- and moderate-income housing
throughout the region. A plan for the
balanced distribution of such housing
will be prepared soon as a supplement
to this General Development Plan.

Meeting region-wide housing needs by
1990 will require 20,000 new and re-
habilitated dwelling units yearly. Their
timing and location should be guided by
a balanced distribution plan. Such a
plan should be prepared soon by the
Area Housing Council for RPC consid-
eration.

Wider use of rehabilitation, replacement
and maintenance programs will be re-
quired to maintain and improve the



general quality of the housing stock,
particularly in areas with older housing.
New housing construction meets for the
most part, additional needs for housing
in new and undeveloped locations.
Continued used of existing housing in
adequate condition meets the bulk of a
community's overall housing needs.
Rehabilitation of as many as 4,000 units
a year will be required to meet total
housing needs. :

Means should be found to hold down
factors contributing to high housing
costs, which go beyond actual construc-
tion. Such factors as high land prices,
land development charges, building
code compliance costs, and closing out-
lays must be reduced.

The quality of residential neighborhood
environments should be maintained and
improved. Rehabilitation and mainte-
nance efforts are necessary in older
neighborhoods throughout the region.
Strong planning and development con-
trols will be required in new suburban
communities. The expanded use of inno-
vative and efficient planned unit devel-
opment should be encouraged.

Development of adequate housing for
all in suitable environmental surround-
ings must be accompanied by equitable
and broad access to employment and
income opportunities throughout the
region. Stronger efforts than those of the
past will be required to achieve this.





Goal

Health: Provide for the best level of
physical and mental health for every
person at all stages of life, and for an
environment which contributes posi-
tively to healthy individual and family
living.

Issues

While many of the resources necessary
to meet the above goal are currently
available, a system is lacking to link the
resources in order to bridge gaps in
service and avoid duplication.

Health indicators for the region show a
less favorable status of health for its
residents than for the State of Maryland
as a whole.

Although health care is now seen as a
right rather than a privilege, many people
lack the means to purchase it. Many of
those who can purchase it are frustrated
in their attempts to find timely and
appropriate service.

The health care system is essentially
sickness-oriented, with few resources
committed to preventing illness or
maintaining positive health.

From 1960 to 1970 the demand for
emergency services in the region has
resulted in a 133 percent increase in
visits to hospital emergency rooms. A
substantial portion of visits were for
non-emergency purposes, because
health care is not readily available for
many people outside the hospital.

Certain weaknesses have been identified
in emergency service for those who
require immediate medical care because
of life-threatening or disabling condi-
tions. They are due in part to the limited
training given to ambulance technicians
and the current practice of transporting
the patient to the nearest hospital
instead of the hospital best able to
handle his injury or illness.

While there are as many psychiatric
hospital beds within the region as there
are medical/surgical beds, mental health
services are grossly underfunded.

A steadily increasing elderly population
within the region demands attention to
the many implications of long-term care.

Recommendations

Maintain and improve a strong health
planning process, with widespread and
active participation by the community.

Formulate and apply health criteria for
engineering and conserving the natural
and man-made environments.

Link resources into service coalitions,
and eliminate duplication and gaps.

Assure every person in the region ready
access to effective and appropriate
health care resources, including primary
(first contact) care.

Improve the effectiveness of the region’s
hospitals in meeting routine care needs.





Develop an emergency medical system
with the quality and capacity to provide
appropriate medical care.

Provide a full range of mental health
services.

Develop alternatives for institutional long
term care which will enable individuals
(especially the elderly, chronically ill,
and disabled) to maintain themselves
independently and with dignity in a home
or community setting.

Provide adequate and effective institu-
tional services for those persons requir-
ing specialized medical care or rehabili-
tation. :

Find and apply mechanisms to assure
the financial viability of the region’s
health system.





Goal

Safety and Justice: Adequate and
equal justice and protection of life and
property against crime, fire, traffic
hazards, and other threats to personal
and public safety.

Issues

The Criminal Justice Planning Board of
this region identifies as the number one
priority in crime prevention the early
recognition of delinquent tendencies,
which start when behavior problems
appear during the first years of a child’s

school life.

Police agencies are still struggling with
problems related to administration, field
services, communications, and training.

On both the circuit and district court
levels, operational dﬁfficulties, such as
overloaded dockets and insufficient per-
sonnel, are causing congestion, slow
administration of justice, and a narrow
range of rehabilitative expectance.

One of the most serious deterrents to
adult rehabilitation is the inability of
local institutions to properly classify,
screen, and diagnose incoming prison-
ers, many of whom are in need of
special programs.





Another major obstacle to adult rehabili-
tation is the acute overcrowding of jails

and prisons, and their inability to sepa-

rate juvenile from older offenders. }

A key problem in the rehabilitation of the
juvenile delinquent is the limited number }
of available alternatives to confining him
in an institution.

Adult rehabilitation is impeded by a
serious lack of community correctional
alternatives such as halfway houses,
adequate probation services, and work
release or educational furlough
programs.

Local institutions have a need for addi-
tional manpower allocations and contin-
uing training programs if rehabilitation
is to be effective.

k]

Recommendations

A vast increase in funds is needed for
community-based delinquency preven-
tion programs.

Immediate police needs are additional
personnel and specialized equipment,
an improved modern communications
network, expansion of management and
technical training programs, and intensi-
fied community relations programs.

Measures recommended for increasing
the efficiency of the adjudication process
include: management studies of prose-
cutors’ offices; utilization of automatic
data processing; assignment of para-
professionals for staff support work;
easing of staff limitations in the State’s
Attorney's office to improve pre-trial
screening and case preparation; up-
grading and expanding psychiatric
evaluation services; extension of the
State’s Attorney’s services to juvenile
and district courts.

PopuUation
and Economy
of theRegion





Goal

Economic Well-Being: Adequate and
rewarding employment for everyone
able to work; opportunity for securing
goods and services necessary for
satisfactory life in today’s society; eco-
nomical and effective delivery of public
assistance to those who cannot other-
wise provide; sound governmental
fiscal bases and balanced economic
development in the region.

In planning for job opportunities and the
provision of goods and services, it is
essential to estimate as accurately as
possible the future growth, composition,
and distribution of the region’'s popula-
tion.

Birth rate, death rate, and migration data

~ indicate that the total population of the

region will be 2,800,000 by 1990 com-
pared with 2,070,000 in 1970.

In 1990, one quarter of the region’s pop-
ulation will be black, the same propor-
tion as exists today. Eighty percent of
the region’s 1990 black population will
live in Baltimore City. That will represent
an accelerated movement into suburban
counties during the seventies and

|__eighties, doubling the number of black |

residents there.

Between 1970 and 1990 the elderly
population will grow from a little over 8
percent to almost 10 percent.

Although Baltimore City population will
remain close to its present 900,000, it is
expected that the city’s percentage of
the region’s total population will decline
from 45 to 30 percent. On the other
hand, significant growth is anticipated in
the suburban counties.

By 1990, 50,000 people living in the
region will work in Metropolitan Wash-
ington.



Over the period 1970-1990, employment
will increase by about 300,000 jobs to a
level near 1,200,000, and the economy
will continue its shift from goods-
producing to service-producing activi-
ties. Service-job opportunities will tend
to develop near rapidly expanding su-
burban communities, but MetroCenter,
Baltimore’s central business district, will
continue as the financial-administrative-
business service hub of the region.

During the coming decade, there will be
small employment gains in such indus-
tries as construction, transportation,
communications, and public utilities, but
the greatest gains will be in the areas of
finance, trade, government, and other
types of services. In all industry groups,
there should be a notable increase in the
demand for professionals, and a mod-
erate increase in the managerial cate-
gories.

While median family income in the
_region was over $10,000 in 1970, almost
170,000 residents are dependent on
some form of public assistance. Poverty
is most concentrated in the urban core,
but is also found in the rural outer
reaches of the region beyond suburban
development. Poverty is not confined to
the jobless. Fully 70 percent of male
heads of households with incomes be- |

low the officially defined poverty level

have some form of employment.

Many citizens are unable to par@icipate
in the economy because of various
forms of discrimination on the basis of
race, age, or sex, as well as geographic
separation from job opportunities in the
suburban counties.

An increasing number of jobs will call for
skills which require specialized educa-
tion and training. Because of the influx
of young persons into the labor force
during-the past few years, a crisis in
matching skills and work experience to
jobs is occurring.



Interdependence of the several jurisdic-
tions within the regional economy is
evident in_a number of ways, most
notably in the patterns of commuting be-
tween work places and residences. The
city and counties share unequally in
fiscal burdens and public benefits.

Recommendations

Jobs should not only offer employment,
but also opportunities for advancement
at wages sufficient to permit a decent
standard of living.

Discriminatory employment practices
should be identified and abolished.

Efforts should be made to improve public
transportation and to increase the availa-
bility of housing in outlying areas in
order to expand suburban job opportuni-
ties for inner-city residents. Major em-
ployers and the jurisdictions in which
they locate have a responsibility for mak-
ing housing available to workers at
appropriate prices and rents.

Local economic development activities
should be linked to manpower training
and development programs in order that
occupational requirements of industry
can be balanced with the skills of the
labor force. ¢

quired to reduce the inequities in tax
base structure which result from current
commuting patterns.

Naitural
Enviionment

Goal

Natural Environment: Preservation and
enhancement of sunlight, air, water
and land resources, the wildlife and
vegatation of the region in order to
support and enrich human life.

The wholesale clearance of woodlands
and forests has resulted in flooding
and erosion, with silt entering and
polluting watercourses.

The Chesapeake Bay has been addi-
tionally menaced by storm runoff from

city streets, poorly treated municipal

wastewater, industrial pqllution, ship
bilge and oil spills.

Access to the bay's beaches has been
steadiiy declining because of pollution,
erosion by wave action, and residential
development along the shoreline.

A rapid decrease in the number and
species of wildlife has resulted from
the depletion of woodlands and wet-
lands, their natural habitat.

The region shares in widespread air

“pollution which has become a national



problem:. L

Key agricultural lands, important to the
economy and beauty of the region, are
very inviting to prospective developers.



"~ flood waters should be instituted.



Recommendations

It is vital that the region’s water, land,
and air resources be protected by
reducing pollution.

Enforcement of laws regarding sedimen-
tation control, dumping untreated wastes
from ships, oil spills, and other land and
water pollution control measures should

be strongly supported.

Development patterns which respect the
natural environment should be en-
couraged by the careful placement of
public utilities such as water, sewers
and highways in areas most appro-
priate for development.

Septic tank use should be carefully
controlled.

Measures should be taken to assure
public access to streams, rivers, and
the Chesapeake.Bay, including acquisi-
tion of waterfront parks.

Preservation of wetlands should be
encouraged.

Development on slopes in excess of
20 percent should be limited, and public
control of such slopes increased.

Areas within 100-year flood plains
should be kept free from development,
and other new approaches for managing

Vion-Made
EnvironmMent



Goal

Man-made environment: To improve
the quality of development, create
image and character, protect and en-
hance the cultural, historic, visual, and
ecological assets of the region’s man-
made environment.

One of the essentials of an enriching and
satisfying environment is a strengthening
of the region’s overall image. The
Baltimore Region has capitalized to only
a limited degree on its unique features—
the Chesapeake Bay, the Harbor, the

Too often urban areas are developed
on a piecemeal basis rather than
according to standards and criteria that
would produce a harmonious, coherent
environment.

Recommendations

A visual image for the region should be
created by means of design and de-
velopment policies which enhance the
quality of the region’s man-made en-
vironment.

The region should be classified into
development districts with a recognition
of their wide diversity and differing
design requirements.

Roads link individual districts into a
series of continuous experiences and
therefore should be designed to enhance
the environments through which they
pass. Standards for roadways should be
established which will guide alignments,
landscaping, and roadside development.

_Conservation policies should be applied

to structures and districts with archi-
tectural, historic, cultural or social
significance, as well as to unique
natural features and vistas.

Landscaping should not be construed
as just the application of plant materials,

[Recreationona
Open Sooce



Goal

Recreation and Open Space: Oppor-
tunities sufficient to accommodate the
full range of human needs for recrea-
tion, and open spaces sufficient to
meet the region’s conservation needs.

Recreation and leisure time experiences
are important in meeting the need for
relief from the routine and repetitive
activities of daily life.

Growth in many forms of recreation has
taken place in recent years, and there

Recommendations

A system of regional activity areas and
recreation corridors, including a trail
system, should be created.

Neighborhood and community recrea-
tion centers and parks should be estab-
lished close to where people live.

Unique historic and cultural areas
should be protected to give people a
sense of continuity with past events and
ways of life in the region. ‘

An additional 176,000 acres in the
regional open space system and 25,000
acres in the local open space system
need protection by 1990.

The recommended open space plan will
cost $521 million for acquisition and
development and up to @ maximum of
$37 million per year for operation and
maintenance. z

A financial plan and program should be
undertaken to systematically éstablish
priorities and funding schedules. Maxi-
mum state and federal aid should be
sought.

Sewerage, Water,

aond Sold Waistes

Goal

Utilities: A supply of safe water for all
uses, and satisfactory disposal
methods for liquid and solid wastes,
all in the context of sound environ-
mental health planning.

The ability of sewage treatment plants
to handle adequately the wastewater
which reaches them, the capacity of
pipelines to carry the wastes, and the
ability of receiving waters to assimilate
the effluent are important to health and

Dr: N
P me“].



is-every-indication-thatincrease-in



Tree planting throughout the region
should be encouraged and tree clear-
ance by developers allowed only by
permit.

Air pollution sources should be identi-
fied, and state and county health
department regulations should be
supported and enforced.

Naise pollution should be kept to a level
which is not injurious to individual
health.-

Prime agricultural lands should be
preserved for agricultural purposes and
strong measures should be taken to
protect them from development.



valleys, the Baltimore skyline—all of
which create a distinctive character.

The strength of the region as a dis~
tinctive, satisfying environment is parti-
ally dependent on the accumulated
effect of the areas or districts which

compose it. This requires highlighting

the outstanding féatures and character-
istics of each district.

The traveler receives an impression of
districts from roadways, which tend to
identify and define their major features

and character. Poorly located junk yards, .

service stations, oversize or garish signs
exemplify features 'which detract from
the character of urban areas.



but also as the fabric of the environ-
ment into which spaces and structures
are woven. Landscape plans should be
prepared for towns and communities
the region.

The Regional Planning Council should
establish guidelines and offer assistance
to local jurisdictions in the formulation
of design policies.

recreation demands will continue into
the future.

The acquisition or protection of open
space is urgent, as urban growth in the
Baltimore Region between now and

-1990 is likely to consume about 100,000

acres.

Open spaces are important in order to
preserve natural features and determine
the lotation of urban development in
the region. 4





Failing septic tanks create health
hazards and nuisances. In the urbanizing
sectors of the region, overflowing septic
tanks pollute streams and estuarine
rivers that drain the coastal plain.

The demand for treated water is steadily
increasing. Present use is 250 million
gallons per day or 68 percent of the
supply. By 1980, it is estimated that it
will rise to 303 million gallons per day
or 83 percent of the supply. If use con-
tinues to increase at this rate, the present
developed supply of water will be in-
adequate after the year 2000.

Two important issues in the increasingly
serious problem of solid wastes disposal
are the location of disposal sites and a





reluctance to experiment with tech-
nological advances which would pro-
vide more efficient collection and
disposal systems.

The widespread destruction by the
storm “Agnes’’ in June, 1972, highlights
the need for storm drainage and flood
prevention measures to be taken by
agencies of the region.

Recommendations

Development should be prohibited in
areas where public sewerage facilities
are not available and where soil or
topographic conditions are unsuitable
for individual septic tanks.

The Back River and Patapsco River
wastewater treatment plants serve about

70 percent of the region’s population.

The larger of the two, the Back River

plant, is now undergoing extension and
modernization; a development and con-
struction program has been designed for |
the Patapsco River plant. Smaller waste-
water treatment plants will also be re- |
quired to accommodate a growing
population.

To correct septic tank problems, owners
should be required to take one of the |
following actions: construction of new -
septic tank drainage fields; installation |
of limited service community disposal |
systems; tapping into existing public |
facilities. The method selected would |
depend on individual circumstances, the
location of the property, and water |
quality requirements.

\

\

If water use continues to rise at its

present rate, additional sources will be
needed after the year 2000. These might

be an increase in the already existing |
Susquehanna River supply, development ‘
of a new source on the Potomac River,
recycling of used water, distillation, and
other measures which are being cur-
rently investigated. -~

HousNg :

A preliminary solid waste disposal plan
was completed in February, 1972.
Further planning, now underway, should
seriously consider all resource recovery
possibilities.

A preliminary plan for handling storm
drainage problems is now being pre-
pared, but additional funds will be
needed to complete a detailed plan and
program.

The services and utilities described
above all have interjurisdictional impli-
cations. It is recommended that the
local governments in the region formally
cooperate in planning, financing, and
operating water, sewer, storm drainage,
and solid waste disposal services.

Estimated costs for water and sewer
facilities to 1990 is $930 million in
constant dollars. The 1980 annual cost
for debt retirement and operating these
facilities is estimated at $104 million.



Energy: ransmission

i r

Transportation: A high level of service
for the movement of people and goods
and the efficient transmission of

~ energy, consistent with enhancement

of the esthetic, physical, economic
and social environment.

By 1990 travel within the region will
double to more than 4.5 million person
trips per day.

People relying on public transportation
often are very limited as to where they
can go for medical, education, and
recreation services. About 450,000
people in the region live in households
without an automobile.

The ab'ility of the region to maintain
and expand its economic base will
depend to a large degree on the ability
of the transportation system to move
people to employment centers, which
are becoming increasingly decentral-
ized.





The transportation system must also
accommodate significant increases in
the amount of freight to be moved.
Freight movement facilities, including
highway and rail connections between
freight terminals and their markets are
particularly important to the Port of
Baltimore and Friendship, International
Airport.

An adequate supply and distribution of
energy must be provided in order to
sustain and enhance the quality of life.
Two of the most important energy
challenges facing the region are: to meet
the growing needs and to meet them in
a manner that will minimize harmful
effects to the environment.

Recommendations

An integrated public transportation
system costing $1.8 billion centered on
a regional rapid transit system is essen-
tial to meet the needs of people not
having access to an automobile, to
provide mobility in high density areas
which cannot be adequately served by
highways alone, and to encourage in-
vestment and development at key activity
centers. Two types of rapid transit are
proposed—trains operating in excess
of 75 miles an hour and express and
limited service buses.

Expansion and improvement of the
highway system at a cost of $2.4 billion
is recommended. Almost 85 percent of
the cost of the recommended con-
struction would be in the urban areas
of the region.

Actions should be taken to reduce
travel demand by instituting more
restrictive parking policies, modifying
shift patterns, and improving bus
service. ;

In order to keep the Port of Baltimore
competitive with other east coast ports,







improvements to both terminal facilities
and highway and rail connections are
essential,

Major improvements are required at
Friendship International Airport, and
general airports will be needed in Anne
Arundel, Carroll, Harford and Baltimore
Counties.

Taxation policies which penalize the
added cost of placing transmission lines
underground, in order to protect the
environment, should be eliminated.

Transportation facilities and energy
transmission corridors should be so
designed and constructed as to mini-
mize disturbance to the natural environ-
ment and residential communities.





Goal

Shelter and Community Development:
Adequate choice from a sufficient
supply of decent homes in suitable
environments within economic reach
of all citizens of the region.

While housing is generally adequate for

‘most people in the Baltimore Region,

it is not yet a reality for a substantial
number of households. The region’s
primary housing problem is a shortage
of adequate units, particularly for low
and moderate income families. For
minority group citizens, equal housing
opportunity is still more hope than
reality.

Some 90,000 of the region’s housing
units are now inadequate and must be
rehabilitated or replaced. The largest
portion of this deficit exists in Baltimore
City. However, some of the more rural
counties contain a substantial percent-
age of inadequate housing.

The cost of housing, particularly for
home buyers, has skyrocketed in recent
years. This has been a major factor in
the growing trend toward the develop-
ment of multi-family rental housing.



There is an increasing awareness that
not only the house, but also its environ-
ment, with attendant public services,
must be improved before the nationally
adopted goal of a “‘decent home in a
suitable living environment’ can be
achieved for all residents of the Balti-
more area.

Patterns of racial and economic dis-
crimination remain in the Baltimore
Region, despite some progress during
the past decade. :

Recommendations

Adequate and suitably located housing
for all of the region’s residents can be
achieved before 1990 provided the
following conditions are met and main-
tained: high volume production and re-
habilitation; realistic income gains and -
housing cost stability; intensified con-
cern about the environment and the
ability of local governments to cope
with urban development pressures;
realization of equal opportunity in both
housing and employment.

Of major importance is closing still
evident gaps in the supply and location
of low- and moderate-income housing
throughout the region. A plan for the
balanced distribution of such housing
will be prepared soon as a supplement
to this General Development Plan.

Meeting region-wide housing needs by
1990 will require 20,000 new and re-
habilitated dwelling units yearly. Their
timing and location should be guided by
a balanced distribution plan. Such a
plan should be prepared soon by the
Area Housing Council for RPC consid-
eration.

Wider use of rehabilitation, replacement
and maintenance programs will be re-
quired to maintain and improve the



general quality of the housing stock,
particularly in areas with older housing.
New housing construction meets for the
most part, additional needs for housing
in new and undeveloped locations.
Continued used of existing housing in
adequate condition meets the bulk of a
community's overall housing needs.
Rehabilitation of as many as 4,000 units
a year will be required to meet total
housing needs. :

Means should be found to hold down
factors contributing to high housing
costs, which go beyond actual construc-
tion. Such factors as high land prices,
land development charges, building
code compliance costs, and closing out-
lays must be reduced.

The quality of residential neighborhood
environments should be maintained and
improved. Rehabilitation and mainte-
nance efforts are necessary in older
neighborhoods throughout the region.
Strong planning and development con-
trols will be required in new suburban
communities. The expanded use of inno-
vative and efficient planned unit devel-
opment should be encouraged.

Development of adequate housing for
all in suitable environmental surround-
ings must be accompanied by equitable
and broad access to employment and
income opportunities throughout the
region. Stronger efforts than those of the
past will be required to achieve this.





Goal

Health: Provide for the best level of
physical and mental health for every
person at all stages of life, and for an
environment which contributes posi-
tively to healthy individual and family
living.

Issues

While many of the resources necessary
to meet the above goal are currently
available, a system is lacking to link the
resources in order to bridge gaps in
service and avoid duplication.

Health indicators for the region show a
less favorable status of health for its
residents than for the State of Maryland
as a whole.

Although health care is now seen as a
right rather than a privilege, many people
lack the means to purchase it. Many of
those who can purchase it are frustrated
in their attempts to find timely and
appropriate service.

The health care system is essentially
sickness-oriented, with few resources
committed to preventing illness or
maintaining positive health.

From 1960 to 1970 the demand for
emergency services in the region has
resulted in a 133 percent increase in
visits to hospital emergency rooms. A
substantial portion of visits were for
non-emergency purposes, because
health care is not readily available for
many people outside the hospital.

Certain weaknesses have been identified
in emergency service for those who
require immediate medical care because
of life-threatening or disabling condi-
tions. They are due in part to the limited
training given to ambulance technicians
and the current practice of transporting
the patient to the nearest hospital
instead of the hospital best able to
handle his injury or illness.

While there are as many psychiatric
hospital beds within the region as there
are medical/surgical beds, mental health
services are grossly underfunded.

A steadily increasing elderly population
within the region demands attention to
the many implications of long-term care.

Recommendations

Maintain and improve a strong health
planning process, with widespread and
active participation by the community.

Formulate and apply health criteria for
engineering and conserving the natural
and man-made environments.

Link resources into service coalitions,
and eliminate duplication and gaps.

Assure every person in the region ready
access to effective and appropriate
health care resources, including primary
(first contact) care.

Improve the effectiveness of the region’s
hospitals in meeting routine care needs.





Develop an emergency medical system
with the quality and capacity to provide
appropriate medical care.

Provide a full range of mental health
services.

Develop alternatives for institutional long
term care which will enable individuals
(especially the elderly, chronically ill,
and disabled) to maintain themselves
independently and with dignity in a home
or community setting.

Provide adequate and effective institu-
tional services for those persons requir-
ing specialized medical care or rehabili-
tation. :

Find and apply mechanisms to assure
the financial viability of the region’s
health system.





Goal

Safety and Justice: Adequate and
equal justice and protection of life and
property against crime, fire, traffic
hazards, and other threats to personal
and public safety.

Issues

The Criminal Justice Planning Board of
this region identifies as the number one
priority in crime prevention the early
recognition of delinquent tendencies,
which start when behavior problems
appear during the first years of a child’s

school life.

Police agencies are still struggling with
problems related to administration, field
services, communications, and training.

On both the circuit and district court
levels, operational dﬁfficulties, such as
overloaded dockets and insufficient per-
sonnel, are causing congestion, slow
administration of justice, and a narrow
range of rehabilitative expectance.

One of the most serious deterrents to
adult rehabilitation is the inability of
local institutions to properly classify,
screen, and diagnose incoming prison-
ers, many of whom are in need of
special programs.





Another major obstacle to adult rehabili-
tation is the acute overcrowding of jails

and prisons, and their inability to sepa-

rate juvenile from older offenders. }

A key problem in the rehabilitation of the
juvenile delinquent is the limited number }
of available alternatives to confining him
in an institution.

Adult rehabilitation is impeded by a
serious lack of community correctional
alternatives such as halfway houses,
adequate probation services, and work
release or educational furlough
programs.

Local institutions have a need for addi-
tional manpower allocations and contin-
uing training programs if rehabilitation
is to be effective.

k]

Recommendations

A vast increase in funds is needed for
community-based delinquency preven-
tion programs.

Immediate police needs are additional
personnel and specialized equipment,
an improved modern communications
network, expansion of management and
technical training programs, and intensi-
fied community relations programs.

Measures recommended for increasing
the efficiency of the adjudication process
include: management studies of prose-
cutors’ offices; utilization of automatic
data processing; assignment of para-
professionals for staff support work;
easing of staff limitations in the State’s
Attorney's office to improve pre-trial
screening and case preparation; up-
grading and expanding psychiatric
evaluation services; extension of the
State’s Attorney’s services to juvenile
and district courts.

PopuUation
and Economy
of theRegion





Goal

Economic Well-Being: Adequate and
rewarding employment for everyone
able to work; opportunity for securing
goods and services necessary for
satisfactory life in today’s society; eco-
nomical and effective delivery of public
assistance to those who cannot other-
wise provide; sound governmental
fiscal bases and balanced economic
development in the region.

In planning for job opportunities and the
provision of goods and services, it is
essential to estimate as accurately as
possible the future growth, composition,
and distribution of the region’'s popula-
tion.

Birth rate, death rate, and migration data

~ indicate that the total population of the

region will be 2,800,000 by 1990 com-
pared with 2,070,000 in 1970.

In 1990, one quarter of the region’s pop-
ulation will be black, the same propor-
tion as exists today. Eighty percent of
the region’s 1990 black population will
live in Baltimore City. That will represent
an accelerated movement into suburban
counties during the seventies and

|__eighties, doubling the number of black |

residents there.

Between 1970 and 1990 the elderly
population will grow from a little over 8
percent to almost 10 percent.

Although Baltimore City population will
remain close to its present 900,000, it is
expected that the city’s percentage of
the region’s total population will decline
from 45 to 30 percent. On the other
hand, significant growth is anticipated in
the suburban counties.

By 1990, 50,000 people living in the
region will work in Metropolitan Wash-
ington.



Over the period 1970-1990, employment
will increase by about 300,000 jobs to a
level near 1,200,000, and the economy
will continue its shift from goods-
producing to service-producing activi-
ties. Service-job opportunities will tend
to develop near rapidly expanding su-
burban communities, but MetroCenter,
Baltimore’s central business district, will
continue as the financial-administrative-
business service hub of the region.

During the coming decade, there will be
small employment gains in such indus-
tries as construction, transportation,
communications, and public utilities, but
the greatest gains will be in the areas of
finance, trade, government, and other
types of services. In all industry groups,
there should be a notable increase in the
demand for professionals, and a mod-
erate increase in the managerial cate-
gories.

While median family income in the
_region was over $10,000 in 1970, almost
170,000 residents are dependent on
some form of public assistance. Poverty
is most concentrated in the urban core,
but is also found in the rural outer
reaches of the region beyond suburban
development. Poverty is not confined to
the jobless. Fully 70 percent of male
heads of households with incomes be- |

low the officially defined poverty level

have some form of employment.

Many citizens are unable to par@icipate
in the economy because of various
forms of discrimination on the basis of
race, age, or sex, as well as geographic
separation from job opportunities in the
suburban counties.

An increasing number of jobs will call for
skills which require specialized educa-
tion and training. Because of the influx
of young persons into the labor force
during-the past few years, a crisis in
matching skills and work experience to
jobs is occurring.



Interdependence of the several jurisdic-
tions within the regional economy is
evident in_a number of ways, most
notably in the patterns of commuting be-
tween work places and residences. The
city and counties share unequally in
fiscal burdens and public benefits.

Recommendations

Jobs should not only offer employment,
but also opportunities for advancement
at wages sufficient to permit a decent
standard of living.

Discriminatory employment practices
should be identified and abolished.

Efforts should be made to improve public
transportation and to increase the availa-
bility of housing in outlying areas in
order to expand suburban job opportuni-
ties for inner-city residents. Major em-
ployers and the jurisdictions in which
they locate have a responsibility for mak-
ing housing available to workers at
appropriate prices and rents.

Local economic development activities
should be linked to manpower training
and development programs in order that
occupational requirements of industry
can be balanced with the skills of the
labor force. ¢

quired to reduce the inequities in tax
base structure which result from current
commuting patterns.

Naitural
Enviionment

Goal

Natural Environment: Preservation and
enhancement of sunlight, air, water
and land resources, the wildlife and
vegatation of the region in order to
support and enrich human life.

The wholesale clearance of woodlands
and forests has resulted in flooding
and erosion, with silt entering and
polluting watercourses.

The Chesapeake Bay has been addi-
tionally menaced by storm runoff from

city streets, poorly treated municipal

wastewater, industrial pqllution, ship
bilge and oil spills.

Access to the bay's beaches has been
steadiiy declining because of pollution,
erosion by wave action, and residential
development along the shoreline.

A rapid decrease in the number and
species of wildlife has resulted from
the depletion of woodlands and wet-
lands, their natural habitat.

The region shares in widespread air

“pollution which has become a national



problem:. L

Key agricultural lands, important to the
economy and beauty of the region, are
very inviting to prospective developers.



"~ flood waters should be instituted.



Recommendations

It is vital that the region’s water, land,
and air resources be protected by
reducing pollution.

Enforcement of laws regarding sedimen-
tation control, dumping untreated wastes
from ships, oil spills, and other land and
water pollution control measures should

be strongly supported.

Development patterns which respect the
natural environment should be en-
couraged by the careful placement of
public utilities such as water, sewers
and highways in areas most appro-
priate for development.

Septic tank use should be carefully
controlled.

Measures should be taken to assure
public access to streams, rivers, and
the Chesapeake.Bay, including acquisi-
tion of waterfront parks.

Preservation of wetlands should be
encouraged.

Development on slopes in excess of
20 percent should be limited, and public
control of such slopes increased.

Areas within 100-year flood plains
should be kept free from development,
and other new approaches for managing

Vion-Made
EnvironmMent



Goal

Man-made environment: To improve
the quality of development, create
image and character, protect and en-
hance the cultural, historic, visual, and
ecological assets of the region’s man-
made environment.

One of the essentials of an enriching and
satisfying environment is a strengthening
of the region’s overall image. The
Baltimore Region has capitalized to only
a limited degree on its unique features—
the Chesapeake Bay, the Harbor, the

Too often urban areas are developed
on a piecemeal basis rather than
according to standards and criteria that
would produce a harmonious, coherent
environment.

Recommendations

A visual image for the region should be
created by means of design and de-
velopment policies which enhance the
quality of the region’s man-made en-
vironment.

The region should be classified into
development districts with a recognition
of their wide diversity and differing
design requirements.

Roads link individual districts into a
series of continuous experiences and
therefore should be designed to enhance
the environments through which they
pass. Standards for roadways should be
established which will guide alignments,
landscaping, and roadside development.

_Conservation policies should be applied

to structures and districts with archi-
tectural, historic, cultural or social
significance, as well as to unique
natural features and vistas.

Landscaping should not be construed
as just the application of plant materials,

[Recreationona
Open Sooce



Goal

Recreation and Open Space: Oppor-
tunities sufficient to accommodate the
full range of human needs for recrea-
tion, and open spaces sufficient to
meet the region’s conservation needs.

Recreation and leisure time experiences
are important in meeting the need for
relief from the routine and repetitive
activities of daily life.

Growth in many forms of recreation has
taken place in recent years, and there

Recommendations

A system of regional activity areas and
recreation corridors, including a trail
system, should be created.

Neighborhood and community recrea-
tion centers and parks should be estab-
lished close to where people live.

Unique historic and cultural areas
should be protected to give people a
sense of continuity with past events and
ways of life in the region. ‘

An additional 176,000 acres in the
regional open space system and 25,000
acres in the local open space system
need protection by 1990.

The recommended open space plan will
cost $521 million for acquisition and
development and up to @ maximum of
$37 million per year for operation and
maintenance. z

A financial plan and program should be
undertaken to systematically éstablish
priorities and funding schedules. Maxi-
mum state and federal aid should be
sought.

Sewerage, Water,

aond Sold Waistes

Goal

Utilities: A supply of safe water for all
uses, and satisfactory disposal
methods for liquid and solid wastes,
all in the context of sound environ-
mental health planning.

The ability of sewage treatment plants
to handle adequately the wastewater
which reaches them, the capacity of
pipelines to carry the wastes, and the
ability of receiving waters to assimilate
the effluent are important to health and

Dr: N
P me“].



is-every-indication-thatincrease-in



Tree planting throughout the region
should be encouraged and tree clear-
ance by developers allowed only by
permit.

Air pollution sources should be identi-
fied, and state and county health
department regulations should be
supported and enforced.

Naise pollution should be kept to a level
which is not injurious to individual
health.-

Prime agricultural lands should be
preserved for agricultural purposes and
strong measures should be taken to
protect them from development.



valleys, the Baltimore skyline—all of
which create a distinctive character.

The strength of the region as a dis~
tinctive, satisfying environment is parti-
ally dependent on the accumulated
effect of the areas or districts which

compose it. This requires highlighting

the outstanding féatures and character-
istics of each district.

The traveler receives an impression of
districts from roadways, which tend to
identify and define their major features

and character. Poorly located junk yards, .

service stations, oversize or garish signs
exemplify features 'which detract from
the character of urban areas.



but also as the fabric of the environ-
ment into which spaces and structures
are woven. Landscape plans should be
prepared for towns and communities
the region.

The Regional Planning Council should
establish guidelines and offer assistance
to local jurisdictions in the formulation
of design policies.

recreation demands will continue into
the future.

The acquisition or protection of open
space is urgent, as urban growth in the
Baltimore Region between now and

-1990 is likely to consume about 100,000

acres.

Open spaces are important in order to
preserve natural features and determine
the lotation of urban development in
the region. 4





Failing septic tanks create health
hazards and nuisances. In the urbanizing
sectors of the region, overflowing septic
tanks pollute streams and estuarine
rivers that drain the coastal plain.

The demand for treated water is steadily
increasing. Present use is 250 million
gallons per day or 68 percent of the
supply. By 1980, it is estimated that it
will rise to 303 million gallons per day
or 83 percent of the supply. If use con-
tinues to increase at this rate, the present
developed supply of water will be in-
adequate after the year 2000.

Two important issues in the increasingly
serious problem of solid wastes disposal
are the location of disposal sites and a





reluctance to experiment with tech-
nological advances which would pro-
vide more efficient collection and
disposal systems.

The widespread destruction by the
storm “Agnes’’ in June, 1972, highlights
the need for storm drainage and flood
prevention measures to be taken by
agencies of the region.

Recommendations

Development should be prohibited in
areas where public sewerage facilities
are not available and where soil or
topographic conditions are unsuitable
for individual septic tanks.

The Back River and Patapsco River
wastewater treatment plants serve about

70 percent of the region’s population.

The larger of the two, the Back River

plant, is now undergoing extension and
modernization; a development and con-
struction program has been designed for |
the Patapsco River plant. Smaller waste-
water treatment plants will also be re- |
quired to accommodate a growing
population.

To correct septic tank problems, owners
should be required to take one of the |
following actions: construction of new -
septic tank drainage fields; installation |
of limited service community disposal |
systems; tapping into existing public |
facilities. The method selected would |
depend on individual circumstances, the
location of the property, and water |
quality requirements.

\

\

If water use continues to rise at its

present rate, additional sources will be
needed after the year 2000. These might

be an increase in the already existing |
Susquehanna River supply, development ‘
of a new source on the Potomac River,
recycling of used water, distillation, and
other measures which are being cur-
rently investigated. -~

OMETIHEN e ST N ST T T s R T

GENERAL DESCRIPTION.

TOPOGRAPHY.

—0-05 Q00—

OUNDARTES. — The State of Maryland lies be-
tween 87° 53’ and 39° 43’ 18" North Latitude,
and Longitude 1° 58’ East, and 2° 30’ West from the
Capitol at Washington, being bounded on the north
by the State of Pennsylvania, on the east by Dela-
ware and the Atlantic Ocean, south and south-west
by Virginia, and south-west and west by West Vir-
ginia. The State’s outlines are more particularly de-
scribed as follows: the famous Mason’s and Dixon’s
line bounds on the east and north, and begins at
Cape Henlopen, the most eastern point of the At-
lantic coast (in Latitude 38° 274’ North, being about
twenty-three miles south of the point now called Cape
Henlopen), and running due west to a point midway
between the Atlantic Ocean and Chesapeake Bay;
thence by a line northerly (being 31° west of north),
tangent to a circle of twelve miles around the Court-
House at New Castle, Delaware ; thence from the
tangent point northerly, bounding on the circumfer-
ence of the circle until it intersects a line run due
north from said tangent point; and thence with this
due north line till it intersects a line run due west
from a point fifteen miles south from the city of
Philadelphia, as originally laid out. Thence with
this due west line (this is the line more particularly
styled Mason’s and Dixon’s line), to intersect a line
run due north from the farthest source of the Poto-
mac river. This last due north line, as always held in
possession by the States of Virginia and Maryland,
and lately finally accepted as the line, is not run from
the farthest source, but from the Fairfax stone at the
head of the northern or shorter branch of* the Poto-
mac. Thence due south to the Fairfax stone, and
thence by the south bank of the Potomac river to
Smith’s Point on the Chesapeake Bay (at the light-
house). From thence easterly to the most western
point of Watkin’s Point, on the eastern shore of the
Chesapeake. From this point the line should run
due east to the Ocean, but has lately been settled as
bounding on the north shore of Pocomoke Sound
and river, to the old line as found marked, and as
generally accepted in the neighborhood by titles
and otherwise, and thence on this old line to the
Atlantic. From this last point the State fronts on
the Atlantic Ocean northerly to the place of begin-
ning, enclosing an area of 10,979 square miles,
of which the Chesapeake Bay covers about 985
square miles, and other navigable waters about 1,000
miles.

The stone at the northeast corner of Maryland
having been remcved, in 1849 a revision of the
survey made by Mason and Dixon was determined
upon.

" Commissioners were appointed by the States of
Delaware, Maryland, and Pennsylvania, who, with
the aid of Colonel James D. Graham, verified in all
important points the work of their predecessors. A
slight change was made which increased by one
acre and eighty-seven one-hundredths the area of
Maryland.

FACE OF THE COUNTRY.— The surface on
both shores of Chesapeake Bay is level, and the soil
generally sandy. A range of hills enters the State
near the Susquehanna, and extends in a southwesterly
direction to the Potomac river, which it intersects

about ten miles above Washington city. This ridge
2





divides the alluvial or tide-water district from the
mountainous part of the State.

The tide-water district embraces nearly one-half
of the territory of the State, the surface being nearly
level, except in the northern part, and but slightly
elevated above the sea, and it is supposed to have
formed the bed of an ancient ocean. Beds of
marl, shell lime, and green sand abound, making
its soil highly productive, when properly cultivated.
The Atlantic coast of the ¢ Eastern Shore” has no
harbors, and is bordered throughout by a sandy
beach, from a few yards to more than a fourth of a
mile in breadth, enclosing a shallow lagoon, which,
owing to the blocking up of several passages by
which it formerly communicated with the sea, may
almost be considered an inland lake. The surface of
the eastern shore which forms part of the peninsula
lying between the Chesapeake and Delaware bays is
low and level, except in the northern part, where it
is somewhat broken and hilly.

In the northern part of Worcester County and
extending across into Delaware, is a high table-land
known as the ¢ Cypress Swamp,” far the most ex-
tensive of the swamps of the State, having an area
of about 50,000 acres. The mountainous district
occupies the strip of territory (not more than four
miles wide in its narrowest part) in the north-west
part of the State, between the Pennsylvania line and
the Potomac river. It is crossed by different ridges
of the Alleghany Mountains, bearing different local
names, such as South-east Mountain, Sugar Loaf
Mountain, Catoctin, Blue Ridge, Kittatinny, Rugged
Mountain, ete., none of which are of great elevation.
This district, which embraces the counties of Car-
roll, Frederick, Washington, Alleghany, and Gar-
rett<(proposed), so far from being wild and uninhab-
itable, containg some of the finest roads and most
desirable farms in the State, much of the region
being characterized by hills of moderate height,
whose rounded summits are covered with verdure,
and the streams that intersect them have generally
abrupt banks, with small tracts of alluvial soil. One
of the finest valleys is the one known in Pennsylva-
nia as the “Cumberland Valley,” in Maryland as
the ¢ Iagerstown Valley,” and in Virginia as the
“Shenandoah Valley.” Tt has a rolling surface and
fertile soil resting upon ¢ Trenton limestone,” which
is remarkable as containing all the great caverns in
the country. Westward of this valley is a belt from
thirty to sixty miles wide of ridges of moderate
height, with their included valleys, and the Alle-
ghany ranges are reached in the county of that name.
The mountains cross the State in long, parallel ridges,
frequently some distance apart, and interspersed with
broad level valleys, called ¢ glades,” which are nat-
ural meadows, for miles as flat as tide-water marshes,
and are covered with natural grass, without timber
or trees of any sort. The surface of the country
in this part of the State is generally rugged and
broken, and much of it is still covered with the native
forest.

RIVERS, BAYS, ETC. — The Potomac, which
constitutes the boundary between Maryland and Vir-
ginia, is formed by the north and south branches,
which unite about 20 miles south-east of Cumber-
land. It flows first north-east to Ilancock, passing
through several ridges of mountains, then pursues a
south-east direction, and receives from the right its
largest affluent, the Shenandoah, just before its pas-



sage through the Blue Ridge at Harper’s Ferry.
Flowing thence south-east to within fourteen miles
above Georgetown, it falls over the edge of the primi-
tive formation in one of the most interesting cataracts
in the U. States. The descent is about eighty feet
in one and a half miles, from thirty to forty feet of
which are in one perpendicular pitch. For some
fifty miles below Georgetown the general course of
the river is south and south-west, after which it re-
sumes its general south-easterly course, expanding
into an estuary some six or cight miles in width, and
empties into the Chesapeake Bay in about 88° North
Latitude, and 76° 10’ West Longitude. The entire
length of the Potomac is about three hundred and
fifty miles. The tide ascends to Georgetown, in the
District of Columbia, about one hundred and twenty
miles from the mouth of the river, which is navi-
gable for the largest vessels to Washington city.

Most of the streams flowing into the Potomac on
the Maryland side are small. Wicomico River and
Mattawoman Creek, in Charles Co., Anacostia River
and Rock Creek, near Washington, the Monocacy
River, in Frederick Co., and the Antietam River and
Licking Creek, in Washington Co., are the principal
ones.

The Susquehanna river enters the State from
Pennsylvania near the north-east corner, and, flow-
ing in a south-easterly direction for fifteen miles,
empties into Chesapeake Bay at Havre-de-Grace.
The main stream is about one hundred and fifty
miles long, and has very unequal breadth, at some
places exceeding a mile, and at others less than one-
fourth of a mile. It is adorned by numerous beau-
tiful islands, and the channel is frequently obstructed
by rocky rapids, which prevent navigation in low
stages of water.

The Patuxent is the longest river, lying entirely
in Maryland. It rises about eighteen miles east of
Frederick city. Flowing in a south-easterly direction,
it forms the boundary between Montgomery, Prince
George’s, and Saint Mary’s counties on the right,
and Howard, Anne Arundel, and Calvert counties
on the left, and empties by an estuary two or three
miles wide into Chesapeake Bay. The valley of this
river is about ninety miles long, and is remarkably
narrow. Small vessels ascend forty or fifty miles
from its month.

The entire waters of the State of Maryland flow
into Chesapeake Bay, except a few small streams in
the eastern part of Worcester County, which flow
into Sinepuxent and Chincoteague bays, and the
Youghiogheny river and branches, which empty into
the Monongahela and Ohio rivers.

Chesapeake, the largest bay in the United States,
enters Virginia between Cape Charles and Cape
Henry, in about Latitude 87° N., and Longitude
76° W., and extends into Maryland as far as 89°
86" N. Latitude, and 76° 8’ W. Longitude. The
length is about two hundred miles, and the breadth
from four to forty miles. The distance from Cape
Charles to Cape Henry is about twelve miles,

Chesapeake Bay is remarkable for the extreme
irregularity of its coast-line, —numerous bays and
estuaries are on either side, some of which serve as
outlets or reservoirs to the waters of the different
rivers of Maryland and Virginia, while others are
scarcely fed by any permanent stream, being nothing
more than mere arms or projections from the sea.
The depth of the bay is sufficient for the largest ships
to ascend nearly to the mouth of the Susquehanna.

GENERAL DESCRIPTION.

TOPOGRAPHY.

—0-05 Q00—

OUNDARTES. — The State of Maryland lies be-
tween 87° 53’ and 39° 43’ 18" North Latitude,
and Longitude 1° 58’ East, and 2° 30’ West from the
Capitol at Washington, being bounded on the north
by the State of Pennsylvania, on the east by Dela-
ware and the Atlantic Ocean, south and south-west
by Virginia, and south-west and west by West Vir-
ginia. The State’s outlines are more particularly de-
scribed as follows: the famous Mason’s and Dixon’s
line bounds on the east and north, and begins at
Cape Henlopen, the most eastern point of the At-
lantic coast (in Latitude 38° 274’ North, being about
twenty-three miles south of the point now called Cape
Henlopen), and running due west to a point midway
between the Atlantic Ocean and Chesapeake Bay;
thence by a line northerly (being 31° west of north),
tangent to a circle of twelve miles around the Court-
House at New Castle, Delaware ; thence from the
tangent point northerly, bounding on the circumfer-
ence of the circle until it intersects a line run due
north from said tangent point; and thence with this
due north line till it intersects a line run due west
from a point fifteen miles south from the city of
Philadelphia, as originally laid out. Thence with
this due west line (this is the line more particularly
styled Mason’s and Dixon’s line), to intersect a line
run due north from the farthest source of the Poto-
mac river. This last due north line, as always held in
possession by the States of Virginia and Maryland,
and lately finally accepted as the line, is not run from
the farthest source, but from the Fairfax stone at the
head of the northern or shorter branch of* the Poto-
mac. Thence due south to the Fairfax stone, and
thence by the south bank of the Potomac river to
Smith’s Point on the Chesapeake Bay (at the light-
house). From thence easterly to the most western
point of Watkin’s Point, on the eastern shore of the
Chesapeake. From this point the line should run
due east to the Ocean, but has lately been settled as
bounding on the north shore of Pocomoke Sound
and river, to the old line as found marked, and as
generally accepted in the neighborhood by titles
and otherwise, and thence on this old line to the
Atlantic. From this last point the State fronts on
the Atlantic Ocean northerly to the place of begin-
ning, enclosing an area of 10,979 square miles,
of which the Chesapeake Bay covers about 985
square miles, and other navigable waters about 1,000
miles.

The stone at the northeast corner of Maryland
having been remcved, in 1849 a revision of the
survey made by Mason and Dixon was determined
upon.

" Commissioners were appointed by the States of
Delaware, Maryland, and Pennsylvania, who, with
the aid of Colonel James D. Graham, verified in all
important points the work of their predecessors. A
slight change was made which increased by one
acre and eighty-seven one-hundredths the area of
Maryland.

FACE OF THE COUNTRY.— The surface on
both shores of Chesapeake Bay is level, and the soil
generally sandy. A range of hills enters the State
near the Susquehanna, and extends in a southwesterly
direction to the Potomac river, which it intersects

about ten miles above Washington city. This ridge
2





divides the alluvial or tide-water district from the
mountainous part of the State.

The tide-water district embraces nearly one-half
of the territory of the State, the surface being nearly
level, except in the northern part, and but slightly
elevated above the sea, and it is supposed to have
formed the bed of an ancient ocean. Beds of
marl, shell lime, and green sand abound, making
its soil highly productive, when properly cultivated.
The Atlantic coast of the ¢ Eastern Shore” has no
harbors, and is bordered throughout by a sandy
beach, from a few yards to more than a fourth of a
mile in breadth, enclosing a shallow lagoon, which,
owing to the blocking up of several passages by
which it formerly communicated with the sea, may
almost be considered an inland lake. The surface of
the eastern shore which forms part of the peninsula
lying between the Chesapeake and Delaware bays is
low and level, except in the northern part, where it
is somewhat broken and hilly.

In the northern part of Worcester County and
extending across into Delaware, is a high table-land
known as the ¢ Cypress Swamp,” far the most ex-
tensive of the swamps of the State, having an area
of about 50,000 acres. The mountainous district

The region drained by the Chesapeake Bay and the
rivers flowing into it, embraces an area of about
70,000 square miles.
