ALLEGHANY COUNTY * occupies the extreme
western end of the State, and is bounded on the
north by Pennsylvania, east by Washington County,
south by the north branch of the Potomac river to
its source at the Fairfax stone, and on the west by a
line run due north from the Fairfax stone to the
Pennsylvania line. The two last-named outlines
separate it from the State of West Virginia.

This county is crossed by the ranges of the Alle-
ghany Mountains, from which it takesits name. The
geology is composed principally of sandstone and
limestone, with quartz and slate. The most valuable
minerals are the vast coal-fields and iron-ore beds.
The soil is of varying character of sand and clay, in
some parts quite fertile, though mostly uncultivated,
and covered with natural forests. The waters of the
county are the North Branch of the Potomac, and
Savage River, and George’s, Will’s Town, and Fif-
teen Mile creeks, with many tributaries heading in
the mountains, and all flowing into the Potomac.
The western portion of the county is drained by the
Big and Little Youghiogheny rivers (commonly called
Big and Little Yough), with their numerous small
creeks and branches, which empty into the Monon-
gahela and Ohio rivers.

The surface of Alleghany is broken and irregular,
the greater part being on the mountains, and covered
with the original forests of fine timbers, whilst be-
tween the mountain ridges are many broad and level
valleys known as ¢ The Glades,” which have in most
cases a rich deep soil, and are covered with excellent
grasses, forming naturally very fine grazing lands,
and yielding large crops of hay. These lands also
make good farms, producing all kinds of grain and
fine fruit.

Alleghany possesses, in its immense coal-fields, the
most valuable mineral deposits in the State, being
superior, in fact, to gold mines. There are three
large coal-fields: one in the Youghiogheny Valley,
another along Meadow Mountain, neither of which is
used except for local purposes, having no outlet to a
market. The third is the “Great George’s Creek”
and Cumberland coal-field. This region, since the
construction of the Chesapeake and Ohio Canal, and
the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad, has been largely
developed. The George’s Creek, now Cumberland
and Pennsylvania Railroad, extends from Western-
port, on the Potomac, and the Baltimore and Ohio

*If adopted by the people at the November election of 1872, the
county of Alleghany will be divided, and the western portion will
be formed into a new county, and called ¢ Garrett.”

The line of division commences on the north branch of the Po-
tomac, at the mouth of Savage River, and runs in a north-easterly
direction to the summit of Savage Mountain, on the Pennsylvania
line.



Railroad, up George’s Creck, and tunnelling the ridge
at Frostburg, then descends the sides of the moun-
tains by Mt. Savage to Cumberland. The Cumber-
land Coal and Iron Company’s Railroad also connects
their mines with Cumberland. These two roads,
running directly from the mines, transport the coal
and deliver it to the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad,
and Chesapeake and Ohio Canal, which bring it to
the markets at Georgetown and Alexandria on the
Potomac, and to Baltimore. The products of these
mines have increased from a few thousand tons,
twelve or fifteen years back, to an annual delivery
ofnearly 1,000,000 tons with the present facilities, tax-
ing the capacity of the two great sources of outlet,
one of which, the canal, is generally closed four or
five months in the year.

The coal produced is bituminous, burns very easily
and to a very light ash, having no slag or clinker. It
is excellent for blacksmithing, and unexcelled for
manufacturing purposes generally, being the very
best fuel for generating steam. The demand for
this coal is always equal to or beyond the supply,
whilst the extent of coal in this one field alone is
such, that it is estimated it would yield its present
annual supply for 4,000 years. :

This county has also large supplies of iron ores,
which are smelted in several large furnaces, many
undeveloped beds being a very fine description of
ore. Also, excellent building material of limestone
and sandstone, and large quantities of hydraulic ce-
ment, which is obtained very near to and prepared
for market at Cumberland. Fire-brick clay of a
very superior quality is found and manufactured in
immense quantities at Mt. Savage Works. This
county has great and almost innumerable water-
powers, comparatively little used, having only some
few grist and saw mills (mostly the latter) for local
uses only.

This county has good transportation by the rail-
road and canal before named, and also a turnpike
running easterly; and the Great National Road
(turnpike), which was built by the United States
Government to Indianapolis, runs westerly from
Cumberland.

Cumberland, the county-seat, is situated around a
great bend in the Potomac river, and sustained prin-
cipally by the operations of the coal trade, by the
Baltimore and Ohio Railroad, and the Chesapeake
and Ohio Canal which terminates here.

ANNE ARUNDEL is the most centrally situated
county of the State, and is bounded on the east by
the Chesapeake Bay, south by Calvert County, west
by the Patuxent river and Prince George’s County,
northwest by Howard County, and north by Balti-
more County. At its northern extremity it lies
immediately opposite to and is connected with
Baltimore city by a draw-bridge about a mile long.
Iron ore abounds in the northern part of Anne
Arundel.

This county is of a rolling character, but has no
very elevated points, and, like most of the other coun-
ties, has all descriptions of soil. Below Annapolis
there is generally a stiffer soil, and mostly an excellent
fertile country, and very productive in tobacco and
grain. The country between Annapolis and Balti-
more is almost entirely cultivated in truck gardens,
and sends to the Baltimore markets a large propor-
tion of their finest supplies, producing immense
quantities of strawberries, peas, cucumbers, toma-
toes, cantaloupes, water-melons, cabbages, &c. This
section is highly adapted for this purpose, being
mostly a light soil, easily tilled, and, being protected
by the elevated lands north of Baltimore, is several
days earlier in ripening crops than the soils around
the north of the city. The timbers are principally
oaks, chestnut, and pines. There are some fisheries
in the county though not very extensive, but oysters
abound around all the shores south from Sandy
Point, and also wild fowl in the season.

Annapolis city is the county-seat, the capital of



Maryland, and the oldest city in the State, dating its
origin from the early days of the colony. It was,
until the Revolution, the largest city, and also pub-
lished the only newspaper in the State for the first
forty or fifty years of its existence. The United
States Naval Academy having been located here
some years back, the city took quite a start, and be-
came quite renewed in appearance, and also increased
in population from 38,011 in 1850 to 4,529 in 1860,
and 5,744 in 1870. The city is pleasantly situated
near the mouth of the Severn river, which is navi-
gable for large vessels several miles farther up.

BALTIMORE COUNTY is the most central of
the northern tier of counties, and one of the largest
in the State, being bounded on the north by Penn-
sylvania, east by Harford County, west by Carroll
County, and southwest and south by the Patapsco
Falls and River, separating it from Howard and
Anne Arundel counties. This county, from its po-
sition surrounding the metropolis, is the most im-
portant in the State. The surface is uneven and
varied, and the rivers and falls which traverse it
afford immense water-powers, and are the sites of
the most extensive milling operations in the Union.
The Little and Great Gunpowder Falls, Patapsco
River, and Gwynn’s and Jones’s Falls are improved
with large carpet, cotton and woollen factories, fur-
naces, foundries, paper and flouring mills, all doing
a large and flourishing business. The finest and
strongest cotton duck and the best flour are here
manufactured. In many parts fruits are extensively
cultivated, and the vicinity of Baltimore is remark-
able for the fine quality and profusion of its garden
vegetables.

Iron ores of the brown hematite order, magnetic
oxide, and carbonate species are found in many parts
of the county, and smelted in several furnaces.
Copper mines are worked at Bare Hills, about seven
miles north of Baltimore; and near Bare Hills, and
southwest from Reisterstown, are very extensive beds
of chrome ore, yiclding a large proportion of that
article produced by our State, which furnishes the
entire supply of chrome used in this country, and
much of that used in Europe.

The large beds of clay in the vicinity of Baltimore
have always been celebrated for producing bricks
unequalled in the country for uniformity of color
and smoothness. This clay is also manufactured
into stone-ware and earthen-ware. Beds of excel-
lent clay for fire-bricks also exist in the same vicinity.

Large quarries of fine building-stone are exten-
sively worked, affording good granite and gneiss, in
the vicinity of Baltimore. In the neighborhood of
Texas and Cockeysville are unlimited quantities of
excellent marble, the fine-grained white species used
for the Capitol extension at Washington, and the
alum marble, well known from its use in the con-
struction of the Patent Office at Washington. Large
quarries of limestone exist in many parts of the
county; a great quantity is burned at Texas. Lime
is abundant in Long Green, Dulany’s, Green Spring,
Worthington, and other valleys, which valleys con-
tain some of the very finest and most productive
lands in the State.

There are some fisheries on the Bay shore, and
some of the best points for shooting wild fowl. The
county is well provided with travelling facilities,
most of the roads leaving the city are turnpikes,
whilst all the railway routes also centre here. The
Baltimore and Ohio Railroad, running southwesterly
and westerly; the Western Maryland Railroad, north-
westerly; the Northern Central extends the entire
length of the county in a northern direction, and the
Philadelphia Railroad toward the east. There are
also horse railways running westerly to Catonsville,
and northerly to Towsontown, seven miles from
Baltimore.

CALVERT COUNTY lies on the western shore
of Chesapeake Bay, and is the smallest county in the

* New county of GarrrrT, proposed to be formed from the
western part of Alleghany.
+ New county from Somerset and Worcester in 1867.

ALLEGHANY COUNTY * occupies the extreme
western end of the State, and is bounded on the
north by Pennsylvania, east by Washington County,
south by the north branch of the Potomac river to
its source at the Fairfax stone, and on the west by a
line run due north from the Fairfax stone to the
Pennsylvania line. The two last-named outlines
separate it from the State of West Virginia.

This county is crossed by the ranges of the Alle-
ghany Mountains, from which it takesits name. The
geology is composed principally of sandstone and
limestone, with quartz and slate. The most valuable
minerals are the vast coal-fields and iron-ore beds.
The soil is of varying character of sand and clay, in
some parts quite fertile, though mostly uncultivated,
and covered with natural forests. The waters of the
county are the North Branch of the Potomac, and
Savage River, and George’s, Will’s Town, and Fif-
teen Mile creeks, with many tributaries heading in
the mountains, and all flowing into the Potomac.
The western portion of the county is drained by the
Big and Little Youghiogheny rivers (commonly called
Big and Little Yough), with their numerous small
creeks and branches, which empty into the Monon-
gahela and Ohio rivers.

The surface of Alleghany is broken and irregular,
the greater part being on the mountains, and covered
with the original forests of fine timbers, whilst be-
tween the mountain ridges are many broad and level
valleys known as ¢ The Glades,” which have in most
cases a rich deep soil, and are covered with excellent
grasses, forming naturally very fine grazing lands,
and yielding large crops of hay. These lands also
make good farms, producing all kinds of grain and
fine fruit.

Alleghany possesses, in its immense coal-fields, the
most valuable mineral deposits in the State, being
superior, in fact, to gold mines. There are three
large coal-fields: one in the Youghiogheny Valley,
another along Meadow Mountain, neither of which is
used except for local purposes, having no outlet to a
market. The third is the “Great George’s Creek”
and Cumberland coal-field. This region, since the
construction of the Chesapeake and Ohio Canal, and
the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad, has been largely
developed. The George’s Creek, now Cumberland
and Pennsylvania Railroad, extends from Western-
port, on the Potomac, and the Baltimore and Ohio

*If adopted by the people at the November election of 1872, the
county of Alleghany will be divided, and the western portion will
be formed into a new county, and called ¢ Garrett.”

The line of division commences on the north branch of the Po-
tomac, at the mouth of Savage River, and runs in a north-easterly
direction to the summit of Savage Mountain, on the Pennsylvania
line.



Railroad, up George’s Creck, and tunnelling the ridge
at Frostburg, then descends the sides of the moun-
tains by Mt. Savage to Cumberland. The Cumber-
land Coal and Iron Company’s Railroad also connects
their mines with Cumberland. These two roads,
running directly from the mines, transport the coal
and deliver it to the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad,
and Chesapeake and Ohio Canal, which bring it to
the markets at Georgetown and Alexandria on the
Potomac, and to Baltimore. The products of these
mines have increased from a few thousand tons,
twelve or fifteen years back, to an annual delivery
ofnearly 1,000,000 tons with the present facilities, tax-
ing the capacity of the two great sources of outlet,
one of which, the canal, is generally closed four or
five months in the year.

The coal produced is bituminous, burns very easily
and to a very light ash, having no slag or clinker. It
is excellent for blacksmithing, and unexcelled for
manufacturing purposes generally, being the very
best fuel for generating steam. The demand for
this coal is always equal to or beyond the supply,
whilst the extent of coal in this one field alone is
such, that it is estimated it would yield its present
annual supply for 4,000 years. :

This county has also large supplies of iron ores,
which are smelted in several large furnaces, many
undeveloped beds being a very fine description of
ore. Also, excellent building material of limestone
and sandstone, and large quantities of hydraulic ce-
ment, which is obtained very near to and prepared
for market at Cumberland. Fire-brick clay of a
very superior quality is found and manufactured in
immense quantities at Mt. Savage Works. This
county has great and almost innumerable water-
powers, comparatively little used, having only some
few grist and saw mills (mostly the latter) for local
uses only.

This county has good transportation by the rail-
road and canal before named, and also a turnpike
running easterly; and the Great National Road
(turnpike), which was built by the United States
Government to Indianapolis, runs westerly from
Cumberland.

Cumberland, the county-seat, is situated around a
great bend in the Potomac river, and sustained prin-
cipally by the operations of the coal trade, by the
Baltimore and Ohio Railroad, and the Chesapeake
and Ohio Canal which terminates here.

ANNE ARUNDEL is the most centrally situated
county of the State, and is bounded on the east by
the Chesapeake Bay, south by Calvert County, west
by the Patuxent river and Prince George’s County,
northwest by Howard County, and north by Balti-
more County. At its northern extremity it lies
immediately opposite to and is connected with
Baltimore city by a draw-bridge about a mile long.
Iron ore abounds in the northern part of Anne
Arundel.

This county is of a rolling character, but has no
very elevated points, and, like most of the other coun-
ties, has all descriptions of soil. Below Annapolis
there is generally a stiffer soil, and mostly an excellent
fertile country, and very productive in tobacco and
grain. The country between Annapolis and Balti-
more is almost entirely cultivated in truck gardens,
and sends to the Baltimore markets a large propor-
tion of their finest supplies, producing immense
quantities of strawberries, peas, cucumbers, toma-
toes, cantaloupes, water-melons, cabbages, &c. This
section is highly adapted for this purpose, being
mostly a light soil, easily tilled, and, being protected
by the elevated lands north of Baltimore, is several
days earlier in ripening crops than the soils around
the north of the city. The timbers are principally
oaks, chestnut, and pines. There are some fisheries
in the county though not very extensive, but oysters
abound around all the shores south from Sandy
Point, and also wild fowl in the season.

Annapolis city is the county-seat, the capital of



Maryland, and the oldest city in the State, dating its
origin from the early days of the colony. It was,
until the Revolution, the largest city, and also pub-
lished the only newspaper in the State for the first
forty or fifty years of its existence. The United
States Naval Academy having been located here
some years back, the city took quite a start, and be-
came quite renewed in appearance, and also increased
in population from 38,011 in 1850 to 4,529 in 1860,
and 5,744 in 1870. The city is pleasantly situated
near the mouth of the Severn river, which is navi-
gable for large vessels several miles farther up.

BALTIMORE COUNTY is the most central of
the northern tier of counties, and one of the largest
in the State, being bounded on the north by Penn-
sylvania, east by Harford County, west by Carroll
County, and southwest and south by the Patapsco
Falls and River, separating it from Howard and
Anne Arundel counties. This county, from its po-
sition surrounding the metropolis, is the most im-
portant in the State. The surface is uneven and
varied, and the rivers and falls which traverse it
afford immense water-powers, and are the sites of
the most extensive milling operations in the Union.
The Little and Great Gunpowder Falls, Patapsco
River, and Gwynn’s and Jones’s Falls are improved
with large carpet, cotton and woollen factories, fur-
naces, foundries, paper and flouring mills, all doing
a large and flourishing business. The finest and
strongest cotton duck and the best flour are here
manufactured. In many parts fruits are extensively
cultivated, and the vicinity of Baltimore is remark-
able for the fine quality and profusion of its garden
vegetables.

Iron ores of the brown hematite order, magnetic
oxide, and carbonate species are found in many parts
of the county, and smelted in several furnaces.
Copper mines are worked at Bare Hills, about seven
miles north of Baltimore; and near Bare Hills, and
southwest from Reisterstown, are very extensive beds
of chrome ore, yiclding a large proportion of that
article produced by our State, which furnishes the
entire supply of chrome used in this country, and
much of that used in Europe.

The large beds of clay in the vicinity of Baltimore
have always been celebrated for producing bricks
unequalled in the country for uniformity of color
and smoothness. This clay is also manufactured
into stone-ware and earthen-ware. Beds of excel-
lent clay for fire-bricks also exist in the same vicinity.

Large quarries of fine building-stone are exten-
sively worked, affording good granite and gneiss, in
the vicinity of Baltimore. In the neighborhood of
Texas and Cockeysville are unlimited quantities of
excellent marble, the fine-grained white species used
for the Capitol extension at Washington, and the
alum marble, well known from its use in the con-
struction of the Patent Office at Washington. Large
quarries of limestone exist in many parts of the
county; a great quantity is burned at Texas. Lime
is abundant in Long Green, Dulany’s, Green Spring,
Worthington, and other valleys, which valleys con-
tain some of the very finest and most productive
lands in the State.

There are some fisheries on the Bay shore, and
some of the best points for shooting wild fowl. The
county is well provided with travelling facilities,
most of the roads leaving the city are turnpikes,
whilst all the railway routes also centre here. The
Baltimore and Ohio Railroad, running southwesterly
and westerly; the Western Maryland Railroad, north-
westerly; the Northern Central extends the entire
length of the county in a northern direction, and the
Philadelphia Railroad toward the east. There are
also horse railways running westerly to Catonsville,
and northerly to Towsontown, seven miles from
Baltimore.

CALVERT COUNTY lies on the western shore
of Chesapeake Bay, and is the smallest county in the

GENERAL DESCRIPTION.





State, being in length about 32 miles, with an aver-

age width of only 7 miles. Itisa peninsula, bounded
by the Bay on the east, the Patuxent River on the
west, and on the north by Anne Arundel County.
The surface is undulating, and drains from a central
elevation towards the bay and river, into which nu-
merous little creeks empty.

The soil is a soft fine mould, except on the Patux-
ent, where it is more clayey, and is well adapted to
the growth of corn, tobacco, and wheat, though the
great staple is tobacco. The climate is generally
warm and mild. The waters of the Chesapeake and
Patuxent abound in the finest fish and oysters; im-
mense quantities of the latter are annually carried to
Baltimore and the Northern markets; the trade em-
ploying large numbers of men. Tripoli, which is
used as a polishing material, is found in many local-
ities, the deposit on the Patuxent being very large.
Marl exists also, affording a good fertilizer in many
localities. Oak, Chestnut, Pine, and Locust are the
natural timber growths, and mostly line the navi-
gable waters.

CAROLINE COUNTY is of small area, and is
bounded on the east by the State of Delaware, north-
west and west by Queen Anne’s and Talbot, and
south’by Dorchester counties.

The main branch of the Choptank River runs
through the county, and is navigated by steamboats
to Denton. This, with other crecks, afford excellent
facilities for sending produce to market, and in re-
turn, obtaining lime, ashes, and manures; scarcely
any land lying more than five miles from navigable
water.

Some of its soils are sandy, some are low meadow-
lands of rich black earth, but the largest proportion
is a loam with a clay subsoil. The last will produce
grains, grasses, vegetables, cotton, and tobacco, which
latter two are raised in small quantities very success-
fully for domestic use. The sandy soil is very pro-
ductive in sweet potatoes, and every variety of vege-
tables and fruits. Peaches are very largely cultivated
and sent to the city markets.

The general character of the county is level, but
sufficiently undulating to afford drainage, and the
roads are mostly level and hard, and give very fine
travelling facilities. Some excellent fisheries of shad
and herring are in the county, and very large quan-
tities of oysters are marketed. Crabs, wild ducks,
and other game are also abundant.

The county-seat is at Denton, a quiet town pleas-
antly situated at the head of steamboat navigation
on the Choptank River. Two other considerable
towns are Greensborough and Hillsborough, both
near the Maryland and Delaware Railroad, which
crosses the upper part of the county.

CARROLL COUNTY is bounded on the north
by Pennsylvania, on the south by Howard County,
on the east by Baltimore County, and on the west by
Frederick County. The surface is mostly undulat-

ing, watered by fine streams, tributaries of the Pa-

tapsco and Monocacy rivers, which flow from innu-
merable springs of the purest water. Kxcellent
water-power is afforded by these streams, which is
improved by cotton and woollen factories, merchant
and paper-mills, and numerous saw and grist-mills.
There are also a considerable number of tanneries,
induced, no doubt, by the abundance of fine oak
timber, which comprises the body of the natural
growth of wood. Parr’s Ridge passes through this
county, and is the first elevated ridge approaching
the Alleghanies. From this ridge the Catoctin
Mountains are plainly visible.

The soils are limestone, “ Red-lands,” and slaty

soil, all mostly very fertile or easily improved, ren-

dering it one of the finest agricultural counties of
Maryland. It has but a small proportion of very
poor or unimproved land.

‘Wheat, rye, corn, and oats are largely produced,
with some potatoes and buckwheat, and latterly con-

s N A i N il TS



siderable sorghum. Tobacco is still raised to some
extent in the lower part of the county, but is yearly

less cultivated. The grazing is fine, and it ranks as .

a fine dairy county, producing a large share of the
butter crop of the State. The Pipe Creek, Sam’s
Creek, and Wakefield valleys are unexcelled for fer-
tility and fine farming.

The county possesses fine building material, a good
species of granite, and other stone. Marble has been
quarried near Sam’s Creek. Large quantities of lime-
stone are quarried in the western, central, and north-
ern part of the county, and large beds of iron ore
are worked in the vicinity of Westminster and else-
where. A number of copper mines have been
opened, and several are now working, in a line ex-
tending from the Springfield mine near Sykesville,
to the Maryland Company’s mine near Finksburg.

The soapstone quarry near Marriottsville has been
and is still extensively worked, and furnishes the
purest quality of soapstone known. At the manu-
factory in Baltimore, it is sawed and worked into all
imaginable shapes for a great variety of purposes.
The number of uses to which it is applied have of
late been considerably multiplied. Even the refuse
stone and dust are valuable in many ways.

The county has a fair share of good roads, and has
communication with Baltimore by means of an ex-
cellent turnpike, one branch of which runs to West-
minster, and the other to Manchester. The Balti-
more and Ohio Railroad traverses its southern boun-
dary, and the Western Maryland passes through
the centre of the county from the Baltimore to
the Frederick County line, passing through West-
minster.

The county-seat is Westminster, which has very
considerably increased in business and general wel-
fare since the completion of the Western Maryland
Railroad.

New Windsor, Manchester, Uniontown, and Ta-
neytown are likewise considerable towns. The first
mentioned is a fine and handsome town, and is
a delightful summer resort, having several mineral
springs.

CECIL COUNTY, organized in 1674, and named
in honor of Cecil, Cecilius Lord Baltimore, is the
most northern of the Eastern Shore counties, forms
the north-east corner of the State, being bounded on
the north by Pennsylvania, on the east by Delaware,
(the celebrated Mason and Dixon’s line separating
the three States,) on the south by Sassafras River,
and west by Chesapeake Bay and Susquehanna
River.

This county is one of the most thriving and enter-
prising in the State. The character of the land is
mixed, the part above the Bay being mostly rolling
and quite hilly, like the Western Shore; and below
Elkton, quite level and similar to the adjoining East-
ern Shore counties. The soil also comprises every
variety, a considerable portion centrally situated,
called ¢ The Barrens,” being pure sand and gravel
(though even this section has of late much improved),
whilst other parts have heavier clayey soil, mixed
rocky, and the lower part an excellent light clay loam.
The county is well populated, and the farming and
improvements generally are in advance of the aver-
age throughout the State.

‘Wheat, oats, and corn are the staple farm produec-
tions; very large crops of hay are raised and sent to
Baltimore and elsewhere in bales. In the southern
part, known as Sassafras Neck, are many large

‘peach farms. This crop is very large and profitable

here.

Cecil County possesses inexhaustible quarries of
excellent granite at Port Deposit, on the Susque-
hanna River. Soapstone also exists on the same
river, and in the northern part near to Pennsylvania
are large beds of iron-ore and chrome, comprising a
good proportion of the most valuable chrome mines
in the world. Near North East River are extensive
deposits of clay suitable for making fire-bricks, and,



latterly, discoveries are reported of kaolin or porce-
lain clay of a fine quality.

The county is well watered and possesses some of
the best water-powers, which are in most cases well
improved with large furnaces, forges, rolling-mills,
paper, grist, and saw-mills.

“ Gilpin’s Falls,” on Great North East Creek, is a
wild and romantic place, and is also a great water-
power, which is at present not used. The creek falls
about a hundred feet in but a few hundred feet of
distance. Cecil has also the largest number of shad
and herring fisheries of any county in the State, ex-
tending from the mouth of the Susquehanna River
around the bay and river shores into the Sassafras
River. These shores also afford abundance of wild
fowl in the season.

The county enjoys excellent facilities for transpor-
tation. The Philadelphia, Wilmington, and Balti-
more Railroad traverses the centre, and also the
Chesapeake and Delaware Canal, and the Philadel-
phia Central Railroad crosses the north-western cor-
ner of the county. The bay and rivers have lines of
steamboats running daily.

The county-seat is Elkton, on the Philadelphia,
Wilmington, and Baltimore Railroad, a very thriving
town of about 1,800 inhabitants. The town of Port
Deposit, on the Susquehanna River, about 4} miles
above its mouth, is the principal business town, and
transacts a very heavy trade in lumber and logs, which
are rafted down the river from the upper country of
Pennsylvania, and also a large trade in grain and
produce. This town has a steamboat running to
Havre de Grace, and also a daily line to Baltimore
and Philadelphia. The third town in size, Chesa-
peake City, is situated at the western end of the
Chesapeake and Delaware Canal. Other thriving
villages are North East, Brick Meeting-House, Rising
Sun, Cecilton, and Warwick.

CHARLES COUNTY, first settled in 1640, occu-
pies the south-western part of the State, and is
bounded on the west and south by the Potomac
River, which makes here a very large curve in its
course. Prince George’s County bounds it on the
north, and St. Mary’s County on the south-east.

The county has an outlet at Benedict, on the Pa-
tuxent River, having a front thereon of three to four
miles. The surface of the county, like that of St.
Mary’s County, somewhat resembles the Kastern

Shore, being generally low and sandy, though suf--

ficiently rolling to be well drained by the numerous
branches flowing into the bordering rivers.

The soil of Charles County has been much ex-
hausted by neglectful culture, but endeavors are now
being used to restore and improve it. Onthe banks
of Port Tobacco Creek and other points, green sand
shell-marl is found in large quantities, affording an
abundant fertilizer. A large proportion of these de-
posits are situated so as to be worked very cheaply.
The county is entirely devoted to agriculture, the
crops being mostly tobacco, corn, and wheat. The
former is the staple production. Fruits do well
in this section. Fish and oysters abound on these
shores.

Port Tobacco, the county-seat, is a small town
near the head of the creek of the same name.
There are no villages of any importance in the
county.

DORCHESTER COUNTY, organized in 1669, is
on the eastern shore, and extends from the Chesa-
peake Bay to the Delaware State line, and is bounded
on the south-east by the Nanticoke River, separating
it from Somerset County, and on the north by Chop-
tank River, between it and Talbot County, and by
Caroline County. This county, in size, is above
the medium, having an area of about 770 square

miles.

The country is generally level, though the upper
part of the county is sufficiently undulating to create
some water-powers — which are improved by grist

considerably increased in business and general wel-
fare since the completion of the Western Maryland
Railroad.

New Windsor, Manchester, Uniontown, and Ta-
neytown are likewise considerable towns. The first
mentioned is a fine and handsome town, and is
a delightful summer resort, having several mineral
springs.

CECIL COUNTY, organized in 1674, and named
in honor of Cecil, Cecilius Lord Baltimore, is the
most northern of the Eastern Shore counties, forms
the north-east corner of the State, being bounded on
the north by Pennsylvania, on the east by Delaware,
(the celebrated Mason and Dixon’s line separating
the three States,) on the south by Sassafras River,
and west by Chesapeake Bay and Susquehanna
River.

This county is one of the most thriving and enter-
prising in the State. The character of the land is
mixed, the part above the Bay being mostly rolling
and quite hilly, like the Western Shore; and below
Elkton, quite level and similar to the adjoining East-
ern Shore counties. The soil also comprises every
variety, a considerable portion centrally situated,
called ¢ The Barrens,” being pure sand and gravel
(though even this section has of late much improved),
whilst other parts have heavier clayey soil, mixed
rocky, and the lower part an excellent light clay loam.
The county is well populated, and the farming and
improvements generally are in advance of the aver-
age throughout the State.

‘Wheat, oats, and corn are the staple farm produec-
tions; very large crops of hay are raised and sent to
Baltimore and elsewhere in bales. In the southern
part, known as Sassafras Neck, are many large

‘peach farms. This crop is very large and profitable

here.

Cecil County possesses inexhaustible quarries of
excellent granite at Port Deposit, on the Susque-
hanna River. Soapstone also exists on the same
river, and in the northern part near to Pennsylvania
are large beds of iron-ore and chrome, comprising a
good proportion of the most valuable chrome mines
in the world. Near North East River are extensive
deposits of clay suitable for making fire-bricks, and,



latterly, discoveries are reported of kaolin or porce-
lain clay of a fine quality.

The county is well watered and possesses some of
the best water-powers, which are in most cases well
improved with large furnaces, forges, rolling-mills,
paper, grist, and saw-mills.

“ Gilpin’s Falls,” on Great North East Creek, is a
wild and romantic place, and is also a great water-
power, which is at present not used. The creek falls
about a hundred feet in but a few hundred feet of
distance. Cecil has also the largest number of shad
and herring fisheries of any county in the State, ex-
tending from the mouth of the Susquehanna River
around the bay and river shores into the Sassafras
River. These shores also afford abundance of wild
fowl in the season.

The county enjoys excellent facilities for transpor-
tation. The Philadelphia, Wilmington, and Balti-
more Railroad traverses the centre, and also the
Chesapeake and Delaware Canal, and the Philadel-
phia Central Railroad crosses the north-western cor-
ner of the county. The bay and rivers have lines of
steamboats running daily.

The county-seat is Elkton, on the Philadelphia,
Wilmington, and Baltimore Railroad, a very thriving
town of about 1,800 inhabitants. The town of Port
Deposit, on the Susquehanna River, about 4} miles
above its mouth, is the principal business town, and
transacts a very heavy trade in lumber and logs, which
are rafted down the river from the upper country of
Pennsylvania, and also a large trade in grain and
produce. This town has a steamboat running to
Havre de Grace, and also a daily line to Baltimore
and Philadelphia. The third town in size, Chesa-
peake City, is situated at the western end of the
Chesapeake and Delaware Canal. Other thriving
villages are North East, Brick Meeting-House, Rising
Sun, Cecilton, and Warwick.

CHARLES COUNTY, first settled in 1640, occu-
pies the south-western part of the State, and is
bounded on the west and south by the Potomac
River, which makes here a very large curve in its
course. Prince George’s County bounds it on the
north, and St. Mary’s County on the south-east.

The county has an outlet at Benedict, on the Pa-
tuxent River, having a front thereon of three to four
miles. The surface of the county, like that of St.
Mary’s County, somewhat resembles the Kastern

Shore, being generally low and sandy, though suf--

ficiently rolling to be well drained by the numerous
branches flowing into the bordering rivers.

The soil of Charles County has been much ex-
hausted by neglectful culture, but endeavors are now
being used to restore and improve it. Onthe banks
of Port Tobacco Creek and other points, green sand
shell-marl is found in large quantities, affording an
abundant fertilizer. A large proportion of these de-
posits are situated so as to be worked very cheaply.
The county is entirely devoted to agriculture, the
crops being mostly tobacco, corn, and wheat. The
former is the staple production. Fruits do well
in this section. Fish and oysters abound on these
shores.

Port Tobacco, the county-seat, is a small town
near the head of the creek of the same name.
There are no villages of any importance in the
county.

DORCHESTER COUNTY, organized in 1669, is
on the eastern shore, and extends from the Chesa-
peake Bay to the Delaware State line, and is bounded
on the south-east by the Nanticoke River, separating
it from Somerset County, and on the north by Chop-
tank River, between it and Talbot County, and by
Caroline County. This county, in size, is above
the medium, having an area of about 770 square

miles.

The country is generally level, though the upper
part of the county is sufficiently undulating to create
some water-powers — which are improved by grist

GENERAL DESCRIPTION.



and saw-mills for local business. The soil is vari-
able, and of the same character with most of this
shore of the Bay, ranging from stiff clay to a light
sand, with, in many places, a black loam. Shell-
rmanure affords a good fertilizer. Oak, hickory,
pine, and walnut are the natural timbers, which are
abundant and largely exported. A good part of the
county is uncultivated, but where well tilled the land
is generally quite productive. 'Wheat and corn are
the staples, with large quantities of vegetables, and
also some sorghum is now raised. This county is
largely increasing its production of peaches, which
are being made very profitable crops. Shad and
herring fisheries are numerous, and generally do
well, whilst almost all sections have supplies of fresh
fish. Opysters are very abundant, and of the finest
kind, this county taking in some of the upper part
of the great oyster-beds of Tangier Sound, the most
famous oyster-field of Maryland. .

Dorchester is almost surrounded by navigabl
waters, and is also intersected by the Transquaking,
Chicamacomico, and Blackwater rivers, and Marshy
Ilope Creck, giving facilities for transportation of
produce, ete., nearly all points being conveniently
located to the water. The recent completion of a
railroad 83.5 miles in length, from Cambridge, to
connect with the Delaware Railroad at Seaford, Del.,
has greatly increased the commercial facilities of the
county.

Cambridge is the county-seat, and is a very pleas-
ant town, well situated on the south bank of the
Choptank River. Other villages are East New Mar-
ket, Vienna, and Church Creek.

FREDERICK COUNTY ranks with the largest
counties, and is bounded on the north by Pennsyl-
vania, on the east by Carroll County, south-easterly
by Montgomery County, south by the Potomac River
and Virginia, and on the west by the Blue Ridge, or
South Mountains, separating it from Washington
County.

This is one of the richest and most beautiful coun-
ties of the State. The soil is mostly limestone, with
some slaty, and considerable “red-lands.” The sur-
face is undulating — partly mountainous —the Ca-
toctin Mountains dividing the county into two broad
valleys, that to the westward being known as the
Middletown Valley, which is drained by the Catoctin
River and its branches; and that east of the Catoc-
tin range is the valley of the Monocacy. Both
rivers flow southward into the Potomac. These two
great valleys are unsurpassed for rural beauty and
excellent farming, and produce extraordinary crops
of the principal grains of this latitude. The eastern
slope of the Catocti Mountain is a most excellent
grape country.

The county is well watered by innumerable pure
springs, which flow into the branches of the rivers
before named, and create abundance of water-powers,
which are improved by large grist- and saw-mills,
and merchant or flour-mills. There are also a
number of other mills, tanneries, and various do-
mestic manufactures. An immense water-power
unimproved, exists on the Potomac River at Wever-
ton. The narrow valley between the Monocacy and
Buckeystown has a rich deposit of a marl composed
of lime and earthy substance, which extends to a
considerable depth; this with the limestone yield an
inexhaustible supply of manure.

Copper mines in the Linganore section have been
worked since the Revolutionary war. Near Liberty
and New London are several mines, now extensively
operated. There are several slate quarries, one of
which near Ijamsville, on the Baltimore and Ohio
Railroad, produces a large supply of excellent roofing
material. Along the side of Catoctin Mountain iron
ore abounds, of the brown hematite species. Some
of these beds, although worked for eighty years, secem
to be inexhaustible. From Woodsborough to the
Potomac is a range of limestone marble unusually
pure, varying in color from blue to dove color. It



takes a beautiful polish, and is similar to the famed
Italian marbles of that color. At the foot of Catoc-
tin Mountain there is a similar bed, and one resem-
bling verde antique. West of Frederick is another
kind of variegated shades of light and dark red, and
on the west side of Monocacy is found the variety
widely known, from having been used for the col-
umns in the old hall of the House of Representatives
of the Capitol at Washington. Frederick County
is now centrally traversed by the Baltimore and
Ohio Railroad, whose company is also now building
a branch from the Point of Rocks, to run through
Montgomery County direct to Washington, whilst
along the southern border, on the Potomac River,
runs the Chesapeake and Ohio Canal, and the West-
ern Maryland Railroad is extended from Union
Bridge at the eastern border of the county to Hagers-
town. These together afford good transportation to
all portions of the county.

The county-seat is at Frederick City, a very pleas-
ant city of about 9,000 inhabitants, situated in a very
fine fertile district. In addition to this city, the
county is dotted with considerable towns, all sus-
tained by the surrounding country, such as Middle-
town, New Market, Jefferson, and others.

HARFORD COUNTY, organized in 1773, is of

medium size, is the north-eastern corner of the west-

ern shore of the State, and is bounded on the east
and south-east by the Susquehanna River and Ches-
apeake Bay, on the north by Pennsylvania, and on
the west and south-west by Baltimore County.

This county possesses a great variety of soils. The
lower part being level and composed of some sandy
and some clay lands, but mostly of a light loam, very
easily worked and improved. The section called the
Necks has mostly very fine and large farms, with ex-
tensive peach orchards. The country above the
Philadelphia turnpike is undulating and in some
parts very hilly, the soil comprising clay, light-loam,
and considerable limestone, the last-mentioned being
mostly found in the upper part of the county.

This county is well watered by branches emptying
into the Little Gunpowder River, and Winter’s and
Binum’s Runs, which flow southward into the Ches-
apeake, and by Deer Creek and its tributaries, which
drain the northern part of the county, and flow into
the Susquehanna. ¢ The Rocks of Deer Creek” is
one of the most romantic spots in the State, and
well worth a visit of the admirers of the great works
of nature. These rocks form a great promontory
projecting over the road, passing along the bank of
the creek. :

Perhaps no county in the State has improved more
in appearance, fertility, and general prosperity during
the last twenty years than Harford.

The productions are wheat, buckwheat, oats, and
corn, and recently considerable crops of sorghum

have been raised, and made into a fine syrup by a -

number of mills erected for that purpose.

This county possesses fine water-powers, improved
by furnaces, factories, foundries, some flour-mills, and
numerous saw- and grist-mills.

In this county are large quarries of excellent build-
ing-stone of a gneiss or granite character.

This county possesses large beds of iron ore, and
some of the most valuable chrome beds in the world.
Also, near the Pennsylvania line, extensive slate
quarries have been worked, and near Abingdon there
exists a very large deposit of kaolin or poreelain clay
of a pure white color, and very good quality, fit for
making fine porcelain ware.

Very large shad and herring fisheries are located
around the Susquehanna and Bay shore, and innu-
merable flocks of’ wild fowl swarm around the tide-
waters of the county, and afford, with the fisheries,
a good business for many of the inhabitants of that
region.

The Philadelphia, Wilmington, and Baltimore
Railroad passes through the county from Havre de
Grace, and the Tidewater Canal runs aleng the west



bank of the Susquehanna, having its outlet at Havre -

de Grace.

The county-seat is Belair, a small but pleasant
town of 300 or 400 inhabitants, and is situated in an
improved neighborhood.

The principal town is Havre de Grace, at the mouth
of the Susquehanna River. It has about 2,500 in-
habitants, and does a considerable lumber and coal
business. It received its name from French officers
in the Revolutionary army, who were passing through
at about the time it was laid out, and fancied that
it resembled the city of the same name in France.

Port Deposit, four miles above Havre de Grace, is
at the head of tide-water and sloop navigation, and
has an extensive lumber trade.

HOWARD COUNTY, formed since 1850 out of
the north-west part of Anne Arundel, is one of the
smallest counties, having a length of about twenty-
five miles, and a width of about twelve miles, and is
centrally situated between the head-waters of the
Patapsco and Patuxent rivers, the west branch of the
former stream separating it from Carroll and Balti-
more counties, on the north and east, and the main
branch of the Patuxent bounding on the south-west
between it and Montgomery and Prince George’s
counties, Anne Arundel County bounds it on the
south-east.

This county is very undulating, and the soil mostly
good, though not all improved, with considerable
fine limestone land in the central and southern parts.
It is completely intersected with spring branches
flowing into the larger streams, and affording a large
amount of excellent water-powers, which are mostly
improved by factories, mills, furnaces, etc. Some of
the very best water-powers and largest factories in
the State are on its two boundary streams. Inex-
haustible quarries of granite exist in the county; one
variety near the upper end of the county much re-
sembles the famous Quincy granite. The largest
quarries, or those most extensively worked, are be-
tween Sykesville and Baltimore, on the Patapsco,
from which stone the Cathedral and Record Office
in Baltimore were built. Another variety, called
porphyritic granite, has reddish crystals of feldspar
disseminated through it. There are large iron-ore
beds next to Anne Arundel County, and near the
Washington Railroad. IToward has thirty-one miles
of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad on one side, and
twelve miles of the Washington Branch Railroad on
the south-east, which together give convenient access
to almost all parts of the county. This accessibility,
with the eminent natural advantages of pure air and
water, and innumerable beautiful building sites, are
promoting improvements, and the vicinity of the
railroads is being built up with fine country-seats.
Near the centre of the county is the Doughoregan
Manor of Charles Carroll, of Carrollton, containing
nearly 14,000 acres of the finest land in the county.

The county-seat is Ellicott’s Mills, a considerable
town on the Patapsco, surrounded with very ro-
mantic scenery, and many manufactories. Two other
considerable towns in the county are Elkridge Land-
ing and Lisbon.

KENT COUNTY, organized in 1650, is the sec-
ond in the tier of Hastern Shore counties, and is
bounded on the Kast by Delaware, and is a peninsula
lying between the Sassafras River on the north, sep-
arating it from Cecil County, the Chesapeake Bay on
the west, and the Chester River on the south and
southeast, separating it from Queen Anne’s County.

The country is level though not very low, and
sufficiently rolling to be well drained by many
creeks flowing into its border rivers and the Bay.

The soil is mostly a light friable clayey loam, very
easily improved and productive. "Wheat, oats, and
corn, and every variety of vegetables, grow abun-
dantly. The farms are very fine where attended
with any care, and latterly nearly every farm has its
orchards of hundreds, and in some instances thou-

GENERAL DESCRIPTION.

9



sands of peach-trees, producing immense crops of
this delicious fruit, which are taken to market by
the Sassafras and Chester River steamers, which run
daily most of the year. Several single peach-
orchards in the county yield sufficient to employ one
steamer in the fruit season. Other fruits grow well
where cultivated.

Kent has abundance of fine fishing, and on the
Bay shore and in Chester River inexhaustible oyster
beds, which give employment to a large portion of
the population, and during the season is generally
surrounded by flocks of thousands of wild ducks,
swans, etc., which also afford fine gume and much
profit to many persons.

Chestertown is the county-seat, and is a very pretty
town regularly laid out, and very pleasantly situated
on the west side of Chester River. It is dependent
for support upon the surrounding country, its best
trade being in grain, produce, fruit, and oysters.

MONTGOMERY COUNTY is bounded on the
south-west by Virginia, on the north-west by Fred-
erick County, on the north-east by the Patuxent
River which separates it from Howard County, and
on the south-cast by Prince George’s County and the
District of Columbia.

Large quarries of sandstone are opened near the
mouth of Seneca Creek, of which the Smithsonian
Institute at Washington is built, and also a marble
quarry near the Potomac above Poolesville. A
quarry of excellent roofing-slate has been opened
near Hyattstown. Other varieties of building-stones
exist, but are not developed to any extent. Several
gold mines are being worked in the northern part of
the county and near the Great Falls of Potomac.
Also chrome ore has been largely extracted from the
central part of the county.

The surface of the county is mostly hilly, and
gives rise to many branches and creeks, which pos-
sess some of the finest water-powers; this being, in
fact, one of the features of this county, most of the
streams having very considerable fall in but a short
distance. The Great Falls of the Potomac belongs
to Montgomery County, and constitutes perhaps the
greatest available water-power in the Union. These
water-powers are partly improved with a number of
large flour- and grist- and saw-mills.

The soil varies greatly, the western or upper part
of the county being a finely cultivated and fertile
region, whilst the more northern part, although
more thickly settled, is a thinner and poorer soil.
The eastern section, near to Howard and Prince
George’s counties, is mostly a light sandy, with some
clay land, and exhibits, in its vast improvements
about Sandy Spring, what may be accomplished by
industrious skilful tillage. These lands, which were
formerly almost a wilderness, with a value of two
or three dollars per acre, have become an ex-
cellent farming district, and worth $30 an acre and
more.

This county bounds the District of Columbia on
the north-west and partly on the north-east, and
from its proximity to Washington (which is one of
the best markets), is being cultivated considerably in
market farms. Its elevated and very healthy. char-
acter is also attracting many persons to locate coun-
try-seats. These will, no doubt, largely increase in
numbers on the completion of the Metropolitan
Branch Railroad.

The Chesapeake and Ohio Canal runs along its
entire south-western border, and the Metropolitan
Branch of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad, which
is located from near the ¢“Point of Rocks” to
‘Washington, will pass through the centre of the
county, affording convenient access to nearly all
parts. ‘

The county-seat is Rockville, the principal town
in the county, which has a population of about 500
inhabitants. Other smaller villages are Poolesville,
Brookeville, Hyattstown, Damascus, Triadelphia,
Sandy Spring, and Darnestown.

3



PRINCE GEORGE’S COUNTY, organized 1695,
has an area of 500 square miles, and is bounded by
the Patuxent River on the north-east and east, on
the south by Charles County, on the west by the
Potomac River, and on the north-west by the Dis-
trict of Columbia and Montgomery County.

The soil consists mostly of the best loam and sand
intermixed with clay. The underlying strata is marl
and cemented sand, resembling sandstone. The
surface is rolling, and well supplied with springs
and running streams flowing into the two boundary
rivers. These streams have considerable water-
powers, some of them improved with saw and grist
mills. At Laurel, on the Patuxent, is a large cotton
factory.

Prince George’s is an agricultural county, and
ranks with the best counties in the State. The dis-
trict known as “The Forrest” is celebrated for its
fine farms, and is unsurpassed in fertility and pro-
ductions. The principal products are tobacco, corn,
wheat, and rye. Tobacco is the great crop of the
county, and amounted, in 1860, to 13,446,550 lbs.,
being much the greatest production of any one
county in the Union, and about one-third of the crop
of the whole State. The corn crop is also very large.

Iron ore is abundant in several localities, and near
Oxen Creek are large supplies of sulphuret of iron,
which it is thought might be manufactured into sul-
phuric acid. At Fort Washington there is a ferru-
ginous clay, known as ¢ bole,” which is employed to
dye cloth and thread a red color. Tripoli is also
found in many localities, and some of it has been
exported from Nottingham.

The State Agricultural College is situated north
of Bladensburg, in a locality surrounded by some of
the finest farms in Maryland.

Prince George’s has some of the largest shad and
herring fisheries on the Potomac, and on the Pa-
tuxent are extensive beds of fine oysters.
~ The county has, for transporting produce, the Po-
tomac and Patuxent rivers, which are traversed by
many sailing-vessels, besides lines of steamers to
‘Washington and Hill’s Landing on the latter river.
The Baltimore and Washington Railroad also crosses
the northern part of the county.

The county-seat is Upper Marlborough, a small
town. The other towns of importance are Laurel, a
thriving manufacturing village on the Patuxent
River and Baltimore Railroad, and Bladensburg,
also near the railroad and but a few miles from
Washington, and near the battle-ground of the last
war with England in 1814. ,

QUEEN ANNE COUNTY, organized in 1706, is
on the eastern shore of the Bay, extending from the
State of Delaware on the east to the Chesapeake on

the west, and is bounded on the north by the Chester ‘

River, and on the south by Talbot and Caroline coun-
ties. It includes Kent Island, the largest island in
the Chesapeake Bay, which is about fifteen miles
long. Kent Island is important in the history of
Maryland as having been the site of the first white
settlement within the State.

The surface is level and generally low, and the
soils, though various, are mostly of the kind known
as white-oak soil, with a red clay sub-soil, and are
easily worked, and with reasonable attention are
very fertile, producing excellent crops of grain and
grasses. Much of this county is very fine, Kent
Island and the central section especially exhibiting
very fine and flourishing farms. Vegetable or truck
farms are becoming numerous, as also are fruit farms
and peach orchards.

This county is two-thirds bounded by navigable
water, placing nearly all parts of the county con-
venient to market by bay vessels and steamboats ply-
ing north and south of it daily. The water is good,
and the county is drained by numerous creeks, along
which patches of forest dot every farm.

Marl is abundant, and is much used as a fertilizer.
The only mineral found is bog iron-ore.



Queen Anne has unlimited supplies of fish, oysters,
and wild fowl,in the inlets surrounding its shores.

Centreville, the county-seat, is a small town situ-
ated at the head of Corsica Creek, which is navi-
gable for light-draught vessels. Queenstown, Crump-
ton, and Sudlersville are other small villages.

SAINT MARY’S COUNTY, settled in about
1634, occupies the south-eastern extremity of the west-
ern shore of the Chesapeake Bay, and forms a penin-
sula bounded south-westerly by the Potomac River,
easterly and north-easterly by the Bay and Patux-
ent River, and on the north-west by Charles County,
being almost insulated by the finest and deepest
waters, This is the oldest county in the State. The
site of the old town of St. Mary’s is on the river of
the same name, and was the place where the first
settlement was made under the grant of Lord Balti-
more, and where the first government of the colony
or province of Maryland was held for many years,
until the ascendancy of the Protestant or Puritan
element. The portion of the county bounding on
the Patuxent was originally part of Calvert County.
The county is well drained by numerous creeks and
branches, though not very elevated. The south-
eastern portion is mostly level and low, but the
north-western part is undulating, giving some water-
power, which is improved by grist and saw mills.
The soil when first settled was mostly a rich black
mould, of considerable depth; but from excessive
culture, without rest or renovation, it was much re-
duced in productiveness; but in the last thirty years
a great improvement has taken place, lime and marl
having been extensively used.

Tobacco and corn are the principal crops of the
county. The climate much resembles that of the
Eastern Shore, and it would no doubt be as produc-
tive in fruits, ete. No rocks or minerals of note are
found, but marl is abundant.

The county has excellent water communication by
large steamers, which continually run on the Bay and
Potomac and Patuxent rivers. Kish, oysters, and
wild fowl abound.

Point Lookout, at the mouth of the Potomac, and
Piney Point, on the same river, some distance
above, are watering-places, both celebrated for their
invigorating sea-air and excellent bathing-grounds.

The county-seat is Leonardtown, a small town near
the head of Breton’s Bay. There are no towns of
any size in the county.

SOMERSET is the southernmost Bay county of
the Eastern Shore. It is bounded north by Wico-
mico County, east by Worcester, south by Pocomoke
River and Sound, and west by Chesapeake Bay.

The Pocomoke River, which forms the south-east-
ern boundary, is navigable into Worcester County.
Other navigable waters are the Manokin, and the
Annemessex, and Little Annemessex rivers, and
‘Wicomico and Monie creeks. All these waters run
a good distance into the county, giving water com-
munication to nearly all portions. The county in-
cludes the large islands, South Marsh and Smith’s,
lying between the Chesapeake Bay and Tangier
Sound. The surface is level generally, though suf-
ficiently undulating to give a considerable number
of mill seats, improved mostly by grist- and saw-mills
for local uses.

The soil in the northern part is a sand and clay
mixed, and the lower section is mostly a strong clay
soil well adapted to the growth of grain. The pro-
ductions of the county are principally corn, wheat,
oats, and potatoes, with some market vegetables and
fruits. Sweet potatoes are cultivated very largely,
and yield extraordinary crops. In many parts wool
and cotton are raised in sufficient quantities for do-
mestic uses. The soil of Somerset is particularly
adapted to the growth of market truck, and with
its mild climate, caused by proximity to the Bay
and ocean, no county could excel it in the produc-
tion of early or tender plants. The greatest mine

sands of peach-trees, producing immense crops of
this delicious fruit, which are taken to market by
the Sassafras and Chester River steamers, which run
daily most of the year. Several single peach-
orchards in the county yield sufficient to employ one
steamer in the fruit season. Other fruits grow well
where cultivated.

Kent has abundance of fine fishing, and on the
Bay shore and in Chester River inexhaustible oyster
beds, which give employment to a large portion of
the population, and during the season is generally
surrounded by flocks of thousands of wild ducks,
swans, etc., which also afford fine gume and much
profit to many persons.

Chestertown is the county-seat, and is a very pretty
town regularly laid out, and very pleasantly situated
on the west side of Chester River. It is dependent
for support upon the surrounding country, its best
trade being in grain, produce, fruit, and oysters.

GENERAL DESCRIPTION.



of wealth, of Somerset County, is in its inexhausti-
ble oyster-beds, which are unexcelled in their quality
by any country known. These include the greater
part of the Tangier Sound, which produces the fa-
mous Tangier oysters. The oyster trade employs a
very large portion of the population on the islands
and shores of the Sound and rivers. Fish and wild
fowl are also abundant.

The county town is Princess Anne, situated near
the head of Manokin River, which town has about
1,000 inhabitants.

TALBOT COUNTY occupies a central position
among the Eastern Shore counties, being immedi-
ately on the bay shore, and bounded southerly and
south-easterly by the Choptank River and Tuckahoe
Creek, the former separating it from Dorchester,
and the latter from Caroline County. It is bounded
on the North by Queen Anne, which is partly sepa-
rated from it by Wye River.

Seven-eighths of the outline of Talbot is bounded
by navigable waters, and it has also running inland
Third Haven, Harris, and Broad creeks, and St. Mi-
chael’s and Miles’ rivers, dividing it into peninsulas
or necks, and several considerable islands, so that
three-fourths of the farms have navigable water at
their very doors, and of the balance the farthest is
not five miles from a landing.

Talbot has a healthy, mild climate (being tem-
pered by the surrounding waters), and is considered
by its enterprising citizens as the garden spot of
this section.

The soil in the upper part is loamy with a red
clay sub-soil, and the lower part principally ¢ white
oak.” - Both sections are fertile and very productive
in grains and fruits. Deposits of shell marl are very
large and numerous, and also the green sand marl,
similar to that found in New Jersey. The county
produces excellent crops of wheat, corn, oats, Irish
and sweet potatoes, and latterly peaches are becom-
ing a leading production, and no doubt yield a large
profit, the climate being highly favorable to their
growth ; also considerable sorghum, flax, butter, and
honey have been made of late.

The finest fish, oysters, and wild fowl are abun-
dant.

Easton, the county-seat, is situated near the head-
waters of Third Haven Creek. St. Michael’s is
another very pleasant village, lying on the river of
the same name. The only other town of impor-
tance is Oxford, at the mouth of Third Haven Creek,
and which is the termination of the Maryland and
Delaware Railroad, now completed to Haston, the
county-seat.

WASHINGTON COUNTY is situated in the
western part of the State, and bounded on the north
by Pennsylvania, east by the Blue Ridge or South
Mountains, separating it from Frederick County,
south and south-westerly by the Potomac River, and
~ on the west by Alleghany County.

The surface of the county is partly mountainous,
being crossed by a number of ridges, between which,
however, are several fine broad valleys, drained by
Antietam, Conococheague, and Israel creeks. The
minerals of the county have not been much devel-
oped. The principal rocks are limestone and slate.
Iron ore is known to exist in abundance in several
localities, and limestone in immense quantities. Hy-
draulic cement is found near Hancock, and below
Williamsport is a hard calcareous slate, which splits
into parallel layers, and takes a fine polish, and is
very durable. Emery (corundum) is found near the
Antietam.

The soil is principally limestone, with some slate
and white-oak land.

In the eastern part of the county is the great
valley of the Antietam Creek, commonly called the
Hagerstown Valley, that town occupying a central
position therein. This valley is mostly limestone



land, which is unusually productive, and gives crops
of wheat and other grains unexcelled by any por-
tion of the State. The wheat is equally fine in
quality as in quantity, and is manufactured into
excellent flour, there being a large number of mill
seats, improved by fine merchant flour-mills.

This valley has been made famous by the military
operations of the great contending armies during the
war just closed, and also suffered very largely from
these operations. The great battle of Antietam was
fought by the two armies, with columns stretching
north and south on either side and facing the town
of Sharpsburg. So great is the natural wealth and
comparative power of this valley, and the industry
of the people, that but few traces can now be seen
of the damage then done. This county ranks with
the most productive and best populated, although
not very well supplied heretofore with transporting
facilities, excepting good roads. The Chesapeake
and Ohio Canal follows the entire border on the Po-
tomac River, and from Hagerstown the Franklin
Railroad runs northerly into Pennsylvania.

The principal town and county-seat is Hagerstown,
a city of about 6,000 inhabitants, which is an agree-
able city abounding with good fare from the sur-
rounding fertile country. Other considerable towns
are Williamsport and Hancock, on the Potomae,
Boonsborough, Funkstown, Leitersburg, and Clear-
spring, with a number of still smaller villages.

WICOMICO COUNTY * was formed in the fall
of 1867 out of portions of Somerset and Worcester
counties, in accordance with Article 18th of the
Constitution of the State of Maryland, adopted in
that year,—the districts of Barren Creek, Quantico,
Salisbury, Sharptown, Trappe, and Tyaskin being
taken from Somerset County, and Parsons, Nutter,
Pittsburgh, and Dennis from Worcester County.
The boundaries are as follows, namely: Beginning
at the point where the Mason and Dixon’s line
crosses the channel of the Pocomoke River; thence
following the said line to the channel of the Nanticoke
River ; thence with the channel of said river to Tan-
gier Sound, or the intersection of the Nanticoke and
Wicomico rivers; thence up the channel of the Wi-
comico River to the mouth of Wicomico Creek;
thence with the channel of said creek and Casser-
dyke Creek to Dashields, or Desharoon’s Mills;
thence with the mill-pond of said mills and follow-
ing the middle prong of the mill branch to Meadow
Bridge, on the road dividing Somerset and Worces-
ter counties, near the south-west corner of Wm. S.
Morris’s farm; thence due east to the Pocomoke
River; thence with the channel of said river to the
beginning. The surface of the county is level. The
soil is various, being composed of clay, heavy black
loarn, and a light sandy soil. The principal crops are
corn, wheat, and oats. The soil is adapted to the
raising of fruits of all kinds. In the upper section
of the county, bordering on the Eastern Shore and
Worcester and Pocomoke railroads, strawberries
and other small fruits are raised in abundance, —
strawberries being the principal and the best-paying
crop, many persons realizing three hundred dollars
per acre clear; the variety cultivated is the ¢« Wil-
son’s Albany.”

The inhabitants of the southernmost district of the
county cultivate water-melons largely, realizing very
handsome profits. The melons are sent by vessels
to Boston, New York, and other cities. The county
has extensive beds of oysters, which furnish employ-
ment to a great number of her citizens throughout
the year, except from the 15th day of May to the
15th day of September, when they are not allowed
to be taken in order to protect the beds.

The county-seat, Salisbury, is situated at the head
of Wicomico River, on the Eastern Shore Railroad,
and is the principal business town on the shore, car-
rying on a large and flourishing trade in corn and
lumber with Baltimore and other places.

" % Information furnished by Geo. W. Bell, Esq.



At present, freight has to be carried down in
lighters or scows to the anchorage, about one mile
below the town, and then loaded in vessels. DBut
soon vessels are expected to load at the wharves,
Congress having made an appropriation to improve
the navigation of the river. The town has about
2,500 inhabitants. Trappe district is the birthplace
of Samuel Chase, one of the signers of the Declara-
tion of Independence.

The name of the county is that which belonged
to a tribe of Indians whose habitations were on the
banks of the Wicomico River, and whose name was
spelled ¢ Wycomico.”

WORCESTER COUNTY, organized in 1742,
occupies the extreme south-eastern corner of the
State, and comprises the entire front on the Atlantic
Occan of about thirty-three miles from Delaware to
Virginia, and is bounded on the north by Wicomico
County and the State of Delaware, east by the ocean,
south by the ocean and Virginia, and west by Som-
erset and Wicomico counties, from the latter of
which it is separated by the Pocomoke River. The
ocean beach of the county is a narrow sand bar
thrown up by the surf, of a width varying from a
few yards to over a quarter of a mile; between that
bar and the mainland are large connected bodies of
shoal water, known as Assawoman, Isle of Wight,
and Sinepuxent bays, and the upper part of Chin-
coteague Sound. There is now no connection be-
tween this water and the ocean, the last inlet having
been closed of late years by the action of the water.
Into these waters flows all the Eastern drainage of
the county, whilst that west of a slight central ridge
flows into the Pocomoke River. This county ranks
with the larger ones in area, but has many very
large bodies of uncultivated lands, and rather a
sparse population.

A considerable portion of the great cypress swamp
in the southern portion of Declaware formerly ex-
tended into the upper part of this county, but it
has all been reclaimed but about 4,000 or 5,000 acres,
the former swamp lands being now exceedingly pro-
ductive farms.

The prevailing soil is sand mixed with red and
white clay. Bog iron-ore exists in numerous locali-
ties. Besides marsh, muck, and peat, the county has
a large supply of oyster-shell lime. Shell deposits
are found covering several acres in extent, and some-
times to a depth of several feet.

Worcester is almost entirely an agricultural
county, and the productions are principally corn,
oats, and potatoes, with immense quantities of oys-
ters. Sweet potatoes are a considerable crop, and
yield very abundantly. Fruits are being cultivated
of late, and peaches and grapes do very well. The
climate being much tempered by the ocean air, is
mild, and permits the cultivation of many fruits and
tender vegetables in the open air which cannot
withstand the severe winters of more northern lati-
tudes; besides producing strawberries and many
other market products about ten days earlier than
in the upper counties, bringing the highest price and
largest profits.

- This county, in common with the surrounding
country, possesses a large share of the finest oyster-
beds, and feeding-ground for vast flocks of wild
fowl, ducks, brant, etc. The amount of home-made
manufactures of wool and cotton were greater here
in 1860 than in any other county.

The county-seat is Snow Hill, situated at the head
of navigation on the Pocomoke River, and having a
population of about 1,000. Newtown, also on the
Pocomoke River, about eighteen miles above its
mouth, is a very thriving town of about 1,200 inhab-
itants. This town has grown very rapidly of late,

owing to an enterprising spirit among its population.

Berlin, in the upper part of the county, is also a
considerable town of about nine hundred inhab-
itants.
