GENERAL DESCRIPTION.



of wealth, of Somerset County, is in its inexhausti-
ble oyster-beds, which are unexcelled in their quality
by any country known. These include the greater
part of the Tangier Sound, which produces the fa-
mous Tangier oysters. The oyster trade employs a
very large portion of the population on the islands
and shores of the Sound and rivers. Fish and wild
fowl are also abundant.

The county town is Princess Anne, situated near
the head of Manokin River, which town has about
1,000 inhabitants.

TALBOT COUNTY occupies a central position
among the Eastern Shore counties, being immedi-
ately on the bay shore, and bounded southerly and
south-easterly by the Choptank River and Tuckahoe
Creek, the former separating it from Dorchester,
and the latter from Caroline County. It is bounded
on the North by Queen Anne, which is partly sepa-
rated from it by Wye River.

Seven-eighths of the outline of Talbot is bounded
by navigable waters, and it has also running inland
Third Haven, Harris, and Broad creeks, and St. Mi-
chael’s and Miles’ rivers, dividing it into peninsulas
or necks, and several considerable islands, so that
three-fourths of the farms have navigable water at
their very doors, and of the balance the farthest is
not five miles from a landing.

Talbot has a healthy, mild climate (being tem-
pered by the surrounding waters), and is considered
by its enterprising citizens as the garden spot of
this section.

The soil in the upper part is loamy with a red
clay sub-soil, and the lower part principally ¢ white
oak.” - Both sections are fertile and very productive
in grains and fruits. Deposits of shell marl are very
large and numerous, and also the green sand marl,
similar to that found in New Jersey. The county
produces excellent crops of wheat, corn, oats, Irish
and sweet potatoes, and latterly peaches are becom-
ing a leading production, and no doubt yield a large
profit, the climate being highly favorable to their
growth ; also considerable sorghum, flax, butter, and
honey have been made of late.

The finest fish, oysters, and wild fowl are abun-
dant.

Easton, the county-seat, is situated near the head-
waters of Third Haven Creek. St. Michael’s is
another very pleasant village, lying on the river of
the same name. The only other town of impor-
tance is Oxford, at the mouth of Third Haven Creek,
and which is the termination of the Maryland and
Delaware Railroad, now completed to Haston, the
county-seat.

WASHINGTON COUNTY is situated in the
western part of the State, and bounded on the north
by Pennsylvania, east by the Blue Ridge or South
Mountains, separating it from Frederick County,
south and south-westerly by the Potomac River, and
~ on the west by Alleghany County.

The surface of the county is partly mountainous,
being crossed by a number of ridges, between which,
however, are several fine broad valleys, drained by
Antietam, Conococheague, and Israel creeks. The
minerals of the county have not been much devel-
oped. The principal rocks are limestone and slate.
Iron ore is known to exist in abundance in several
localities, and limestone in immense quantities. Hy-
draulic cement is found near Hancock, and below
Williamsport is a hard calcareous slate, which splits
into parallel layers, and takes a fine polish, and is
very durable. Emery (corundum) is found near the
Antietam.

The soil is principally limestone, with some slate
and white-oak land.

In the eastern part of the county is the great
valley of the Antietam Creek, commonly called the
Hagerstown Valley, that town occupying a central
position therein. This valley is mostly limestone



land, which is unusually productive, and gives crops
of wheat and other grains unexcelled by any por-
tion of the State. The wheat is equally fine in
quality as in quantity, and is manufactured into
excellent flour, there being a large number of mill
seats, improved by fine merchant flour-mills.

This valley has been made famous by the military
operations of the great contending armies during the
war just closed, and also suffered very largely from
these operations. The great battle of Antietam was
fought by the two armies, with columns stretching
north and south on either side and facing the town
of Sharpsburg. So great is the natural wealth and
comparative power of this valley, and the industry
of the people, that but few traces can now be seen
of the damage then done. This county ranks with
the most productive and best populated, although
not very well supplied heretofore with transporting
facilities, excepting good roads. The Chesapeake
and Ohio Canal follows the entire border on the Po-
tomac River, and from Hagerstown the Franklin
Railroad runs northerly into Pennsylvania.

The principal town and county-seat is Hagerstown,
a city of about 6,000 inhabitants, which is an agree-
able city abounding with good fare from the sur-
rounding fertile country. Other considerable towns
are Williamsport and Hancock, on the Potomae,
Boonsborough, Funkstown, Leitersburg, and Clear-
spring, with a number of still smaller villages.

WICOMICO COUNTY * was formed in the fall
of 1867 out of portions of Somerset and Worcester
counties, in accordance with Article 18th of the
Constitution of the State of Maryland, adopted in
that year,—the districts of Barren Creek, Quantico,
Salisbury, Sharptown, Trappe, and Tyaskin being
taken from Somerset County, and Parsons, Nutter,
Pittsburgh, and Dennis from Worcester County.
The boundaries are as follows, namely: Beginning
at the point where the Mason and Dixon’s line
crosses the channel of the Pocomoke River; thence
following the said line to the channel of the Nanticoke
River ; thence with the channel of said river to Tan-
gier Sound, or the intersection of the Nanticoke and
Wicomico rivers; thence up the channel of the Wi-
comico River to the mouth of Wicomico Creek;
thence with the channel of said creek and Casser-
dyke Creek to Dashields, or Desharoon’s Mills;
thence with the mill-pond of said mills and follow-
ing the middle prong of the mill branch to Meadow
Bridge, on the road dividing Somerset and Worces-
ter counties, near the south-west corner of Wm. S.
Morris’s farm; thence due east to the Pocomoke
River; thence with the channel of said river to the
beginning. The surface of the county is level. The
soil is various, being composed of clay, heavy black
loarn, and a light sandy soil. The principal crops are
corn, wheat, and oats. The soil is adapted to the
raising of fruits of all kinds. In the upper section
of the county, bordering on the Eastern Shore and
Worcester and Pocomoke railroads, strawberries
and other small fruits are raised in abundance, —
strawberries being the principal and the best-paying
crop, many persons realizing three hundred dollars
per acre clear; the variety cultivated is the ¢« Wil-
son’s Albany.”

The inhabitants of the southernmost district of the
county cultivate water-melons largely, realizing very
handsome profits. The melons are sent by vessels
to Boston, New York, and other cities. The county
has extensive beds of oysters, which furnish employ-
ment to a great number of her citizens throughout
the year, except from the 15th day of May to the
15th day of September, when they are not allowed
to be taken in order to protect the beds.

The county-seat, Salisbury, is situated at the head
of Wicomico River, on the Eastern Shore Railroad,
and is the principal business town on the shore, car-
rying on a large and flourishing trade in corn and
lumber with Baltimore and other places.

HISTORY.

——0-0p 00—

THE State of Maryland was one of the British

colonies, and original thirteen States of the
American Union, and occupies the most central po-
sition on the seaboard, nearly surrounding the Na-
tional Capital.

The first settlement in Maryland was made in 1631
upon Kent Island, by William Claiborne and some
followers, who took possession of that region. In
the following year, a grant was made by Charles L
of England, to Lord Baltimore, of lands covering an
area even larger than the present limits of the State.
A permanent settlement was made and government
established at St. Mary’s, on the river and in the
county of the same name, at the head of which col-
ony was Leonard Calvert, the brother of the Propri-
etary. The name of Maryland (Terra Marize) was
given in honor of the queen of the reigning mon-
arch, Charles I. The first settlers were Catholic
refugees. The settlers on Kent Island refused alle-
giance, and gave some trouble, but were finally
brought into subjection to the Proprietary’s govern-
ment. The colony in its younger days underwent
many changes, the Proprietary being displaced at
times, and the British government appointing gov-
ernors. In 1691, the British king, who had assumed
control of the colony, appointed Sir Lionel Copley
governor, and one of the first acts of his government
was the removal of the seat of government from
St. Mary’s to the town of Providence, from that time
called Annapolis, where it has ever since remained.
In this locality was concentrated the Puritan ele-
ment, which had now gained the ascendancy.

In 1715, the government was again and finally
restored to the Proprietary, the principal obstacle to
the recognition of the family rights being removed
by the fact of their having been educated in the faith
of the establizhed “ Church of England.” The pop-
ulation was then about 80,600, and at this time and
very many years succeeding, tobacco was almost the
only production, and was also used as a currency for
various purposes, and mostly in trade. In 1745, the
first and for a long time the only newspaper in the
colony, the “ Maryland Gazette,” was published at
Annapolis. In 1748, the population was estimated
at 130,000, of which 94,000 were white, and 36,000
colored. In the contest which annihilated the French
dominion in America, Maryland took an active part.

The unfortunate expedition of Braddock against
Fort Duquesne was organized in this Province, and
marched from Frederick in 1754. In the Revolu-

- tion, Maryland also occupied a leading position, par-

ticipating early and strenuously in all the move-
ments of that period. The province expended nearly
$8,000,000 and furnished over 20,000 men to the
armies. At the close of the war, Congress met in
the State House at Annapolis, and the Senate cham-
ber of that vencrable edifice (which is still un-
changed) became inseparably connected with the
history of that epoch, by the resignation therein of
his commission as commander-in-chief of the armies,
by George Washington.

In the war with Great Britain in 1812 and 1815,
many important movements of the British on land
and water took place in this State. In 1813, the vil-
lages of Frenchtown, Havre de Grace, Frederick-
town, and Georgetown, about the head of the Bay,
were plundered and burned by the naval force of
Admiral Cockburn, which traversed the Chesapeake.
The battle of Bladensburg was fought near the town
of the same name, and resulted disastrously to the
American forces. In 1814, the British attempted the
attack upon Baltimore city, which ended in their
defeat at the battle of North Point in Patapsco

‘Neck, and they were also completely repulsed in

their direct attack on the city by Fort McHenry and

some small batteries on the suburbs of the town.
At the November session of the Assembly in 1835,

an Act was passed amending the Constitution and



HISTORY.

form of government of the State. It gave the elec-
tion of the governor to the people, instead of to two
eléctors from each county as heretofore; abolished
the Council to the Governor; gave one senator to
each county and one to the city of Baltimore, and
changed the apportionment of delegates, giving five
to Baltimore and to each of two of the counties, four
to each of cight of the counties, three to cach of the
remaining counties, and one to Annapolis.

In 1851 a State Convention assembled for the pur-
pose of revising the Constitution. The principal
changes were: conforming the representations of
the counlies more to the population,— giving Balti-
more city ten; to Anmapolis, none; to two of the
counties, six; to one, five; to two, four; to six,
three; and to the remaining ones, two each; making
the judiciary elective by the people, and making the
sessions of the legislature biennial.

Governor Lowe was succeeded in 1854 by T. Wat-
kins Ligon, Esq., of Howard County. IIe was suc-
ceeded, in 1857, by Thomas Holliday Iicks, Esq.,
of Dorchester County. During Governor Iicks’s
term of office, the Southern States seceded from the
Union.

The civil war virtually commenced on the 4th of
March, 1861, when Gen. P. T. Beauregard took for-
mal command of the Confederate forces in Charles-
ton, and commenced operations for besieging Fort
Sumter, which surrendered on the 13th of April fol-
lowing. Although Maryland did not secede from the
Union, some of the opening and most important
events of the war transpired in the State, the first
blood being shed in the streets of Baltimore on the
19th of April, when a Massachusetts regiment pass-
ing through to Washington was attacked by a mob,
and two Kkilled and eight wounded.

For some months after, the principal seat of war
being near Washington and on the Potomac border,
the proximity of large bodies of troops, and the con-
stant liability that the State would become the the-
atre of active hostilities, had a tendency to demoral-
ize all industries and keep the community in a state
of excitement and alarm, which subsequent events
fully justified, as Maryland was, during the war,
three times invaded by the Confederate forces.

In 1862, Gen. Lee passed northward through Vir-
ginia, forded the Potomac near the Point of Rocks
on the 8d of Sept., and on the morning of Sept.
6th, the advance-guard, 3,000 strong, under ¢ Stone-
wall” Jackson, entered without opposition the city
of Frederick. On the 8th, Gen. Lee issued a pro-
clamation to the people of Maryland, urging them
to secede from the Union, and assuring them of the
covperation of his army to aid them in severing
their connection with it. No general response was
made to the appeal. :

At the same time, Governor Augustus W. Brad-
ford, who succeeded Governor Hicks in December,
1861, issued a proclamation calling upon the citizens
to form suitable organizations to render effectual
aid to the National Government. On the 10th, the
advance of Gen. Lee’s army entered Ilagerstown,
having evacuated Frederick the same day, the latter
place being reached by the Union army under Gen.
McClellan on the 12th.

Gen. Lee having dispatched a portion of his army
under the command of Gen. Jackson, for the attack
on Harper’s Ferry, took up a strong position with the
remainder about twelve miles west of Frederick,
where, on the 14th, was fought the battle of South
Mountain, which was opened by an attack from the
right wing of the Union army under Gen. Hooker,
and, after a sharply contested engagement which
lasted throughout the day, the Confederate forces re-
treated in the direction of the Potomac, and concen-
trated at Sharpsburg, near Antietam Creek, where
they were rejoined by Gen. Jackson, who had, on the
15th, captured Harper’s Ferry with 11,000 prisoners.

Here, at daylight on the 17th of September, com-
menced the battle of ¢ Antietam,” one of the most
destructive engagements of the war, nearly 30,000



11

men being killed or wounded. About 200,000
men were engaged, with 500 pieces of artillery, the
fight continuing until the combatants were separated
by the darkness of the night. The tide of battle
swayed with varying results during the day, nearly
all the ground upon which it was fought being taken
and retaken in turn. Both armies slept upon the
field, expecting to renew the fight on the morning
of the 18th. The Confederate army, however, re-
tired from their position, and crossed the Potomac
into Virginia, abandoning every place they had occu-
pied north of the river, including Harper’s Ferry.

On the 10th and 11th of October following, Gen.
J. E. B. Stewart, with a force of 2,000 Confederate
cavalry, made a daring raid across the State, reach-
ing Chambersburg, P’a., where he burnt all the
Government property, supplied himself with fresh
horses, and, after capturing a large amount of stores
and supplies, passed rapidly around the Union army
in Maryland, and crossed the Potomac into Virginia.

On the 14th of June, 1863, Gen. Lee again crossed
the Potomac and advanced upon Hagerstown, ex-
tending his army through the border counties of
Maryland and Pennsylvania to Chambersburg, Car-
lisle, etc. The armies finally concentrated near
Gettysburg, a small town in Adams County, Pa.,
114 miles west of Philadelphia, and 75 north of
‘Washington.

Here, on the 1st, 2d, and 3d of July, was fought a
great battle between the entire army of Gen. Lee, and
the army of the Potomac under Gen. Meade, which
resulted in the defeat of the Confederate forces, and
a joint loss of about 48,000 men, killed or wounded.

In July, 1864, Gen. Early, with a force of 22,000
men, crossed the Potomac into Maryland, above
Harper’s Ferry, marched upon Hagerstown, and
took possession of that place. To save the city of
Frederick from burning, the sum of two hundred
thousand dollars was paid to General Early; and
nearly one hundred thousand dollars was paid to
McCausland, in money and goods, by the citizens of
Hagerstown.

Passing on towards Baltimore, he was met on the
9th of July by Gen. Lewis Wallace, at Monocacy,
where a severe engagement was had without check-
ing his advance, and the next day he took possession
of Fredericktown. For four days his army was en-
gaged in plundering the people of Maryland, passing
at one time to within six miles of Washington, cutting
the railroad and telegraphic communication with the
North, and threatening the Capital itself. On the 13th
he recrossed the Potomac with an immense amount
of booty, and made his way back to Richmond.

In April, 1864, a convention was held for a further
revision of the State Constitution. By this conven-
tion a registration of voters was provided for; the
principle of representation according to population
was adopted; to Baltimore City were given three
senators and eighteen representatives; to each county
one senator; to two counties six representatives; to
two, five; to two, four; to two, three; to two, eight;
and to four, one; the power of appointing magis-
trates was restored to the Governor; and a State
Board of Education was created, consisting of the
Governor, the Lieutenant-Governor, the Speaker of
the Iouse of Delegates, and the State Superinten-
dent of Education.

Besides these changes, it was declared — Article
24th, Declaration of Rights—¢that hereafter, in this
State, there shall be neither slavery nor involuntary
gervitude, except in punishment of crime whereof
the party shall have been duly convicted; and all
persons held to service or labor as slaves are hereby
declared free.”

Since the close of the Civil War, the advance of
Maryland in all material interests has been rapid.
An entire change in the system of labor, and the
establishment of free schools, have largely increased
immigration, and done much toward the develop-
ment of the agricultural and other industrial interests
of the State,

armies. At the close of the war, Congress met in
the State House at Annapolis, and the Senate cham-
ber of that vencrable edifice (which is still un-
changed) became inseparably connected with the
history of that epoch, by the resignation therein of
his commission as commander-in-chief of the armies,
by George Washington.

In the war with Great Britain in 1812 and 1815,
many important movements of the British on land
and water took place in this State. In 1813, the vil-
lages of Frenchtown, Havre de Grace, Frederick-
town, and Georgetown, about the head of the Bay,
were plundered and burned by the naval force of
Admiral Cockburn, which traversed the Chesapeake.
The battle of Bladensburg was fought near the town
of the same name, and resulted disastrously to the
American forces. In 1814, the British attempted the
attack upon Baltimore city, which ended in their
defeat at the battle of North Point in Patapsco

‘Neck, and they were also completely repulsed in

their direct attack on the city by Fort McHenry and

some small batteries on the suburbs of the town.
At the November session of the Assembly in 1835,

an Act was passed amending the Constitution and



HISTORY.

form of government of the State. It gave the elec-
tion of the governor to the people, instead of to two
eléctors from each county as heretofore; abolished
the Council to the Governor; gave one senator to
each county and one to the city of Baltimore, and
changed the apportionment of delegates, giving five
to Baltimore and to each of two of the counties, four
to each of cight of the counties, three to cach of the
remaining counties, and one to Annapolis.

In 1851 a State Convention assembled for the pur-
pose of revising the Constitution. The principal
changes were: conforming the representations of
the counlies more to the population,— giving Balti-
more city ten; to Anmapolis, none; to two of the
counties, six; to one, five; to two, four; to six,
three; and to the remaining ones, two each; making
the judiciary elective by the people, and making the
sessions of the legislature biennial.

Governor Lowe was succeeded in 1854 by T. Wat-
kins Ligon, Esq., of Howard County. IIe was suc-
ceeded, in 1857, by Thomas Holliday Iicks, Esq.,
of Dorchester County. During Governor Iicks’s
term of office, the Southern States seceded from the
Union.

The civil war virtually commenced on the 4th of
March, 1861, when Gen. P. T. Beauregard took for-
mal command of the Confederate forces in Charles-
ton, and commenced operations for besieging Fort
Sumter, which surrendered on the 13th of April fol-
lowing. Although Maryland did not secede from the
Union, some of the opening and most important
events of the war transpired in the State, the first
blood being shed in the streets of Baltimore on the
19th of April, when a Massachusetts regiment pass-
ing through to Washington was attacked by a mob,
and two Kkilled and eight wounded.

For some months after, the principal seat of war
being near Washington and on the Potomac border,
the proximity of large bodies of troops, and the con-
stant liability that the State would become the the-
atre of active hostilities, had a tendency to demoral-
ize all industries and keep the community in a state
of excitement and alarm, which subsequent events
fully justified, as Maryland was, during the war,
three times invaded by the Confederate forces.

In 1862, Gen. Lee passed northward through Vir-
ginia, forded the Potomac near the Point of Rocks
on the 8d of Sept., and on the morning of Sept.
6th, the advance-guard, 3,000 strong, under ¢ Stone-
wall” Jackson, entered without opposition the city
of Frederick. On the 8th, Gen. Lee issued a pro-
clamation to the people of Maryland, urging them
to secede from the Union, and assuring them of the
covperation of his army to aid them in severing
their connection with it. No general response was
made to the appeal. :

At the same time, Governor Augustus W. Brad-
ford, who succeeded Governor Hicks in December,
1861, issued a proclamation calling upon the citizens
to form suitable organizations to render effectual
aid to the National Government. On the 10th, the
advance of Gen. Lee’s army entered Ilagerstown,
having evacuated Frederick the same day, the latter
place being reached by the Union army under Gen.
McClellan on the 12th.

Gen. Lee having dispatched a portion of his army
under the command of Gen. Jackson, for the attack
on Harper’s Ferry, took up a strong position with the
remainder about twelve miles west of Frederick,
where, on the 14th, was fought the battle of South
Mountain, which was opened by an attack from the
right wing of the Union army under Gen. Hooker,
and, after a sharply contested engagement which
lasted throughout the day, the Confederate forces re-
treated in the direction of the Potomac, and concen-
trated at Sharpsburg, near Antietam Creek, where
they were rejoined by Gen. Jackson, who had, on the
15th, captured Harper’s Ferry with 11,000 prisoners.

Here, at daylight on the 17th of September, com-
menced the battle of ¢ Antietam,” one of the most
destructive engagements of the war, nearly 30,000



11

men being killed or wounded. About 200,000
men were engaged, with 500 pieces of artillery, the
fight continuing until the combatants were separated
by the darkness of the night. The tide of battle
swayed with varying results during the day, nearly
all the ground upon which it was fought being taken
and retaken in turn. Both armies slept upon the
field, expecting to renew the fight on the morning
of the 18th. The Confederate army, however, re-
tired from their position, and crossed the Potomac
into Virginia, abandoning every place they had occu-
pied north of the river, including Harper’s Ferry.

On the 10th and 11th of October following, Gen.
J. E. B. Stewart, with a force of 2,000 Confederate
cavalry, made a daring raid across the State, reach-
ing Chambersburg, P’a., where he burnt all the
Government property, supplied himself with fresh
horses, and, after capturing a large amount of stores
and supplies, passed rapidly around the Union army
in Maryland, and crossed the Potomac into Virginia.

On the 14th of June, 1863, Gen. Lee again crossed
the Potomac and advanced upon Hagerstown, ex-
tending his army through the border counties of
Maryland and Pennsylvania to Chambersburg, Car-
lisle, etc. The armies finally concentrated near
Gettysburg, a small town in Adams County, Pa.,
114 miles west of Philadelphia, and 75 north of
‘Washington.

Here, on the 1st, 2d, and 3d of July, was fought a
great battle between the entire army of Gen. Lee, and
the army of the Potomac under Gen. Meade, which
resulted in the defeat of the Confederate forces, and
a joint loss of about 48,000 men, killed or wounded.

In July, 1864, Gen. Early, with a force of 22,000
men, crossed the Potomac into Maryland, above
Harper’s Ferry, marched upon Hagerstown, and
took possession of that place. To save the city of
Frederick from burning, the sum of two hundred
thousand dollars was paid to General Early; and
nearly one hundred thousand dollars was paid to
McCausland, in money and goods, by the citizens of
Hagerstown.

Passing on towards Baltimore, he was met on the
9th of July by Gen. Lewis Wallace, at Monocacy,
where a severe engagement was had without check-
ing his advance, and the next day he took possession
of Fredericktown. For four days his army was en-
gaged in plundering the people of Maryland, passing
at one time to within six miles of Washington, cutting
the railroad and telegraphic communication with the
North, and threatening the Capital itself. On the 13th
he recrossed the Potomac with an immense amount
of booty, and made his way back to Richmond.

In April, 1864, a convention was held for a further
revision of the State Constitution. By this conven-
tion a registration of voters was provided for; the
principle of representation according to population
was adopted; to Baltimore City were given three
senators and eighteen representatives; to each county
one senator; to two counties six representatives; to
two, five; to two, four; to two, three; to two, eight;
and to four, one; the power of appointing magis-
trates was restored to the Governor; and a State
Board of Education was created, consisting of the
Governor, the Lieutenant-Governor, the Speaker of
the Iouse of Delegates, and the State Superinten-
dent of Education.

Besides these changes, it was declared — Article
24th, Declaration of Rights—¢that hereafter, in this
State, there shall be neither slavery nor involuntary
gervitude, except in punishment of crime whereof
the party shall have been duly convicted; and all
persons held to service or labor as slaves are hereby
declared free.”

Since the close of the Civil War, the advance of
Maryland in all material interests has been rapid.
An entire change in the system of labor, and the
establishment of free schools, have largely increased
immigration, and done much toward the develop-
ment of the agricultural and other industrial interests
of the State,

GEOLOGY.



GEOLOGY .*.

——oot@300—

IN the present day there are few who will refuse
their assent to the proposition, that the character
of the industrial operations of every country de-
pends for the most part upon its geological forma-
tion, modified of course by climate. It is equally
certain that, in connection with climate, the geologi-
cal structure and mineral components of any region
determine the character and the fertility of its soils.
The mineral masses which constitute our planet con-
sist of many different kinds of rocks, clays, sands,
and other matters containing several substances es-
sential to the growth of plants. Among these are
silica, alumina, lime, magnesia, potash, soda, oxide
of iron, phosphoric and sulphuric acids, chlorine,
and other substances which exist, or portions of
them, in much larger proportions in certain kinds
of rocks than in others; whilst there are rocks in
which matters essential to plants are so firmly united
together and to other substances, that they are very
slowly liberated for the wants of vegetation.

At and near the surface of the earth atmospherie
agencies are incessantly disintegrating and decom-
posing the rocks and other mineral substances. The
resulting products remain in part, and form an
earthy covering. Portions, however, are dissolved,
and assistin furnishing the mineral matters in spring
water; whilst others are washed off during heavy
falls of rain, and deposited in lower places or carried
into streams and to the ocean. What we term soil
is that portion of this earthy covering lying at and
near the surface, and more or less mixed up with
the remains of plants and animals that have died
thereon.

From the following description of the rocks found
in Maryland, the nature of the soil in different
parts of the State is easily determined, as some of
them abound in properties required by plants, which
in others are either deficient or entirely wanting.

Gleological Formations in Maryland.

A prominent feature in the geology of Maryland
is, that most of the formations exist in nearly paral-
lel ranges whose course is about N.E. by N.; passing

* Principally from Reports and Documents of Philip T. Tyson,
Esq., late State Agricultural Chemist.

R e i i e el e el B S S o s e A e W SR





into Pennsylvania on the north and into Virginia on
the south and west.

Most of them, as shown in the map, constitute
narrow belts, and the Sections will assist in showing
why this is the case. They were doubtless deposited
one upon the other in succession, and afterwards up-
heaved by forces from below, which appear to have
acted along lines nearly coincident with their range
or strike, as it is usually termed. These upheaving
forces seem to have acted most frequently and with
the greatest energy upon the metamorphic rocks 5
and 6, and with somewhat less energy upon the for-
mations numbered 8 to 12, which extend westward to
the North Mountain. When we examine the strati-
fication of the rocks from 13 upwards, we have evi-
dence of less disturbance as we proceed westward.

Since the deposit of the coal formations westward
of Dan’s Mountain, the upheaval secems to have
taken place, with more uniform force, over large
areas. The resultis, therefore, that whilst elevations
of more than 3,000 feet have taken place in some
of the ridges, the strata are not generally turned up
at such high angles, nor are they so much plicated
or broken as in the older rocks.

FORMATION Nos. 1to 5.

Gneiss, Mica Slate, and Hornblende Slate, including the
Intrusive Rocks 1, 2, 3, and 4, and a portion of the
Limestone No. 11.

The south-western limits of these rocks above the
tide-level are at the head of tide-water upon most of
the streams crossed by the old post-road from Elkton
via Havre de Grace, and Baltimore to Washington.

Along this line it passes under the cretaceous
clays 21 and 22. It constitutes a belt varying in
width from 12 to 20 miles, and extending through
portions of Cecil, Harford, Baltimore, Howard, and
Montgomery counties, and is bounded on the north-
west by Talcose slates (6), or, more correctly speak-
ing, it seems to pass into that formation by insensible
shades of difference. Nearest the south-western
limits the prevailing rock is gneiss, with occasional
intercalations of mica-slate, and still more of horn-
blende slate. The proportion of gneiss is greatest
in Baltimore County.

Mica slate increases in quantity as we proceed
north-west, and in Montgomery County it is a pre-
vailing rock. The intercalations of hornblende
slate are more abundant in the gneiss than in the
mica slate.

The metamorphic limestones No. 11, which exist
in this range, are confined to Harford, Baltimore,
and Howard, and include several minor ranges of
dolomite. They are associated with a certain kind
of mica slate which is continuous into Montgomery
County.

In some portions of the mica slate we find garnets,
staurotide, and cyanite disseminated in considerable
quantity; and as these minerals are very slowly
acted upon by atmospheric agents, the rock decays
very slowly; and when they form a large proportion
of the mass, furnish a light barren soil.

FORMATION Nos. 6 and 7.
Talcose Slate, including Roofing-slate.

This formation occupies a small area in the north-
west part of Harford, and thence ranges through
Baltimore, Carroll, Howard, and Montgomery coun-
ties in a wide belt. With the exception of the
south-eastern edge (which may be included within
the metalliferous range, or the borders of No. 5),
this formation is singularly destitute of minerals
other than the rock itself, until we cross the summit
at Parr’s ridge.

The metamorphic limestones, between Parr’s ridge
and the western limit of No. 6, differ materially from
those in No. 5. The latter, with the exception of the
“alum limestone ” (which occupies a small area in
Baltimore County), is generally much mixed up with





o S, ks

small grains of quartz, mica, tale, and other min-
erals. The former, however, is remarkable for its
purity, and has a fine grain, and in some of the
quarries there are ledges much resembling statuary
marble.

It seems, however, that those in the same range,
between Liberty and the railroad near New. Market,
have been more fully metamorphosed, and are less
pure. These limestones do not constitute continuous
belts, but interrupted ledges, varying in length from
a few hundred yards to several miles, and constitute
an important element in the agriculture of that region.

The rocks so far enumerated contain no remains
of animal and vegetable life. Those which follow
contain such remains, and are therefore supposed to
have been formed since organic life began on our
globe.

FORMATION No. 8.

(LPrimal of Pennsylvania Survey.) Polisdam Sandstone
of New York.

This division includes—

1. A hard sandstone made up of grains of quartz,
with occasionally grains of feldspar and kaolin. The
silicious cement seems to have completely filled up
the interstices between the grains, so as to give a
firm, compact structure to the rock. Portions of
this rock seem to have been subjected to such
changes as to render it doubtful whether it should
not be considered as granular quartz, and be classed
among the metamorphic rocks. Vegetable life seems
to have commenced at the period of the formation
of this rock, because it contains fossilized stems of
plants. :

2. A slate varying in color from gray to brownish
and greenish. It is ranked as an argillite, but por-
tions of it assume a marked talcose appearance,
especially in the Catoctin Mountain and in parts of
Middletown Valley, where it has been much dis-
turbed and altered by proximity to intrusive rocks.
These last consist of amphibolites (trap), porphyries,
amygdaloid, serpentine, and epidote. This last-
named rock is extensively developed both in large
masses and intercalated between the slates, and has
largely contributed to produce the highly fertile soil
of Middletown Valley.

FORMATION No. 10.

Auroral series of the Pennsylvania Reports. Chazy and
Black River Limestones of New York.

This constitutes the most extensive limestone for-
mation of the United States or in the world, its
entire length being over 600 miles. A small area
of it occurs in Frederick County near the Monocacy
River, reaching from the Potomac to a point north
of Woodsboro’, where it is covered by the mezozoic
or new red sandstone. Between the South and
North mountains, in the Hagerstown Valley, it is
developed to the extent of more than three-fourths
the area of the part of that fine valley within our
limits. The soil resting upon this formation is
among the best in the State.

FORMATION No. 11.
Metamorphic Limestones.

There are two ranges of these in Maryland, both
of which have been noticed: 1st. In the gneiss and
mica slates. 2d. In the western parts of the talcose
slates of Carroll and Frederick counties.

FORMATION No. 12.

Matinal Series in the Pennsylvania Reports, Hudson
River Slates, Utica Slate, and Trenton Limestone in
the New York Reports.

This formation occurs in Maryland only on the
western side of the Hagerstown Valley, and although
the soil it produces is naturally less fertile than the
adjacent limestone, it can be readily made productive
if judiciously treated.

and the western limit of No. 6, differ materially from
those in No. 5. The latter, with the exception of the
“alum limestone ” (which occupies a small area in
Baltimore County), is generally much mixed up with





o S, ks

small grains of quartz, mica, tale, and other min-
erals. The former, however, is remarkable for its
purity, and has a fine grain, and in some of the
quarries there are ledges much resembling statuary
marble.

It seems, however, that those in the same range,
between Liberty and the railroad near New. Market,
have been more fully metamorphosed, and are less
pure. These limestones do not constitute continuous
belts, but interrupted ledges, varying in length from
a few hundred yards to several miles, and constitute
an important element in the agriculture of that region.

The rocks so far enumerated contain no remains
of animal and vegetable life. Those which follow
contain such remains, and are therefore supposed to
have been formed since organic life began on our
globe.

FORMATION No. 8.

(LPrimal of Pennsylvania Survey.) Polisdam Sandstone
of New York.

This division includes—

1. A hard sandstone made up of grains of quartz,
with occasionally grains of feldspar and kaolin. The
silicious cement seems to have completely filled up
the interstices between the grains, so as to give a
firm, compact structure to the rock. Portions of
this rock seem to have been subjected to such
changes as to render it doubtful whether it should
not be considered as granular quartz, and be classed
among the metamorphic rocks. Vegetable life seems
to have commenced at the period of the formation
of this rock, because it contains fossilized stems of
plants. :

2. A slate varying in color from gray to brownish
and greenish. It is ranked as an argillite, but por-
tions of it assume a marked talcose appearance,
especially in the Catoctin Mountain and in parts of
Middletown Valley, where it has been much dis-
turbed and altered by proximity to intrusive rocks.
These last consist of amphibolites (trap), porphyries,
amygdaloid, serpentine, and epidote. This last-
named rock is extensively developed both in large
masses and intercalated between the slates, and has
largely contributed to produce the highly fertile soil
of Middletown Valley.

FORMATION No. 10.

Auroral series of the Pennsylvania Reports. Chazy and
Black River Limestones of New York.

This constitutes the most extensive limestone for-
mation of the United States or in the world, its
entire length being over 600 miles. A small area
of it occurs in Frederick County near the Monocacy
River, reaching from the Potomac to a point north
of Woodsboro’, where it is covered by the mezozoic
or new red sandstone. Between the South and
North mountains, in the Hagerstown Valley, it is
developed to the extent of more than three-fourths
the area of the part of that fine valley within our
limits. The soil resting upon this formation is
among the best in the State.

FORMATION No. 11.
Metamorphic Limestones.

There are two ranges of these in Maryland, both
of which have been noticed: 1st. In the gneiss and
mica slates. 2d. In the western parts of the talcose
slates of Carroll and Frederick counties.

FORMATION No. 12.

Matinal Series in the Pennsylvania Reports, Hudson
River Slates, Utica Slate, and Trenton Limestone in
the New York Reports.

This formation occurs in Maryland only on the
western side of the Hagerstown Valley, and although
the soil it produces is naturally less fertile than the
adjacent limestone, it can be readily made productive
if judiciously treated.

field_edited_text_processed:
GEOLOGY.

13



FORMATION No. 13.

Levant Series of the Pennsylvania Reports. Oneida Con-
glomerate and Medina Sandstone of the New York
Reports.

These rocks form the summits of the North Moun-
tain, Tonaloway Hill, and Will’s Mountain, and
from thence dip under Dan’s Mountain, and do not
again rise to the surface in Maryland.

FORMATION No. 14a.

Surgent Series of the Pennsylvania Reports. Clinton
Group of the New York Reports.

The importance of this group is owing to its valu-
able beds of iron-ore. It consists of —

1. A series of olive, brown, and yellowish slates,
with some sandy layers. Some of them assume a
claret color by exposure. It contains fossil stems.

2. Iron sandstone, alternating with a greenish
sandy shale. Some of the layers contain sufficient
iron to be worked. They are of a dark reddish-
brown color.

8. Upper shale of a greenish color, which by ex-
posure changes to a buff-color, and sometimes to a
brown and brownish-red.

4. Lower ore shale, greenish, with layers of lime-
stone. :

5. A gray calcareous sandstone in thin layers.

6. The upper ore shale consists of bluish and
greenish shales, with alternations of thin beds of
both pure and shaly limestone, and some beds of cal-
careous sandstone. The lower part of this shale
contains, on both flanks of Will’s Mountain, two,
and sometimes three, beds of what is called the
fossiliferous iron-ore, which continues through both
Pennsylvania and Virginia, and is largely used in
the furnaces in the former State.

7. A thick mass of red shales, sometimes slightly
calcareous. A reference to the section will show
that this formation, resting upon the sandstone
(No. 13), appears on the western flank of the North

Mountain, and in the principal valleys between that

and Martin’s Mountain.

From thence it is covered by other and more
recent formations, until we reach the base of Will’s
Mountain, where it crops out, and renders the fossil-
iferous iron-ore accessible.

FORMATION No. 14b4.

Scalent Series of the Pennsylvania Reports. Onondaga
Salt Group and the Water-lime Group of the New
York Reports.

It consists — 1. Of bluish, greenish, and red cal-
careous shales, with some beds of limestone, resting
upon a thick series of gray, greenish, and bluish
calcareous shales, with beds of impure limestone,
and seems to graduate into the cement rock above.

2. A blue limestone with bands of chert. It is
usually in moderately thin layers, and contains a
little magnesia.

FORMATION No. 15a.

Pre-meridian Limestone of the Pennsylvania Reports.
Lower Helderberqg Limestone, New York Reports.

This limestone varies in color from gray to blue,
and also varies considerably in composition. Some
of the layers are very pure limestone, whilst others
are shaly and silicious. It abounds in layers of chert,
which, near the western base of the North Moun-
tain, are of considerable thickness. It contains
numerous remains of shells, as well as of corals. - It
appears resting upon No. 150, near the western base
of the North Mountain, and dips under No. 16. It
crops out on both flanks of Tonaloway Hill, and
passes under Sideling Hill, Town Hill, Ragged
Mountain, Warner Mountain, and Evits Mountain,
and crops out in the city of Cumberland. It is
again found on the west side of Will’s Mountain,
and dipping under Dan’s Mountain, again rises to



the surface in the State of Ohio,—its identity being
fully established by its fossils.

FORMATION No. 15b.

Meridian Series of the Pennsylvania Reports. Oriskany
Sandstone of the New York Reports.

The sandstone is usually of a yellowish color, has
a coarse open texture, is more or less calcareous, and
contains numerous fossils. It rests upon the lime-

stone last described (15a).

FORMATION No. 16a.

Cadent Slates and Shales of the Pennsylvania Reports.
Marcellus Slates, Hamilton Group, and Genesee
Slates of New York Reports.

This group consists of —
1. A black bituminous shale.

2. Olive, brownish, and gray shales in some locali-

ties, containing thin beds of brown and gray sand-
stone.

3. A brownish and bluish slate.

Among its fossils are remains of plants allied to
those of the coal formation, and the lowest yet
known of that kind.

FORMATION No. 16b.

Vergent Series in the Pennsylvania Reports. Portage
Flags and Ithaca and Chemung Groups of New
York Reports.

It consists of —

1. A fine-grained sandstone (more or less argilla-
ceous) in thin layers, parted by thin seams of shale,
with marine fossils.

2. Blue, gray, and olive-colored shales, with occa-
sional layers of brown and gray sandstones.

The rocks of this group, with those of 16a, are
largely developed between Licking Creek and Han-
cock, in Sideling Hill, and in all the ridges westward
to Cumberland, where they crop out. They are
again seen in Dan’s Mountain, near its base, dipping
westward, and do not appear again in Maryland.

FORMATION No. 17.

Ponent Series of the Pennsylvania Reports. Catskill
Group of the New York Reports.

This group is the equivalent of the old red sand-
stone of Europe, and consists, in Maryland, of rather
soft shales, containing very few fossils, and these in
a few calcareous layers. It occurs in Sideling Hill
and Town Hill, and again on the east flank of Dan’s
Mountain, under which it dips, and reappears on the
west flank of Savage Mountain. It occupies a large
portion of Alleghany County, west of Savage Moun-
tain, between the three coal-basins, as will be seen
by referring to the map.

FORMATION No. 18a.
Vespertine Series of the Pennsylvania Survey.

This group consists of greenish and olive-colored
and bluish shales, with a few thick layers of dull
gray sandstone. It contains remains of plants ap-
proximating those of the coal formation.

FORMATION No. 18b.

Umbral Series of the Pennsylvania Reports.

It consists principally of red shales, with some of
an olive-green color. There are also occasional
alternations of slaty sandstones. It contains a bed
of limestone from forty to fifty feet thick, which is
important from the fact that it is the only thick bed
of limestone in Maryland west of Dan’s Mountain.

FORMATION No. 19. (CoaL.)
Seral Series, Pennsylvania Reports.

The coal formations of Maryland consist of alter-
nations of —



1. Sandstones usually gray, varying from coarse
to fine and shaly.

2. Shales usually black and bituminous, or carbon-
aceous, but also gray, brownish, and olive-colored.

8. Slate clay or massive beds of indurated clay,
with little or no fissile structure, and known by
miners as fire-clay.

4. Bituminous coal.

5. Iron ores of the variety called carbonate of
iron. This lies within a thin strata between the
shales and fire-clays, or in flattened nodules imbed-
ded therein.

FORMATION No. 20.

Mezozoic Series, Penn’a Reports, New Red Sandstone
of the New York Reports and of the British G'eologists.

The new red sandstone of Carroll, Frederick, and

. Montgomery counties, rests upon the metamorphic

and the oldest of the sedimentary rocks. It consists
at its base of coarse red and brown sandstones and
conglomerates, upon which rest finer-grained sand-
stones, followed by red shales of considerable thick-
ness, some of which are calcareous. Upon these
shales is found, in the southern part of Frederick
County, a coarse calcareous conglomerate or preccia
of considerable thickness.

Fip

-FORMATION No. 21.

Cretaceous Group, or Chalk Period.

- A wide belt of this formation exists in Maryland.
It consists of —

1. A thick group of sands and clays of various
colors, but principally white, red, and bluish-gray,
with some thin beds of ferruginous sandstone resting
immediately upon No. 5. In some localities it
abounds in lignite, derived from coniferous plants.
The bluish-gray varieties derive their color from the
carbonaceous remains of plants.

2. Iron-ore clays (No. 22). This subdivision con-
sists of a series of beds of fine gray and lead-colored
clays, containing several courses of carbonate of iron,
in flattened nodules and masses, varying in size from
a pound or two to half a ton or more in weight.

The following fossils have been found-in the for-
mations of Maryland, namely:

A new genus of a Cycas, of large dimensions.

Silicified coniferous wood.

Lignites (coniferous). ;

A fragment of a rib of a whale of large size.

A part of the teeth and bones of an herbivorous
Saurian, a large extinct reptile allied to the lizard,
crocodile, ete.

In the vicinity of Baltimore are beds of moderate
thickness and extent of dark grayish-colored clays,
from which is manufactured brick of a very superior
quality.

The lower green sand, constituting the upper beds
of this group, consists of — ;

1. Green sand, more or less mixed up with silicious
sand, and containing shells. :

2. Bluish sandy clays.

3. Black or dark gray micaceous sandy clay, which,
in some localities, abounds with fossil shark’s teeth.

" 4. Sandy limestone, or indurated marl, with nu-
merous shells. This exists in irregular and inter-
rupted beds, from one to four or five feet thick.

5. Beds of reddish and sometimes yellowish sand-
stones and conglomerates, containing green particles
and very few shells. They are from two or three to
twenty or thirty feet in thickness.

6. Loose silicious or common sand, intercalated
between some of the beds, but most abundant in the
upper portion.

The formation occupies a considerable area em-
bracing parts of Cecil, Kent, Harford, Baltimore,
Anne Arundel, and Prince George’s counties. The
soils of this formation are variable. Those of the
sandy clays, with proper treatment, are productwe,
while those of the stiff clays are expensive to cul-
tivate.

ZOOLOGY.







FORMATION No. 23. (TERTIARY.)

This series consists of nearly horizontal, but inter-
cepted, strata of sands and sandy clays, usually gray-
ish or bluish in color.
beds varying in thickness from a few inches to ten
or fifteen feet, made up in a great measure of marine
shells. Corals are also found among them, and in
some localities in such abundance as to indicate that
they are the remains of elevated coral reefs or
islands. : :

The tertiary groups occupy all of the western
shore south of the cretaceous, including St. Mary’s,
Charles, and Calvert, and portions of Prince George’s
and Anne Arundel counties. On the Eastern Shore
they are believed to reach from a line a little north-
west of Chester River, southward to a line running
from near the head of the Little Choptank, and east-
ward to the Delaware line. They embrace a small
portion of Kent and Dorchester, and all of Queen
Anne’s, Talbot, and Caroline.

They possess the highest agricultural interest, from
the fact that they contain the very extensive deposits
of “shell marl ” which have so largely contributed to
increase the productive value of the land of the
middle counties of the Eastern Shore.

FORMATION No. 24. (Post-TERTIARY.)

This formation embraces Worcester, Somerset,
and the greater portion of Dorchester County, and
consists of beds of loamy clays and sands, which it
is believed have not been elevated more than from
ten to thirty or forty feet above the tide-level. The
numerous islands in the Chesapeake Bay are also
post-tertiary. :

As it contains very few fossils, and perhaps none
that will serve certainly to characterize it, the name

is applied because of its position, being above the

tertiary. ‘

The character of the soil, in connection with the
circumstances under which this region seems to have
been formed, indicates that it consists of sediments
derived from the water while flowing over it from
the various formations already noticed. ~We can
detect in the soil and its subjacent beds matters that
must have come from points north and west of North
Mountain. Except in some very sandy districts, it
furnishes a mixed soil, whose fertility is readily main-
tained or improved.

——— -



ZOOLOGY.



By EDWARD D. COPE, A. M.



HE animals of Maryland are numerous in individ-
uals and varied in type. The regions of greatest
fertility are of course those most prolific of animal life,
while the warmth of our summer climate, and abun-
dance of water, furnish stimulus for its multiplica-
There are distinct regions of dis-
tribution of animals included within its limits, which
will be mentioned at the close of the essay.

SECTION I.— VERTEBRATES.

Commencing with the vertebrated animals, which
are the most conspicuous and the most useful to

~ man, we find about 693 species which are indigenous

to the State. These may be exhibited in the follow-

In glancing over the Mammalia, it is to be ob-
served that the orders of Edentata (Ant-eaters, Sloths,
etc.) and Sirenia (Sea-Cows) are entirely wanting,
while the Quadrumana and Marsupialia are repre-
sented by but one species each, namely, Man and the
Opossum. Of the hoofed animals, only the cloven-
footed division (Artiodactyla Ruminantia) exist in a
wild state, the horses and hog-like types ( Perrisodac-
tyla and Artiodactyla Omnivora), as well as the Masto-
dons (Proboscidia), having all disappeared before the
human period.

The most conspicuous Mammals of the State are:
the panther (Felis concolor), the wild-cats (Lynx Can-
adensis and Lynx rufus), and the black bear ( Ursus
Americanus), among the Carnivora. All of these
species are not uncommon in the mountainous por-
tions. Of the Ruminants, the bison (Bos' Americanus)
and the elk (Cervus Canadensis), the largest known of
the true deer, have been destroyed by human agency.
The common deer (Cariacus Virginianus) is abundant.
Of aquatic carnivora, two species of the seal have
been seen on the coast and in the Chesapeake Bay ;
one of these, the hooded seal (Cystophora cristata), has
occurred twice in the Chesapeake.

- Whales are common off the coast. The right
whale (Balena cisarctica, Cope,) is less so than for-
merly, but may increase again, as their pursuitisnow
less vigorous. Finner whales are still more common;
a large species (Sibboldius lectirostris, Cope,) went
ashore a few years ago near Berlin, and the Sib-
boldius tuberosus (Cope), a smaller species of forty-five
feet in length, has been seen in the Chesapeake.
Other large species are seen, while the smaller forms
are more abundant. Black fish (Globiocephalus),
killers (Orca), and grampus occur. The porpoises
(Delphinus, several species, and herring-hog, Phocena)
are common on the coast and in the Chesapeake
Bay. A white whale (Beluga) is said to have been
caught in the latter, and exhibited in Baltimore.

Of the birds, the number of the group of singers
(Oscines) exceeds those of all others, though the
really superior musicians among them number but
fifteen or twenty. The most numerously represented
division, the wood-warblers ( Zanagride), are not fine
singers, which mostly belong to the thrush and
mocking-bird family. The mocking-bird finds a
congenial home in the lower lands of the State, and
may be seen in both wild and cultivated grounds.
This, with many other, especially Southern species,
find here the northern limit of their range in Mary-
land. : ;



The bobolink (Dolichonyz), of the hang-nest divi-
sion, may be trained to be almost equal to the best.
The birds of prey, especially the hawks, are very
numerous in species, while a single vulture (the
Turkey Buzzard) is extremely common.

The game species are but few, but among them
that noblest of them all, the wild turkey. Two spe-
cies of grouse and a partridge complete the list. As a
seaboard State, Maryland is permanently inhabited
by numerous species of wading-birds. Several
species of herons are common along the streams, of
which Ardea herodias (the blue heron) is the largest,
as well as the most abundant, excepting, perhaps,
the smaller Butorides virescens (Fly-up-the-Creek).
The grass-snipe, which fills the evening with its wild
whistle, represents its family in the rich meadows
throughout the whole year; the wood-cock remains
in the thickets, while the true snipe migrates to the
North in spring.

Owing to the possession of coast-line, and the
great inland bay of Chesapeake, the swimming-birds
are very numerous, especially the ZLamellirostral
forms, or geese, ducks, etc. They remain in im-
mense numbers in the bays of the coast and of the
Chesapeake Bay during part of their autumn migra-
tion southward, or until cold weather overtakes
them. Here the gunners and caterers of Baltimore
and Philadelphia betake themselves in numbers, and
with decoys, blinds, flat-boats, and all the machinery
of destruction, slaughter thousands of these birds
for the markets of their respective cities.

The red-head (Fuliz Americana), canvas-back (F.
vallisnerie), and blue-bill (F. mcwils), are most abun-
dant. The Canada goose and brant mingle in great
flocks, and a single species of swan (Cygnus Ameri
canus) is not rare, but is shy.

The wood-duck (4ix sponsa) is known throughout
the State during the year, but most of the species
enter the rivers and ponds on their southern mi-
gration. The loons remain all winter. Numerous
gulls fish in the rivers and in Chesapeake Bay.

Among the reptiles; Maryland is notable for th:
number of species of tortoises found within its
limits, exceeding in this the European list several
times. The snapping-turtle (Chelydra serpentina) is
at home here, and the box-tortoise (Cistudo clausa) is
extremely abundant. The Chelopus Muhlenbergii is
confined to the north-eastern portion of the State
and adjacent parts of New Jersey. Nearly all the
species are valuable as food, and the ¢terrapin,”
Malaclemnys palustris, Plychemys rugosa (red belly),
and the snapper, are sold in large numbers in the -
Baltimore market.
© Of the 23 species of snakes, only two are venom-
ous: these are, the copperhead (Ancistrodon con-
tortrix), found everywhere where not exterminated ;
and the common rattlesnake (Caudisona horrida),
which originally inhabited the whole country. Both
are dangerous, the rattlesnake occasionally attaining
a length of six feet; but they are both exterminated
from the best-settled regions. The remaining twenty
species, where not too small (five species might be so
reckoned), are very useful animals in destroying
mice, moles, and other vermin, and are preserved by
intelligent farmers on this account. I have taken
three meadow-mice (Arvicolz) from the stomach of
one black snake (Bascanion constrictor), and have
found a house-snake (Ophibolous triangulus) with an
Arvicola in its mouth, and two others held in two
separate coils of the body, awaiting their turn to be
swallowed. : .

Our State is very poorly supplied with lizards; but
those creatures which most resemble them, the Sala-
manders, are perhaps more numerously represented
by species than in any other country of equal area
in the world, excepting some of the Southern States.
There are eighteen species of this group (Batrachia
Urodela), most of which are small. The second in
size in the world, however (Protonopsis horrida), the
mud alligator or water-dog, occurs in the tributaries
of the Youghiogheny, and has been caught occasion-
field_edited_text_value:
- tion everywhere.

16

ZOOLOGY.







FORMATION No. 23. (TERTIARY.)

This series consists of nearly horizontal, but inter-
cepted, strata of sands and sandy clays, usually gray-
ish or bluish in color.
beds varying in thickness from a few inches to ten
or fifteen feet, made up in a great measure of marine
shells. Corals are also found among them, and in
some localities in such abundance as to indicate that
they are the remains of elevated coral reefs or
islands. : :

The tertiary groups occupy all of the western
shore south of the cretaceous, including St. Mary’s,
Charles, and Calvert, and portions of Prince George’s
and Anne Arundel counties. On the Eastern Shore
they are believed to reach from a line a little north-
west of Chester River, southward to a line running
from near the head of the Little Choptank, and east-
ward to the Delaware line. They embrace a small
portion of Kent and Dorchester, and all of Queen
Anne’s, Talbot, and Caroline.

They possess the highest agricultural interest, from
the fact that they contain the very extensive deposits
of “shell marl ” which have so largely contributed to
increase the productive value of the land of the
middle counties of the Eastern Shore.

FORMATION No. 24. (Post-TERTIARY.)

This formation embraces Worcester, Somerset,
and the greater portion of Dorchester County, and
consists of beds of loamy clays and sands, which it
is believed have not been elevated more than from
ten to thirty or forty feet above the tide-level. The
numerous islands in the Chesapeake Bay are also
post-tertiary. :

As it contains very few fossils, and perhaps none
that will serve certainly to characterize it, the name

is applied because of its position, being above the

tertiary. ‘

The character of the soil, in connection with the
circumstances under which this region seems to have
been formed, indicates that it consists of sediments
derived from the water while flowing over it from
the various formations already noticed. ~We can
detect in the soil and its subjacent beds matters that
must have come from points north and west of North
Mountain. Except in some very sandy districts, it
furnishes a mixed soil, whose fertility is readily main-
tained or improved.

ZOOLOGY.



By EDWARD D. COPE, A. M.



HE animals of Maryland are numerous in individ-
uals and varied in type. The regions of greatest
fertility are of course those most prolific of animal life,
while the warmth of our summer climate, and abun-
dance of water, furnish stimulus for its multiplica-
There are distinct regions of dis-
tribution of animals included within its limits, which
will be mentioned at the close of the essay.

SECTION I.— VERTEBRATES.

Commencing with the vertebrated animals, which
are the most conspicuous and the most useful to

~ man, we find about 693 species which are indigenous

to the State. These may be exhibited in the follow-
