In glancing over the Mammalia, it is to be ob-
served that the orders of Edentata (Ant-eaters, Sloths,
etc.) and Sirenia (Sea-Cows) are entirely wanting,
while the Quadrumana and Marsupialia are repre-
sented by but one species each, namely, Man and the
Opossum. Of the hoofed animals, only the cloven-
footed division (Artiodactyla Ruminantia) exist in a
wild state, the horses and hog-like types ( Perrisodac-
tyla and Artiodactyla Omnivora), as well as the Masto-
dons (Proboscidia), having all disappeared before the
human period.

The most conspicuous Mammals of the State are:
the panther (Felis concolor), the wild-cats (Lynx Can-
adensis and Lynx rufus), and the black bear ( Ursus
Americanus), among the Carnivora. All of these
species are not uncommon in the mountainous por-
tions. Of the Ruminants, the bison (Bos' Americanus)
and the elk (Cervus Canadensis), the largest known of
the true deer, have been destroyed by human agency.
The common deer (Cariacus Virginianus) is abundant.
Of aquatic carnivora, two species of the seal have
been seen on the coast and in the Chesapeake Bay ;
one of these, the hooded seal (Cystophora cristata), has
occurred twice in the Chesapeake.

- Whales are common off the coast. The right
whale (Balena cisarctica, Cope,) is less so than for-
merly, but may increase again, as their pursuitisnow
less vigorous. Finner whales are still more common;
a large species (Sibboldius lectirostris, Cope,) went
ashore a few years ago near Berlin, and the Sib-
boldius tuberosus (Cope), a smaller species of forty-five
feet in length, has been seen in the Chesapeake.
Other large species are seen, while the smaller forms
are more abundant. Black fish (Globiocephalus),
killers (Orca), and grampus occur. The porpoises
(Delphinus, several species, and herring-hog, Phocena)
are common on the coast and in the Chesapeake
Bay. A white whale (Beluga) is said to have been
caught in the latter, and exhibited in Baltimore.

Of the birds, the number of the group of singers
(Oscines) exceeds those of all others, though the
really superior musicians among them number but
fifteen or twenty. The most numerously represented
division, the wood-warblers ( Zanagride), are not fine
singers, which mostly belong to the thrush and
mocking-bird family. The mocking-bird finds a
congenial home in the lower lands of the State, and
may be seen in both wild and cultivated grounds.
This, with many other, especially Southern species,
find here the northern limit of their range in Mary-
land. : ;



The bobolink (Dolichonyz), of the hang-nest divi-
sion, may be trained to be almost equal to the best.
The birds of prey, especially the hawks, are very
numerous in species, while a single vulture (the
Turkey Buzzard) is extremely common.

The game species are but few, but among them
that noblest of them all, the wild turkey. Two spe-
cies of grouse and a partridge complete the list. As a
seaboard State, Maryland is permanently inhabited
by numerous species of wading-birds. Several
species of herons are common along the streams, of
which Ardea herodias (the blue heron) is the largest,
as well as the most abundant, excepting, perhaps,
the smaller Butorides virescens (Fly-up-the-Creek).
The grass-snipe, which fills the evening with its wild
whistle, represents its family in the rich meadows
throughout the whole year; the wood-cock remains
in the thickets, while the true snipe migrates to the
North in spring.

Owing to the possession of coast-line, and the
great inland bay of Chesapeake, the swimming-birds
are very numerous, especially the ZLamellirostral
forms, or geese, ducks, etc. They remain in im-
mense numbers in the bays of the coast and of the
Chesapeake Bay during part of their autumn migra-
tion southward, or until cold weather overtakes
them. Here the gunners and caterers of Baltimore
and Philadelphia betake themselves in numbers, and
with decoys, blinds, flat-boats, and all the machinery
of destruction, slaughter thousands of these birds
for the markets of their respective cities.

The red-head (Fuliz Americana), canvas-back (F.
vallisnerie), and blue-bill (F. mcwils), are most abun-
dant. The Canada goose and brant mingle in great
flocks, and a single species of swan (Cygnus Ameri
canus) is not rare, but is shy.

The wood-duck (4ix sponsa) is known throughout
the State during the year, but most of the species
enter the rivers and ponds on their southern mi-
gration. The loons remain all winter. Numerous
gulls fish in the rivers and in Chesapeake Bay.

Among the reptiles; Maryland is notable for th:
number of species of tortoises found within its
limits, exceeding in this the European list several
times. The snapping-turtle (Chelydra serpentina) is
at home here, and the box-tortoise (Cistudo clausa) is
extremely abundant. The Chelopus Muhlenbergii is
confined to the north-eastern portion of the State
and adjacent parts of New Jersey. Nearly all the
species are valuable as food, and the ¢terrapin,”
Malaclemnys palustris, Plychemys rugosa (red belly),
and the snapper, are sold in large numbers in the -
Baltimore market.
© Of the 23 species of snakes, only two are venom-
ous: these are, the copperhead (Ancistrodon con-
tortrix), found everywhere where not exterminated ;
and the common rattlesnake (Caudisona horrida),
which originally inhabited the whole country. Both
are dangerous, the rattlesnake occasionally attaining
a length of six feet; but they are both exterminated
from the best-settled regions. The remaining twenty
species, where not too small (five species might be so
reckoned), are very useful animals in destroying
mice, moles, and other vermin, and are preserved by
intelligent farmers on this account. I have taken
three meadow-mice (Arvicolz) from the stomach of
one black snake (Bascanion constrictor), and have
found a house-snake (Ophibolous triangulus) with an
Arvicola in its mouth, and two others held in two
separate coils of the body, awaiting their turn to be
swallowed. : .

Our State is very poorly supplied with lizards; but
those creatures which most resemble them, the Sala-
manders, are perhaps more numerously represented
by species than in any other country of equal area
in the world, excepting some of the Southern States.
There are eighteen species of this group (Batrachia
Urodela), most of which are small. The second in
size in the world, however (Protonopsis horrida), the
mud alligator or water-dog, occurs in the tributaries
of the Youghiogheny, and has been caught occasion-

field_edited_text_processed:
ZOOLOGY.

17



ally in those of the Susquehanna. The Anura
includes the frogs, toads, ete. There are 5 species
of the former, 1 of the latter, and 4 of tree-toads.
The Scaphiopus is subterranean, excavating its bur-
rows backward with the shovel-bearing hind-feet. It
only comes to the surface to breed, after thunder-
showers in April, and then in the evening, and is
recognized by its loud, discordant notes.

The coast furnishes an inexhaustible supply of
edible fishes, and many forms interesting to the nat-
uralist occur. Nowhere is the large “sheep’s-head”
more abundant and palatable (Archosarqus probato-
cephalus), and the mackerel (Scomber sp.) are not infe-
rior in flavor. Sea-eels are much eaten, and various
species of Scienide (‘ Weak-fish, spots”), ete., make
up the bulk of marketable fishes. The toad-fish
(Batrachus), goose-fish (Lophius), with its huge
mouth, and the slender pipe-fishes and sea-horses
(Lyngnathus and Hippocampus), attract the visitor by
their strange appearance. The largest of the perch-
like fishes is the drum (Pogonias fasciatus), which has
powerful grinding pharyngeal teeth, and is very de-
structive to the oysters.

There are at least 140 species of fresh-water fishes
in the waters of Maryland, of which 80 species are
important as food.
mac and Susquehanna, while there are 41 inhabiting
the Youghiogheny and its branches. When we re-
flect that each female of these species spawns several
thousands or hundreds of thousands of eggs in a
season, we can readily estimate the great importance
this crop might be to us as a source of cheap animal
food, were it cultivated to the extent of the capacity
of our streams. That capacity in Maryland is very
great, for it depends chiefly on the supply of food
for fishes furnished by nature. This is ultimately
derived from a strong vegetation, either directly or
through the insects which feed upon it, or the fishes
thus nourished as food for the carnivorous species.
Ultimately, then, a productive soil is as much the
condition of fish production as of any other, and
thus our State possesses, evidently, extensive ad-
vantages in this respect.

Some of these species migrate to salt water in
autumn, and remain there during the winter; others
descend the creeks to the rivers, and the rivers to
their deeper waters, and congregate in them in cold
weather; others remain all winter in their usual
haunts, burying themselves in mud, and undergoing
a kind of hibernation: while some —for example,
certain catfish—do not take even this precaution.
With a few exceptions, on the advent of spring and
the breaking up of the ice, they ascend to the upper
and clear waters, or to the gravelly bottoms, to de-
posit their spawn. The exceptions are the eels and
trout. The former descend the rivers in autumn,
and deposit their eggs in salt water; the latter spawn
in the upper waters in late autumn, prior to their
riverward migration. Of course, no fishing is per-
mitted by law during the months of spawning and
the pericd of migration. Where the fishes avoid
dams and other obstructions by fish-ways or canal-
locks, these should be especially guarded by the
Fish Commissioners’ deputics or wardens, to prevent
the wholesale destruction that can be inflicted on
them at such times.

The most valuable food-fishes in the State are
members of the herring family (Clupcide). The shad
(Alosa tyrannus) is well known to the inhabitants of
our eastern cities as the best of table-fishes. It had
been almost exterminated from the Susquehanna, but
legislation has restored it. In the Potomac itis still

abundant, but reduced, and further legislation is |

needed to protect it. The herring (Pomolobus pseudo-
harengus), or, properly, ale-wife, is immensely numer-
ous, and is caught in the Potomac and Susquehanna.
The fisheries at the mouth of the latter river supply
an extensive region. An anchovy (Engraulis vittatus)
visits Chesapeake Bay in immense numbers every
spring, and might furnish quite as large a supply of
food as the European species of the same name.

81 species exist in the Poto-,



Of the salmon family, the brook-trout (Salmo fon-
tinalis) is our best-known species. This fish, if prop-
erly protected, will always be important to the
inhabitants of the mountainous portions of our State,
where other species are less abundant. It cannot
fail to be valued, if allowed to increase sufficiently,
by that class of our people who, in those countries,
may find beef and mutton more or less expensive, or
otherwise beyond their reach. The sea salmon (S.
salar) will perhaps never be an important feature of
our fisheries. The Hudson is its southern limit of
migration, and it has been extremely rare there fora
very long period. The Delaware has rarely furnished
a specimen; and though the experiment of cultiva-
tion in our waters is certainly worth trying, the
transplanting to the Susquehanna would most likely
fail. -
The Salmonide furnish the species which are most
useful to the pisciculturist. The brook-trout (Salmo
JSontinalis) is selected as the most hardy, and its prop-
agation is already an important branch of industry.
We will, however, not speak of pisciculture. The
tributaries of the Ohio are entirely without any resi-
dent species of trout, except in a few of its highest
mountain streams.

Many of our most important fishes belong to the
perch family (Percide). The finest fishes among
these are the pike-perch (Stizostedium). The S. Ameri-
canum, or jack, sometimes called jack-salmon, or even
salmon, for flavor and general character of flesh, and
for large size, is only exceeded in value by the shad,
yet it is almost unknown to our markets, except as
an imported article from the lakes. It exists in the
Susquehanna, and ought to be so protected as to be
very abundant there. It is common in the Alle-
ghany and tributaries, and is associated with another
fine species of smaller size, the S. salmoneum, Raf.
Both these fishes ought to be cultivated. The jack
reaches, occasionally, forty pounds, and, like the
trout, seeks the highest and coolest waters that will
float him. Ie possesses great activity and strength,
and is a ravenous destroyer of perch and other spe-
cies. Were he not so superior in every way to all
others, this habit might condemn him; as it is, we
regard it as one of the best species we possess. In
the South, it is eagerly bought, and forms the prin-
cipal table-fish for the various places of resort,
springs, etc., where it can be obtained. It is sup-
plied with means of defence in its powerful teeth,
with which it will inflict wounds. Yet this large
species is almost unknown in many parts of our
State, and as a source of food is comparatively insig-
nificant. As its mode of life combine those of the
brook-trout and bass, there is no reason why some
enterprising person should not make it an object of
culture on the Susquehanna or westward. Proper
protection would also have as much effect in increas-
ing its numbers as in the case of any other species
we have.

The brackish water lovers, the yellow perch and
white and striped bass, are well known. They have
suffered great diminution of numbers from improper
spring fishing, and fishing through the ice at the
mouths of streams in winter. Both these practices
should be put a stop to, in accordance with the
law.

The black bass (Micropterus fasciatus)is only native
of our State in the tributaries of the Youghiogheny.
The public scarcely remembers its introduction into
the Potomac. The James River is the most north-
ern of the eastern rivers which contains species of
the same group (the green bass), but the introduction

of both that species and the present into the Poto- |

mac has been a success. It is a valuable acquisition,
and, though carnivorous, will not interfere mate-
rially with the spawn and fry of the ale-wives (her-
ring of our fishermen) and shad, if the latter are
protected against improper fishing. It attains a
weight of from eight to twelve pounds, and is a
good table-fish. - The “white perch,” or *“moon-
perch,” of the Potomac (Pomoxys hexacanthus), is not



less valuable than the black or green bass. An oc-
casional straggler is taken in the Delaware, and it
occurs in the Susquehanna. It is an excellent table-
fish, and ought to be protected and cultivated. Its
weight is from one to five pounds; in form it is flat
and round, like the sunfish.

The smaller sunfishes also have considerable mar-
ket value. The common species (Pomotis vulgaris)
appears, as is known, in large numbers in winter on
our stalls. The Lipomis appendix is equally abun-
dant, and would, if protected, increase to an almost
incredible extent. In the same way, the mud sun-
fish (Ambloplites pomotis, Baird), which grows to the
size of the white bass in the sluggish streams of the
tide-water region, will become at some future day a
source of food to a considerable population. In fact,
all these fishes could be easily rendered so abundant
in a few years as to sell for a cent apiece, instead of
five and ten cents per pound.

There is much difference of opinion as to the merits
of the pike, and its fitness to receive State protection.
Two species occur in the Potomac (Esox reticulatus
and . porosus), and three in the Susquehanna, (the
same with E. umbrosus.) [Those of the Youghiogheny

are scarcely worth considering, as they are few in

~number.] The K. reficulatus of the east is, on the

other hand, an abundant fish, which sells well and is
generally esteemed. For ourselves, we do not join
in the condemnation visited on the pike by some,
and have a liking for its flesh. If its increase can
be restrained, instead of favored, in waters which
produce the best species, it will cease to inflict much
injury by its voracious habits, for it naturally haunts
still or grassy waters, where it devours fishes inferior
to itself, as eels and catfish and frogs. On the whole,
we do not think the pike needs any protection, as
he has many natural advantages in the struggle
for life; but he should not be destroyed except for
the table.

Eels need no protection, as they pass around ob-
structions by land, and breed in the ocean. Their
numbers have not diminished in our waters to the
same extent as other species, and their capture and
barreling has long beenrr an important industry on
the Susquehanna. When our State is more densely
populated they will be more constantly sought, and
will require protection, as other fishes. The catfishes
of our eastern streams, now subordinate, will then
become very valuable also. : :

The fishes of the carp, sucker, and chub family
are not valued at present, though in Europe they
form a very important part of the food of the inland
population. We have already alluded to their pros-
pective importance here, and on that ground alone
they should share in the protection afforded to our
more valued species. They form, in fact, the bulk
of the piscine population of the United States, and
besides furnishing food for man and bird, form the
sustenance of the perch, bass, jack, pike, and other
carnivorous species. The American carp (Carpiodes
cyprinus), a 2-5-pound fish, is eaten along the Chesa-
peake. The other species are numerous; two come
occasionally to the Baltimore market, and others
occur all over the State. Of the whole group, nine
species are valuable as food-fishes, *but rather on
account of quantity than quality. None suffer more
from the want of protection than these fishes. They
inhabit the upper waters of all our streams, and are
cut off in thousands by every mill-dam on the many
smaller and larger creeks in the country. Their
enormous productiveness (some deposit at one time
500,000 eggs) does not make up for this in the case
of any particular stream from which they may have
been finally driven. The fish-ways, which preserve
the shad and ale-wives, will also protect these.

SECTION II. —INVERTEBRATES.

In Maryland, as elsewhere, the articulated animals
exhibit a great preponderance in number of species.
These belong in a great part to insects proper. The
Crustacea being mostly marine, have many represen-

.

mitted by law during the months of spawning and
the pericd of migration. Where the fishes avoid
dams and other obstructions by fish-ways or canal-
locks, these should be especially guarded by the
Fish Commissioners’ deputics or wardens, to prevent
the wholesale destruction that can be inflicted on
them at such times.

The most valuable food-fishes in the State are
members of the herring family (Clupcide). The shad
(Alosa tyrannus) is well known to the inhabitants of
our eastern cities as the best of table-fishes. It had
been almost exterminated from the Susquehanna, but
legislation has restored it. In the Potomac itis still

abundant, but reduced, and further legislation is |

needed to protect it. The herring (Pomolobus pseudo-
harengus), or, properly, ale-wife, is immensely numer-
ous, and is caught in the Potomac and Susquehanna.
The fisheries at the mouth of the latter river supply
an extensive region. An anchovy (Engraulis vittatus)
visits Chesapeake Bay in immense numbers every
spring, and might furnish quite as large a supply of
food as the European species of the same name.

81 species exist in the Poto-,



Of the salmon family, the brook-trout (Salmo fon-
tinalis) is our best-known species. This fish, if prop-
erly protected, will always be important to the
inhabitants of the mountainous portions of our State,
where other species are less abundant. It cannot
fail to be valued, if allowed to increase sufficiently,
by that class of our people who, in those countries,
may find beef and mutton more or less expensive, or
otherwise beyond their reach. The sea salmon (S.
salar) will perhaps never be an important feature of
our fisheries. The Hudson is its southern limit of
migration, and it has been extremely rare there fora
very long period. The Delaware has rarely furnished
a specimen; and though the experiment of cultiva-
tion in our waters is certainly worth trying, the
transplanting to the Susquehanna would most likely
fail. -
The Salmonide furnish the species which are most
useful to the pisciculturist. The brook-trout (Salmo
JSontinalis) is selected as the most hardy, and its prop-
agation is already an important branch of industry.
We will, however, not speak of pisciculture. The
tributaries of the Ohio are entirely without any resi-
dent species of trout, except in a few of its highest
mountain streams.

Many of our most important fishes belong to the
perch family (Percide). The finest fishes among
these are the pike-perch (Stizostedium). The S. Ameri-
canum, or jack, sometimes called jack-salmon, or even
salmon, for flavor and general character of flesh, and
for large size, is only exceeded in value by the shad,
yet it is almost unknown to our markets, except as
an imported article from the lakes. It exists in the
Susquehanna, and ought to be so protected as to be
very abundant there. It is common in the Alle-
ghany and tributaries, and is associated with another
fine species of smaller size, the S. salmoneum, Raf.
Both these fishes ought to be cultivated. The jack
reaches, occasionally, forty pounds, and, like the
trout, seeks the highest and coolest waters that will
float him. Ie possesses great activity and strength,
and is a ravenous destroyer of perch and other spe-
cies. Were he not so superior in every way to all
others, this habit might condemn him; as it is, we
regard it as one of the best species we possess. In
the South, it is eagerly bought, and forms the prin-
cipal table-fish for the various places of resort,
springs, etc., where it can be obtained. It is sup-
plied with means of defence in its powerful teeth,
with which it will inflict wounds. Yet this large
species is almost unknown in many parts of our
State, and as a source of food is comparatively insig-
nificant. As its mode of life combine those of the
brook-trout and bass, there is no reason why some
enterprising person should not make it an object of
culture on the Susquehanna or westward. Proper
protection would also have as much effect in increas-
ing its numbers as in the case of any other species
we have.

The brackish water lovers, the yellow perch and
white and striped bass, are well known. They have
suffered great diminution of numbers from improper
spring fishing, and fishing through the ice at the
mouths of streams in winter. Both these practices
should be put a stop to, in accordance with the
law.

The black bass (Micropterus fasciatus)is only native
of our State in the tributaries of the Youghiogheny.
The public scarcely remembers its introduction into
the Potomac. The James River is the most north-
ern of the eastern rivers which contains species of
the same group (the green bass), but the introduction

of both that species and the present into the Poto- |

mac has been a success. It is a valuable acquisition,
and, though carnivorous, will not interfere mate-
rially with the spawn and fry of the ale-wives (her-
ring of our fishermen) and shad, if the latter are
protected against improper fishing. It attains a
weight of from eight to twelve pounds, and is a
good table-fish. - The “white perch,” or *“moon-
perch,” of the Potomac (Pomoxys hexacanthus), is not



less valuable than the black or green bass. An oc-
casional straggler is taken in the Delaware, and it
occurs in the Susquehanna. It is an excellent table-
fish, and ought to be protected and cultivated. Its
weight is from one to five pounds; in form it is flat
and round, like the sunfish.

The smaller sunfishes also have considerable mar-
ket value. The common species (Pomotis vulgaris)
appears, as is known, in large numbers in winter on
our stalls. The Lipomis appendix is equally abun-
dant, and would, if protected, increase to an almost
incredible extent. In the same way, the mud sun-
fish (Ambloplites pomotis, Baird), which grows to the
size of the white bass in the sluggish streams of the
tide-water region, will become at some future day a
source of food to a considerable population. In fact,
all these fishes could be easily rendered so abundant
in a few years as to sell for a cent apiece, instead of
five and ten cents per pound.

There is much difference of opinion as to the merits
of the pike, and its fitness to receive State protection.
Two species occur in the Potomac (Esox reticulatus
and . porosus), and three in the Susquehanna, (the
same with E. umbrosus.) [Those of the Youghiogheny

are scarcely worth considering, as they are few in

~number.] The K. reficulatus of the east is, on the

other hand, an abundant fish, which sells well and is
generally esteemed. For ourselves, we do not join
in the condemnation visited on the pike by some,
and have a liking for its flesh. If its increase can
be restrained, instead of favored, in waters which
produce the best species, it will cease to inflict much
injury by its voracious habits, for it naturally haunts
still or grassy waters, where it devours fishes inferior
to itself, as eels and catfish and frogs. On the whole,
we do not think the pike needs any protection, as
he has many natural advantages in the struggle
for life; but he should not be destroyed except for
the table.

Eels need no protection, as they pass around ob-
structions by land, and breed in the ocean. Their
numbers have not diminished in our waters to the
same extent as other species, and their capture and
barreling has long beenrr an important industry on
the Susquehanna. When our State is more densely
populated they will be more constantly sought, and
will require protection, as other fishes. The catfishes
of our eastern streams, now subordinate, will then
become very valuable also. : :

The fishes of the carp, sucker, and chub family
are not valued at present, though in Europe they
form a very important part of the food of the inland
population. We have already alluded to their pros-
pective importance here, and on that ground alone
they should share in the protection afforded to our
more valued species. They form, in fact, the bulk
of the piscine population of the United States, and
besides furnishing food for man and bird, form the
sustenance of the perch, bass, jack, pike, and other
carnivorous species. The American carp (Carpiodes
cyprinus), a 2-5-pound fish, is eaten along the Chesa-
peake. The other species are numerous; two come
occasionally to the Baltimore market, and others
occur all over the State. Of the whole group, nine
species are valuable as food-fishes, *but rather on
account of quantity than quality. None suffer more
from the want of protection than these fishes. They
inhabit the upper waters of all our streams, and are
cut off in thousands by every mill-dam on the many
smaller and larger creeks in the country. Their
enormous productiveness (some deposit at one time
500,000 eggs) does not make up for this in the case
of any particular stream from which they may have
been finally driven. The fish-ways, which preserve
the shad and ale-wives, will also protect these.

SECTION II. —INVERTEBRATES.

In Maryland, as elsewhere, the articulated animals
exhibit a great preponderance in number of species.
These belong in a great part to insects proper. The
Crustacea being mostly marine, have many represen-



LD
sk

R st i o i

.

13



ZOOLOGY,



tatives; two of the crabs of the coast are sold in
greatnumbersin the Baltimore market ; the largest of
these is the Lupa diacantha, Say. Lobsters (Homarus
Americanus) are an extensive article of consumption.
No species is more abundant than the singular king-
crab (Limulus polyphemus), whose relationships appear

to be with the old forms of the coal and earlier peri--

ods of time.

The largest from fresh waters are the crawfishes
(Astacus), which abound in every stream. The little
Branchiopods occur also in the streams. Some spe-
cies are parasitic on fishes. The Isopods are repre-
sented by the very abundant ¢ wood-lice,” which are
of the very few land Crustacea. The Entomostraca
have a hinged shell, shaped like that of a muscle;
there are many minute species.

The Myriapods, or centipedes, abound. One long-
legged, short-bodied species (Cermatia forceps), is
common in out-buildings and cellars, and is very
useful in destroying insects. The active species of
the field and wood are also carnivorous (Seolopocriyp-
tops, Lithobius, et al.), and inflict sharp but harmless
bites on the finger which attacks them. The Spiro-
bolus is large and red-ringed, and exudes a pernicious
fluid, like nitro-muriatic acid; and in the same way,
the stout, short Polydesmus discharges a substance
with the smell of prussic acid.

Spiders, or Arachnida, are very abundant in spe-
cies, and many are of brilliant colors and singular
forms. Though we have no tarantula, a common
species of the same genus (Mygale) spreads over an
area of two inches in diameter with the feet. Wood-
ticks (Zzodes) are also abundant.

There are probably 25,000 species of insects in the
State. All the orders are abundantly represented,
but those which embrace the greatest number of spe-
cies are the Coleoptera, Hymenoptera, and the Lepi-
doptera ; that is, the beetles, the wasps, bees, ete.,
and the butterflies. The Neuroptera (dragon-flics,
cte.) are carnivorous, and are friends of the farmer.
Besides the numerous diurnal dragon-flies, the Chauli-
odus and Sialis, with leaf-like wings, and altogether
an ancient type, fly at night. So does the little
green Chrysopa, which has a vile smell of sulphuret-
ted hydrogen.

" We have in Maryland one termito (ZTermes flavipes),

which, though not so injurious as its congeners of
the tropics, creates havoc in gate-posts, door-steps,
dry floors, ete.

The grasshoppers (Orthoplera) sometimes increase
80 as to be injurious to the farmers, but never to the
extent seen in Western America and Asia. The
musical insects are all here. The katydid (Platy-
phyllum concavum) makes the summer woods uproar-
ious; in the fields hot with the blazing sun, other
species sing like thousands of small shuttles flying;
and the shrubberies are vocal at evening with the
musical thrill of several species of @canthus.

The list of beetles is endless, and many of them
remain unnoticed by naturalists. Many mischievous
pests belong here, which have made great havoc with
our trees and crops. Thus, of the long-horns, several
species of Saperda bore our fruit and hedge-trees to
death; the Clyfus has ruined our locust groves (Ro-
binia pscudacacia); the Oncideres girdle our hickorics;

~the Curculios sting the fruit to such an extent as to

ruin some crops entirely. Thus, plums can no longer
be raised near Philadelphia without extraordinary
protection, and cherries suffer severely. Few apples
do not contain worms. Species of Baridius bore
stems of the potato, and admit water, which causes
rot. The European grain-weevil has come over to
share the victories of his tribe.

The Phytophagous beetles are no better. The

Galeruca vittata has destroyed many elms by eating
the leaves. Other species eat our cucumbers and
cabbages. To keep down these marauders, many
carnivorous species exist. Some species of Iyiia
possess some value as blistering-flies, and one of
them (L. vitlata) eats up the potato tops. Some fif-
teen species of fire-flies spangle the evening shades,
but none of them are very large.



The wasp family is largely represented; but the
bee is rot a native of the State or Continent. Nu-
merous relatives of the wasps build nests of varied
construction, and defend them with formidable
stings. The most numerous family of the Iymenop-
tera is that of the JIehneumons, which check other in-
sect life by laying eggs in the grubs. The galls
(Cynipidee) are scarcely less abundant; their sting-
excrescences deface almost every species of wild
plant.

Ants abound, and some are of large size. But
few are injurious, though two species infest houses.
The largest of the order, species of Stizus, are com-
mon. They have stings which inflict serious wounds.
They burrow in the earth, where they lay up a store
of Cicaaz. They are called “tiger hornets.”

The Dptera, or flies, abound in blood-sucking spe-
cies, from horse- and ox-flies an inch long, to the
delicate mosquito and minute black midge. Hemip-
tera. furnishes the rattling Clcada (“locust” of the
common people), the well-armed Reduvius, and a
host of plain and gay plant-suckers. The bed-bug,
unfortunately, occurs, but is an importation from
Europe.

The Lepidoptera embrace many species of much
beauty, especially among the diurnal species; never-
theless, our region cannot claim preéminence in these
as much as in the numerous and large species of the
Saturnia and Cossus types. The former make large
cocoons of coarse silk, which can be easily cultivated,

and will probably give rise to a silk industry at a

future day. The nocturnal species, or millers, ete.,
are legion, and their work is generally unfavorable
to agriculture. Their eggs produce cut-worms,
apple - worms, ete., and multitudes of leaf-borers,
whose sinuous tracks can be seen in some leaves of
almost every native plant,

There are many species of Molluses in Maryland,
which are of course either marine, fresh-water, or
terrestrial. The first abound on the coast; the two
species of Busycon may be noted as the most striking.
In the bays, as the Sinepuxent, cte., and in the
estuary of the Chesapeake, the oyster (Ostrea Virgin-
ica) abounds, which furnishes the basis of such exten-
sive industries in Baltimore and other places. The
former are far more numerous in the tributaries of
the Youghiogheny than elsewhere, and consist mainly
of pearl muscles (Unio and Anodonta). The species
and individuals are abundant, and. of beautiful color
and lustre. They are employed in making pearl
buttons. The land or air-breathing species are, on
the other hand, Gasteropods of the Pulmonate division.
They chiefly abound in the limestone valleys of the
Alleghanies and the coal regions, on account of the
abundance of materials for constructing their spiral
shells. There are about 65 species in the State, of
which a considerable proportion would be termed
snails. Some are moderately large, but a majority
are small, many extremely so. Two species (Zeben-
nophorus) are without shell ; both are common.

The Polyzoa is a group of minute molluscs having
a common house or domicil, which extends over
stones or other objects, branching after the manner
of corals. Several species oceur in our streams and
ponds; one of them (Pectinatella magnifica) is the
largest in the world. It forms gelatinous masses
round roots or sticks, and contains hundreds of indi-
viduals. ;

The Radiate and Cewlenterate animals are marine.
The sandy shores of the coast do not produce many
sedentary species, but meduse and the Portuguese
man-of-war abound. Acres of beautiful jelly-fish
may be seen on the lower Chesapeake, which often
furnish shelter and food for a little fish beneath their
umbrella. The Hydra of fresh water is also a (-
lenterate. 1t is, in form, urn-shaped, with slender
arms and a stem-like base attached to any support in
the water. They are very simple in structure, and
lengthen their arms exceedingly in scarch of prey.
They may be cut into small pieces, when each piece
kecomes a perfect Hydra. The lowest of animals



are the Protozoa. They are unicellular, composed of
aggregated similar cells or of uniform gelatine. Into
the second class enter the sponges. A fresh-water
sponge (Spongille), whose substance is supported by
horny spicules, occurs in sluggish waters in the
Brandywine and other streams,

SECTION III.—DISTRIBUTION.

We will now take a bricf view of the relations of
the Maryland fauna to those of other regions of the
earth.

North America, of which Maryland forms a part,
embraces the Nearctic fauna. This one is more
nearly related in character to that of Europe and
North Asia (Palwarctic) than any other, though it
possesses an admixture of South American (Neotrop-
ical) life. The most remote from it in character is
the Australian fauna, then the Palwotropical (Indian),
and the African is a little nearer. The Nearctic
Jauna is distinguished by its natural productions into
the Fastern district (to the plains), the Middle (to the
Sierra Nevada), the Pacific (the western coast), and
the Sonoran, which includes Arizona, Sonora, and
part of Lower California. The Eastern district is
characterized, among other points, by the abundance
of tortoises and poverty in lizards, as seen above; by
the presence of bony gars (Lepidosteus), pike (Esox),
and Nematognathi (catfishes). In the broad sense, the
life of the district is characterized by the presence
of some ancient forms of life, which have passed
away in prior geologic epochs, though the Neotrop-
ical and Australian fauna possess a still larger portion
of such. Thus, the snapping-tortoise and the Profo-
nopsis have fossil representatives in some strata of
Europe, and the extinct relatives of the bony gar
abound in still older rocks.

Another proportion of types may be considered
Neotropical (South American) in character. Such are
among Mammals, the opossum and the wood-mice
(Hesperomys); among Birds, the Tyrannide (king-
bird, pewees, etc.), the humming-birds (Zrochilus),
and the tanagers (Pyranga); among the Fishes, the
Nematognathi may be mentioned. Of especial North
American character may be enumerated the raccoon
(Procyon), the skunks (Mephitis), and the lesser deer
(Cariacus); also the American porcupine (Lirethizon).
Among birds, the turkey and the wood-warblers
(Dendreeca) belong especially to the Nearctic fuuna.
Among reptiles, the rattlesnakes and copperheads,
the whole of the salamanders except two species, and
especially the Protonopsis and Necturus, are especially
North American. Of this character, among the

. fishes, are the gar, dog-fish, pike, and Etheostomine

perch, an extensive group of small fishes without
swim-bladders, found in all streams.

There are certain climatal divisions of the fauna
of the Eastern district of North America, regulated
by the elevation of the surface, the latitude, temper-
ature, ete. These have been named the Floridian,
the Louisianian, the Carolinian, the Alleghanion, the
Canadian, the Hudsonian, ete. Maryland is traversed
by the Carolinian, the Alleghanian, and the Cana-
dian, and their boundaries separate the breeding-
places of various species of birds, and range of others,
of mammals, ete.

The greater part of the area of the State, that s,
the low countries from the ocean to the Potomac and
to the line extending from Wilmington to Baltimoroe
and to Washington, D. C., is the especial range
of the mocking-bird, the blue grossbeak, the summer
red-bird (Lyranga wstiva), and others. Also of the
pine meadow-mouse (Arvicola pinetorum), ete.

The middle part of the State is occupied by the
Alleghanian fauna, which extends north and south.
The higher ridges of the Alleghany Mountains are
included in the Canadian, as indicated by the breed-
ing of the snow-bird, various warblers, and the range
of some land animals. This fauna extends along the
mountains to Georgia. Our State, then, presents a
fine and prolific ficld to the student of Biological
Science.

are small, many extremely so. Two species (Zeben-
nophorus) are without shell ; both are common.

The Polyzoa is a group of minute molluscs having
a common house or domicil, which extends over
stones or other objects, branching after the manner
of corals. Several species oceur in our streams and
ponds; one of them (Pectinatella magnifica) is the
largest in the world. It forms gelatinous masses
round roots or sticks, and contains hundreds of indi-
viduals. ;

The Radiate and Cewlenterate animals are marine.
The sandy shores of the coast do not produce many
sedentary species, but meduse and the Portuguese
man-of-war abound. Acres of beautiful jelly-fish
may be seen on the lower Chesapeake, which often
furnish shelter and food for a little fish beneath their
umbrella. The Hydra of fresh water is also a (-
lenterate. 1t is, in form, urn-shaped, with slender
arms and a stem-like base attached to any support in
the water. They are very simple in structure, and
lengthen their arms exceedingly in scarch of prey.
They may be cut into small pieces, when each piece
kecomes a perfect Hydra. The lowest of animals



are the Protozoa. They are unicellular, composed of
aggregated similar cells or of uniform gelatine. Into
the second class enter the sponges. A fresh-water
sponge (Spongille), whose substance is supported by
horny spicules, occurs in sluggish waters in the
Brandywine and other streams,

SECTION III.—DISTRIBUTION.

We will now take a bricf view of the relations of
the Maryland fauna to those of other regions of the
earth.

North America, of which Maryland forms a part,
embraces the Nearctic fauna. This one is more
nearly related in character to that of Europe and
North Asia (Palwarctic) than any other, though it
possesses an admixture of South American (Neotrop-
ical) life. The most remote from it in character is
the Australian fauna, then the Palwotropical (Indian),
and the African is a little nearer. The Nearctic
Jauna is distinguished by its natural productions into
the Fastern district (to the plains), the Middle (to the
Sierra Nevada), the Pacific (the western coast), and
the Sonoran, which includes Arizona, Sonora, and
part of Lower California. The Eastern district is
characterized, among other points, by the abundance
of tortoises and poverty in lizards, as seen above; by
the presence of bony gars (Lepidosteus), pike (Esox),
and Nematognathi (catfishes). In the broad sense, the
life of the district is characterized by the presence
of some ancient forms of life, which have passed
away in prior geologic epochs, though the Neotrop-
ical and Australian fauna possess a still larger portion
of such. Thus, the snapping-tortoise and the Profo-
nopsis have fossil representatives in some strata of
Europe, and the extinct relatives of the bony gar
abound in still older rocks.

Another proportion of types may be considered
Neotropical (South American) in character. Such are
among Mammals, the opossum and the wood-mice
(Hesperomys); among Birds, the Tyrannide (king-
bird, pewees, etc.), the humming-birds (Zrochilus),
and the tanagers (Pyranga); among the Fishes, the
Nematognathi may be mentioned. Of especial North
American character may be enumerated the raccoon
(Procyon), the skunks (Mephitis), and the lesser deer
(Cariacus); also the American porcupine (Lirethizon).
Among birds, the turkey and the wood-warblers
(Dendreeca) belong especially to the Nearctic fuuna.
Among reptiles, the rattlesnakes and copperheads,
the whole of the salamanders except two species, and
especially the Protonopsis and Necturus, are especially
North American. Of this character, among the

. fishes, are the gar, dog-fish, pike, and Etheostomine

perch, an extensive group of small fishes without
swim-bladders, found in all streams.

There are certain climatal divisions of the fauna
of the Eastern district of North America, regulated
by the elevation of the surface, the latitude, temper-
ature, ete. These have been named the Floridian,
the Louisianian, the Carolinian, the Alleghanion, the
Canadian, the Hudsonian, ete. Maryland is traversed
by the Carolinian, the Alleghanian, and the Cana-
dian, and their boundaries separate the breeding-
places of various species of birds, and range of others,
of mammals, ete.

The greater part of the area of the State, that s,
the low countries from the ocean to the Potomac and
to the line extending from Wilmington to Baltimoroe
and to Washington, D. C., is the especial range
of the mocking-bird, the blue grossbeak, the summer
red-bird (Lyranga wstiva), and others. Also of the
pine meadow-mouse (Arvicola pinetorum), ete.

The middle part of the State is occupied by the
Alleghanian fauna, which extends north and south.
The higher ridges of the Alleghany Mountains are
included in the Canadian, as indicated by the breed-
ing of the snow-bird, various warblers, and the range
of some land animals. This fauna extends along the
mountains to Georgia. Our State, then, presents a
fine and prolific ficld to the student of Biological
Science.

field_edited_text_processed:
CLIMATOLOGY.

19



THE CLIMATE OF MARYLAND.

—_————

By LORIN BLODGET,
AUTHOR OF “AMERICAN CLIMATOLOGY,” ETC.

THE configuration of Maryland is very variable,
giving a wide tract nearly at sea-level in the
east and south, a moderately rolling district occupy-
ing the central part of the State, and a sharply cle-
vated mountainous belt crossing the summits of the
Alleghanies in the west. The climate has, therefore,
a wide range, from the soft maritime air of the At-
lantic coast, along the eastern shore, to the compara-
tively cold and severe atmosphere of the mountain
counties. The south-eastern extremity of the State
has the broad Chesapeake Bay to moderate its ex-
tremes,-as well as the Atlantic coast and the not
remote Gulf Stream. It is, therefore, much like
Norfolk and the Carolina coasts, and but little be-
yond the range of the live-oak and the cotton- and
rice-fields. Yet none of these are quite successful
within its limits. The summer heats of the interior
are greatly tempered here, and in many respects the
climate is delightful. Inland, and on leaving the
shores of the Chesapeake Bay, the extremes of heat
and cold alike are greater, and such as generally
belong to the latitude. Altogether, Maryland has a
climate sensibly warmer and softer than the average
of the States of the Atlantic coast.

In the central part of the State the range of single
extremes is great, and may be stated at 10° below
zero for the lowest, and 100° above for the greatest
heats of summer. In the country about Baltimore
and Washington such is the range : extremes ot 100°
in summer have been several times recorded, one
such instance occurring in June, 1853 ; while records
of 95° to 98° are quite frequent, and may be ex-
pected every summer. These extremes are not
greater, however, than is every year experienced as
far north as New England, though a greater number
of hot days will be observed in Maryland. During
these heats the atmosphere is usually more dry and
clastic than further north. As to cold extremes,
observations as low as 10° below zero have been re-
corded at Washington, and sometimes a period of
continuous cold occurs, covering the ground with
snow for two or three months. 1In 1856-7 such se-
verity prevailed from January to March, the use of
sleighs being constant at Washington and Baltimore.
Ice formed to the depth of twelve or fifteen inches
on the Potomac River, and on the shallow arms of
Chesapeake Bay. DBut such severity is rare, and

“may be expected only at intervals of about twenty-
five years. Generally, the winters are open and
mild, without much snow, and with very little ice.
A larger share of fair weather prevails at this season
than in any States northward.

The average temperature for the year at Balti-
more is 54°, being three degrees warmer than New
York city, and one and a half degrees warmer than
Philadelphia. The isothermal lines recede much on
the mountains, however, while they advance to but

little higher figures in the maritime districts. The
summer mean at Baltimore is 75°, being two and a
half degrees warmer than New York, and one degree
warmer than Philadelphia. The winter average is
34° at Baltimore, being two and a half degrees
warmer than New York, and nearly one and a half
degrees warmer than Philadelphia. In the extreme
southeast the winter average rises five degrees higher,
being nearly as warm as Norfolk, which is 40° for
the winter. At Crisfield, Snow Hill, and Salisbury,
this mild winter climate is conspicuous, as also in
St. Mary’s County, west of the Bay. At Frederick,
in the western central part of the State, the climate
is that of Philadelphia, very nearly. Further west,
and among the mountain valleys, the averages are
nearly those of Pittsburgh, though colder in the
higher districts. No records exist for these more

-



elevated localities : they are identical in -climate, as
in configuration, with the mountains of Pennsylvania
and Virginia.

The quantity of rain falling on the eastern shore,
within the cooling influence of the Atlantic, is only
about 42 inches; but inland, and along the borders
of Chesapeake Bay, the quantity rises to 46 inches
nearly. Rains are here conspicuous for the quantity
falling in single storms, though no greater number
of storms or proportion of cloudy weather exists,
than in other districts where a less aggregate depth
falls. In the range from Baltimore to Washington

the quantity falhng is about 44 inches. Then it falls

off to 42 inches, and again to 40 on the eastern slope
of the mountains, with but 38 in the higher localities.
Nearer the Ohio River the quantity increases again,
but this is beyond the boundary of Maryland.

Great as is the quantity of rain falling, the atmos-
phere is free from excessive humidity or great sen-
sible saturation. The proportion of fair and fine
weather is large at all seasons, probably one-third
to one-half greater than in the latitude of New York.
The increase in aggregate depth of rain is due to the
great quantities falling in single storms. These
heavy rains cause frequent floods in the streams and
rivers of the State, particularly in spring and early
summer. The range in the quantity of water falling
in a single month may be from a mere fraction of
an inch to sixteen inches; and in extreme years the
quantity for one year may amount to twice as much
as falls in a dry year.

As has been said, however, the atmosphere is not
saturated or unhealthy from this large rain-fall. The
general climate is bracing and healthy; the low and
marshy borders of the Bay and of the streams of
the east afford local malaria, but not of a severe or
dangerous character. Nor is the State liable to
dangerous fevers, or other diseases of tropical cli-
mates.

The following tabular statements illustrate the
averages of temperature and of the quantity of rain
falling in Maryland, within a reasonably near ap-
proximation, yet they are not as full as they should
be, and need to be supplemented by observations
taken within the limits of other States. The aver-
ages of temperature are relatively more full, and the
determinations more exact than those of the quantity
of rain. The range in extreme years is not so great
as to obscure the result, even if a very limited period
is embraced; while with observations of the quan-
tity of rain, the range in extreme years is such as to
render positive determinations difficult with less
than twenty years of continuous observation. There
is also frequent deficiency in the quantity recorded,
the excess in heavy rains not being all included, and
snow not being melted, or estimated for. The po-
sition of the instruments must also be carefully
adjusted, to make the record full. The records at
the military post at Baltimore, and all the stations
at Washington, are probably deficient in quantity.

The great range in temperature between extreme
months or seasons may be illustrated by citations
from the record at Fort McHenry, Baltimore, where
we have twenty-nine years of continuous observa-
tion, 1831 to 1859.

the coldest summers in 1836, 1840, 1842, and 1846.
The coldest years were 1836, 1840, 1841, and 1843.

The tables of quantity of rain cannot be so well

For twenty-four years of observation at Baltimore,

Baltimore, Fort McHenry, and Fort Washington (when marked Ft. W.)

At any place in valleys or on plains in this State,
away from large bodies of water, the temperature
may fall to zero in the average of winters, and in
upper Maryland to 10° below zero. And in similar
localities the summer maximum may rise to 100° in
extreme seasons, and to 96° in the average of years.
The greatest heats recorded are 103° and 105°, in
the narrow valley of the site of Ft. Washington.

EDUCATION.



22
EDUCATION. this province, which has succeeded with such de- | aggrieved party; and the tax before‘mentioned, im-
s sired effect, that it is now thought necessary and is | posed on ¢Irish servants being Papists,” was con-

HE interest manifested by the people of Mary-
land with regard to education dates back to Co-
lonial times. The first general free-school law was a
- petitionary Act, passed in 1696, of which the first
section reads as follows: “ And may it be enacted
by the King’s most excellent majesty, by and with
the advice, prayer, and consent of this present Gen-
eral Assembly, and the authority of the same, that
for the propagation of the gospel and the education
of the youth of this province in good letters and
manners, that a certain place or places for a free
- school or schools, or place of study of Latin, Greek,
Writing, and the like, consisting of one master, one
usher, and one writing-master or scribe to a school

and one hundred scholars, more or less, according to

the ability of the said free school, may be made,
erected, founded, propagated, and established, under
your royal patronage. And that the most reverend
father in God, Thomas, by Divine Providence Arch-
bishop of Canterbury, primate and Metropolitan of
all England, may be chancellor of the said schools;
and that, to perpetuate the memory of your Majesty,
it may be called King William’s School, etc., ete.”
(This school is still in existence under the name of
St. John’s College.) The Act goes on to provide
~ that as soon as the income of King William’s School
“amounts to one hundred and twenty pounds sterling
per annum, the trustees shall proceed to erect a
gecond free school “at the town of Oxford, on the
eastern shore of this province.” ¢“And also, after
~ the second free school is built, erected, founded, and
furnished, the said rectors, governors, and visitors
shall, as fast as they shall be enabled as aforesaid,
proceed to the erecting of other and more free
schools in this province; that is to say, in every

prayed that it may be enacted, etc., etc.” The law
goes on to enact that a free school shall be estab-
lished in each county, under the superintendence
and control of what we may call a “State Board of
Education,” the members of which are specified by
name in the Act. This Board is required to meet
four times a year, at least; and, among other things,
they are directed to ¢ take all proper methods for the
encouraging good schoolmasters that shall be mem-
bers of the Church of England, and of pious and
exemplary lives and conversations, and capable of
teaching well the grammar, good writing, and the
mathematics, if such can conveniently be got, and
that they allow every such master for his encourage-
ment for the present (besides the benefit and use of
his plantation) [fifty acres], the sum of twenty pounds
per annum.” Under this Act several schools were
established, some of which survive to the present
day; but the funds allowed by law were too small
and too uncertain to produce anything like a general
free-school system. Among other sources of income
we find that clerks not writing a legible hand are to
pay 2,000 1bs. of tobacco, one-half to go to the free-
school fund; the owner of hogs running at large is
to pay 100 lbs. of tobacco to the pubhc schools;
the owner of geese running at large is to pay ten
shillings to the school fund; the fine for sell-
ing liquor within three miles of Friends’ Yearly
Meeting is five pounds, of which one-half is to go
to the public schools; the fine for harboring slaves
is 100 1bs. of tobacco per hour, one-half to be given
to the public schools, and the other half to the

\



tinued (at least on the statute book) till near the
Revolution.

The Revolutionary War proved a serious obstacle
to the progress of education. At its close, many of
the county academies began to show symptoms of
decay; and before the end of the eighteenth cen-
tury, the free-school fund in several counties was
transferred to the commissioners of the poor. Up
to the year 1865, no general system of free schools
was in operation, though every county had a system
(more or less efficient) of its own, supported to a
very limited extent by a State Fund, but mainly by
local taxation. In 1865, the present system, of which
Maryland is justly proud, was inaugurated upon the
basis of the grand principle that the property of the
State shall be held responsible for the education of
the children of the State.

Among many noble men to whose exertions the -
people of Maryland owe this great triumph, two
may be named as most conspicuous— Joseph M.
Cushing, Chairman of the Committee of Education
in the Constitutional Convention of 1864, and Li-
bertus Van Bokkelen, first State Superintendent of
Public Instruction. Three successive legislatures
have made many changes in the original school law,
but the main features are still preserved, — < Educa-
tion absolutely free, and an open highway in which

- who will may walk from the Primary School to the

University.” The last change of importance was
made in 1872, and placed the schools for colored
children on the same footing and under the same
regulations as schools for white children.

















COLLEGES.

BATLWAYS AND UANALS

23



RAILWAYS AND CANALS.

———0-0 @ 00——

N 1784 a company was formed for the purpose of
constructing a canal from the Pennsylvania line,
along the Susquehanna to tide-water, and incor-
porated under the name of ¢ The Proprietors of
the Susquehanna Canal.”

To render the Potomac River navigable, ¢ The
Potomaec Company ” was formed in the same year,
and General Washington was chosen its first presi-
dent. So deep was the interest which he took in
this great design, that he assisted in the survey of
the river in person. It was then supposed that the
Potomac could be rendered navigable by locks and
dams and short canals, and the works for this pur-
pose were very soon undertaken; but experience
proved the fallacy of the idea. When the Potomac
Company was subsequently merged in the Chesa-
peake and Ohio Canal Co., these works were
abandoned, and a more comprehensive plan adopted,
that a more speedy and reliable means of communi-
cation might be had with the rich iron mines and
inexhaustible supply of coal contained in the moun-
tains of Western Maryland.

At a convention of delegates, from different
counties in Maryland, Virginia, and Pennsylvania,
held in Washington, Nov. 6, 18238, it was resolved
to form a company to construct a canal from
Georgetown, D. C., by Cumberland, to the coal
banks on the eastern side of the Alleghanies, and
thence to the highest point of navigation on the
Ohio or Monongahela.

The Ohio and Chesapeake Canal Co. was incor-
porated by act of the Legislature of Virginia, Jan.
27, 1824, and the charter was accepted by the stock-
holders, and the company formally organized in
June, 1828, and the work of construction com-
menced the same year. The canal was completed
in 1845, and is for the greater part from sixty to
seventy feet wide and six feet deep. The rise in a
distance of one hundred and five miles, from
Geprgetown to Williamsport, is three hundred and
fifty-three feet, which is overcome by forty-four
locks, one hundred feet long, by fifteen feet wide.
There are in this distance one hundred and nine-
teen culverts and six aqueducts, all built in the
most substantial manner, of solid stone masonry.

Maryland, looking to the interests of its com-
mercial metropolis, claimed and obtained the right
of constructing, through any portion of the District
of Columbia, a lateral canal, to terminate at the
city of Baltimore, and further insisted upon the
power, and maintained the expediency of the gen-
eral Government’s fostering this great national work
and aiding in its completion.

Owing to doubts of the feasibility of constructing
the lateral canal, and the evident necessity of open-
ing a more direct and speedy means of communi-
cation, the people of Baltimore, at an early day,
determined upon the construction of a railroad to
the waters of the Ohio. In February, 1827, a public
meeting was called in the city, and a memorial pre-
ferred at once to the Legislature. It was asserted
that the route of the railroad was the only practicable
one, that it was shorter by one hundred and forty
miles than the proposed canal, and that it could be
opened at an expense less by seven millions of
dollars. In ten days after the application, a charter
was granted by the Legislature.

The Annaroris ANp Erx Ripge RarLroaD, ex-
tending from Annapolis to Annapolis Junction, —
a point on the Washington branch of the Baltimore
and Obhio Railroad, —was completed in the year
1840, its length being 22:51 miles. For the
promotion of this enterprise, the State subscribed
the sum of $300,000 in bonds, of which $219,378
were issued. As a paying investment, this road
has not been a success, as it has probably never
earned more than would cover its operating ex-
penses,



The BaLriMore AND DruM Poixt RAILROAD, now
in course of construction, is to extend from Balti-
more in a southerly direction to Drum Point, in
Calvert County, a distance of about seventy miles.

The BarrimorE AND Onro Rarnroap CoMpANY was
incorporated in the State of Maryland, on the 28th
of February, 1827, with authority to construct a
railroad from Baltimore to some eligible point on
the Ohio River. With a capital of $5,000,000, and
the required subscription being raised, which was
one-fifth of that amount, the Company was organized
in the following April. After a satisfactory report
of the surveys, the construction was commenced,
and the ground broken at Baltimore on the 4th of
July, 1828. In a short time the first section of the
road, extending to Ellicott’s Mills, a distance of
fourteen miles, was put under contract, and com-
pleted in 1830. In this same year there was a sec-
tion of the road constructed within the city limits.

The year 1832 found the road extended to the
Point of Rocks, a distance of eight miles. In 1833
the work of construction was suspended, and no
additional mileage was added; but in the following
year it was again resumed, and the route extended
beyond the Point of Rocks, a distance of twelve
miles, to Harper’s Ferry.

In 1836 surveys were made for the extension of
the main road to Cumberland and Wheeling, for
which purpose $3,200,000 were subsequently sub-
scribed by the State.

At an early period in the history of the Company,
permission had been obtained from Virginia for the
location of the road through a portion of its terri-
tory. The time having elapsed in which the road
was to have been constructed, an act was passed,
1838, extending the time to five years, and requiring
the Company to locate within the State, with the
exception of five miles, —its road from Harper’s
Ferry to Cumberland. This act also designated the
city of Wheeling as the western terminus of thé
road. At the same time the State made a sub-
scription to the capital stock of the Company to the
amount of $1,058,420, being one-fifth of the esti-
mated cost of the road within its limits.

This act was accepted by the Company, and the
line to Cumberland, a distance of ninety - seven
miles, was placed under countract, and completed
in November, 1842,

No progress had been made in the construction
of the road beyond Cumberland from 1842 to 1847,
as the authority granted by the State of Virginia
had again expired. In 1847, an extension of time
was again obtained. In 1849, the means for re-
suming the work were provided, by the negotiation
of the bonds of the State granted to the Company.
From that date the work progressed rapidly, and in
1851 the road was extended from Cumberland to
Piedmont, a distance of twenty-eight miles; in
1852, from Piedmont to Fairmont, ninety-six miles;
and in the year 1853 the whole line of the road from
Baltimore to Wheeling, 1 distance of three hundred
and cighty miles, was opened to public use.

The BarriMore AND Poromac RATLROAD was char-
tered by the Maryland Legislature, May 6, 1853, to
extend from some point in or near the city of Bal-
timore, to a point on the Potomac River, to be
selected by the President and Directors of said
Company, not higher than Liverpool Point, and not
lower than St. Mary’s River, with such branches at
any point on said Railroad, not exceeding twenty
miles in length, as the said President and Directors
may determine.

The terminating points are Baltimore and Pope’s
Creek, on the Potomac River. The distance from
the Calvert Street Station, Baltimore, to Pope’s
Creek, is 74:20 miles.

Its Washington branch leaves the main stem at
Bowie, Prince George’s County, Md., 2552 miles
from Calvert Street Station, Baltimore, and ter-
minates near the capitol in Washington, a distance
of 17-08 miles.



Both cities are entered by tunnels; that in Balti-
more being nearly a mile and a half in length, and
costing over a million and a half of dollars.

Scarcely anything was done under the charter,
except a survey by Gen. Trimble, until late in 1860,
when its present president was elected a director,
and subsequently president. Ie at once addressed
himself with encrgy to the building of the road.

In the spring of 1861 contracts were made for
building the lower portion of the line to the An-
napolis and Elk Ridge Railroad, putting southern
Maryland in connection with Baltimore by rail, over
the Annapolis and Elk Ridge, and Washington
Branch of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad; but
the breaking out of the war precluded any work
being accomplished.

The war being over, the project was revived, and,
notwithstanding the violent and powerful opposition .
of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad Co., the entire
line has been built, and is now in successful opera-
tion. It has been constructed of the very best
material, of the heaviest iron, and the largest oak-
ties, and its equipment is of the first character.

It was opened for travel between Baltimore and
Washington the second day of July, 1872, with six
passenger trains each way daily, and is doing a
good business from Lafayette, one of its suburban
Baltimore stations, to its depot in Washington.
The tunnel will be completed by April, 1873, when
trains will run, not only into the very centre of
Baltimore, but, through travel east and west, north
and south, will be transported through and under the
city by steam, without any delay or change of cars.

The CoLumpia aANp Port DEPostT RAILROAD is in
process of construction, and will extend, when
completed, along the left bank of the Susquehanna
River, from Port Deposit, Md., to Columbia, Pa., a
distance of 89,3 miles, 10 8 being in Maryland, and
28% in Pennsylvania.

About five miles of the main track have been
completed, forming a connection from the present
southern terminus of the Philadelphia and Balti-
more Central Railroad, at the mouth of the Octo-
rora Creek, and the Philadelphia, Wilmington, and
Baltimore Branch from Perrysville to Port Deposit,
and is operated by the P., W., & B. RR. Co. The
entire line, it is expected, will be open for traffic in
the fall of 1873, and, when completed, will form
another great outlet for coal, running direct to tide-
water, with all grades favorable for the loaded
trains.

The CuMBERLAND AND PENNSYLVANIA RAILROAD
was chartered on the 138th of March, 1850, and ex-
tends from Cumberland, Md., to Piedmont, W.
Va., a distance of thirty-four miles.

The lateral lines are Eckhart Branch, 14 miles;
Neff Run, Midlothian, Consolidation, and Furnace
branches, each 1} to 1} miles in length. Also,
Branch Line, 2} miles from Krugbaum’s (4 miles
from Cumberland) to Pennsylvania State line,
where it will join the Bedford and Bridgeport
Road, which in turn connects with the Huntingdon
and Broad Top Road, terminating at Huntingdon,
on the Pennsylvania Central Road.

The Cumberland and Pennsylvania Road was
built from Cumberland to Mt. Savage in 1844, to
Frostburg in 1852, and in 1857 to Lonaconing. In
1863 the George’s Creek Road, running from Lona-
coning to Piedmont, W. Va., was purchased, thus
completing the line throughout the centre of the
Cumberland coal-field, a distance of thirty-four
miles.

The CuMBERLAND VALLEY RAILROAD extends from
Hagerstown to Harrisburg, Pa., a distance of sev-
enty-four miles; only 575 of it lying within the
State of Maryland. This road was chartered on
the 2d of April, 1831. The work of construction
commenced in January, 1836, and the road was
completed from Chambersburg to the Susquehanna
River opposite Harrisburg, in December, 1887, a
distance of forty-nine miles.

field_edited_text_processed:
24

RATILWAYS AND CANALS



By an act of the Legislature, approved on the 2d
of February, 1836, the Company was empowered to
construct a bridge across the Susquehanna (4,400
feet), and extend the road through Marrisburg to
the Pennsylvania Canal, about three miles beyond
the then eastern terminus, and also to connect with
other roads centring at Harrisburg. 7his was the
original Cumberland Valley Road. That portion
from Chambersburg to Hagerstown was originally
known as the Franklin Railroad.

This company was chartered in Pennsylvania, on
the 12th of March, 1832, and in Maryland in the
same year, and was authorized to construct.a road
in continuation of the Cumberland Valley Railroad
from Chambersburg to Hagerstown. The road was
built in 1838, and after changing owners several
times, finally came into the hands of the Cumber-
land Valley Road, by which it is now operated.

The DorcHESTER AND DELAWARE RAILROAD runs
from Cambridge, Md., to Seaford, Del., a distance
of thirty-three miles, 5% miles of which are in the
State of Delaware, and was built by the - Philadel-
phia, Wilmington, and Baltimore Railroad Com-
pany, and leased to the Dorchester and Delaware
Railroad Company.

The D. & D. RR. Co. owns two locomotives, and
hires the other rolling-stock from the P., W., & B.
RR. Co.

The first work on this road was commenced Oc-
tober 23, 1867, and on November 8, 1869, it was
opened for passengers and freight.

Seaford, the eastern terminus, is on the Delaware
Railroad Line, and Cambridge, the western termi-
nus, is on the south side of the Choptank River,
twenty miles from its entrance into the Chesapeake
Bay, and is the county-seat of Dorchester County.
Steamers to and from Baltimore connect with the
road at this point.

The EasteEry SHORE RAILROAD was chartered by
the Maryland Legislature in the year 1853, and the
company organized February 22d, 1859.

The road from Salisbury to Crisfield was built by
George A. Parker, of Boston, Mass., under one con-
tract, the work being commenced in August, 1865.
In March, 1866, the road was opened for business to
Princess Anne, and in October of the same year
‘was opened to its terminus at Crisfield.

The entire length of the road from Crisfield to
Delmar, a point on the dividing-line between the
States of Maryland and Delaware, is thirty-eight
miles; and at this point it becomes continuous with
the Delaware Railroad.

The Eastern Shore Railroad hasseveral important
connections, two of which are already completed,
and another projected. The Wicomico and Poco-
moke Railroad connects with it at Salisbury; the
‘Worcester Railroad being connected by means of
the Wicomico and Pocomoke. These roads traverse
a rich and prosperous section of country, making
them very important tributaries to the Eastern Shore
Railroad ; the length of the two roads being about
thirty-seven miles. '

The next important branch is the one leading
from near Princess Anne to Newtown, a distance
of nine miles. This road, just completed, may some
day be continued, extending through the Eastern
Shore counties in Virginia, of Accomac and North-
ampton.

The Eastern Shore Railroad, with proposed ex-
tensions, is, geographically, the most direct air-line
route between the North and the South. The dis-
tance from Crisfield to Norfolk, Va., by actual survey,
is eighty-four miles, connecting at Norfolk with the
Seaboard and Roanoke Railroad, and thence to
Charleston, S. C., and other points South. The dis-
tance between Charleston and New York can be
made, over this route, about six hours quicker than
by any other.

The projected connections are, (1.) The railroad to
extend from West Point, on the York River, Va,
to Pionkatank on the Chesapeake Bay, thence by



steam thirty-five miles to Crisfield; (2.) The Wash-
ington and Point Lookout Railroad, from Washing-
ton, D. C., to the mouth of the Potomac River at
Point Lookout, in St. Mary’s County, Md., which
road is now partly built, and is expected soon to be
finished ; thence by steamer to Crisfield, a distance
of thirty miles; and (3.) The Baltimore and Drum
Point Railroad, extending from that point to Balti-
more, and connecting by steamer from Drum Point
to Cristield, a distance of forty-five miles.

The grades of the Eastern Shore Railroad are re-
markably easy, and its direction nearly an air-line.
At Delmar, its northern terminus, it is thirty-two fect
above tide-water; at Salisbury, twenty-six; Princess
Anne, fourteen; Kingston, twelve; Crisfield, its
southern terminus, four —making twenty-eight feet
in thirty-eight miles. The road is in a prosperous
condition, and its business steadily increasing, and is
surely destined to become a most important connect-
ing-link between the Atlantic seaboard section of the
South and the great cities of the North.

The KrxT CouNTY RAILROAD Was commenced in

Roads to a point five miles beyond Chestertown,
near Belle Air, a distance of twenty-five miles.

There is a branch or lateral road, five-eighths of a
mile long, from the depot in the precincts of Ches-
tertown to Chester River. At the terminus on the
river a fine substantial wharf has been erected. The
direction through which the road passes is one of the
finest agricultural sections in the country. It is in
contemplation to extend the road from Belle Air to
some point on the Chesapeake Bay, from which a
steamer can run to Baltimore in 1§ hours.

In 1868, the Legislature of Maryland authorized

sey’s Cross Roads to the Delaware line, and the Del-
aware Legislature authorized the same company to
construct a road from some point on the Delaware
TRailroad to meet the proposed road from Massey’s.
In 1869 they constructed this road from Townsend, on
the Delaware Road to Massey’s Cross Roads in
Maryland. Thisis known as the Townsend Branch,
and is ten miles long.

There is a railroad from Massey’s Cross Roads
through Millington, in Kent, and through Queen
Anne County to Centreville, about twenty miles in
length, called the QuEEN ANNE AND KENT RATLROAD.
This road and the Kent County Railroad lease the
Townsend Branch,and thus have direct connections,
through the Declaware Railroad, with all the main
lines. :

About 9,000 passengers travelled over the Kent
County Railroad in 1871. The businessisimproving,
and, if the Bay connections are made, will increase
still more. A telegraph is being constructed along
the line.

authorized to construct a road from Clayton, on the
Delaware Railroad, to Oxford, on the Choptank, an
arm of the Chesapeake Bay, a distance of fifty-four

27th of December, 1857, and was completed, with

At its terminus on the Chesapeake Bay there is a

known as the Franklin Railroad.

in continuation of the Cumberland Valley Railroad
from Chambersburg to Hagerstown. The road was
built in 1838, and after changing owners several
times, finally came into the hands of the Cumber-
land Valley Road, by which it is now operated.

land and Delaware Road was completed. In 1838,

The PrrrspvrcH, WASHINGTON AND DBALTIMORE
Ramuroap CompaNy was chartered on the 3d of
April, 1837, under the name of the Pittsburgh and
Connellsville Railroad Company, with authority to
construct a road from Pittsburgh by the course of
the Monongahela and Youghiogheny rivers to some
suitable point at or near Connellsville. The charter
having lapsed, was revived by an Act passed on the
18th of April, 18438, and the company authorized to
extend their road beyond Connellsville to Smithfield
or any other point on the waters of the Youghi-
ogheny. In January, 1853, the company obtained a
charter from the State of Maryland, which conferred
authority for the extension of the road into that
State as far as Cumberland.

The necessary surveys were commenced on the
20th of July, 1853, and the contract for the work on
the division between West Newton and Connells-
ville, twenty-five miles, was given out on the 22d of
March, 1854. This portion of the road was com-
pleted and opened for business on the 13th of Sep-
tember, 1855. On the 26th of April of the same
year, that portion of the first division of the road,
between West Newton and Turtle Creek, was con-
tracted for, and the work immediately thereafter com-
menced ; and in the spring of 1856, the contract was
given out for the tunnel at Sand Patch Summit.



On the 10th of August, 1856, the road was opened
from West Newton to Guffey’s Station, eight miles,
and on the 14th of January, 1857, to the mouth of
Turtle Creek, fifteen miles.

Operations at the tunnel works were suspended on
the 1st of October, 1857. Early in 1859, the work of
construction was commenced between Turtle Creek
and Pittsburgh. The entire length of the road was
completed from Pittsburgh to Cumberland in April,
1870, a distance of 149-5 miles. Only about five
miles of the road lies within the State of Maryland.

The WasniNaToN BrancH RatLroap CoMPANY was
chartered by the Maryland Legislature on the 9th
of March, 1833, and authorized to construct a road
from a point on the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad to
Washington. Soon after, the work of construction
was commenced, and the road opened for traffic on
the 20th of July, from the Relay House, on the B.
& O. Railroad, to Bladensburg, a distance of twenty-
four miles; and on the 25th of August the remain-
der, a distance of six miles, was completed, opening
the road through to Washington in 1835. It was
constructed under the auspices of the B. & O. Rail-
road Co., which owns $1,016,800 of its share capital
of $1,650,000, and is also managed and operated by it.

The WasniNgroN CouNTY RAILROAD, extending
from Weverton, on the Baltimore and Ohio Rail-
road, through Washington County to Hagerstown,
a distance of twenty-four miles, was opened for
traffic on December 1, 1867. The road is princi-
pally owned by the Baltimore and Ohio Company.



The WESTERN MARYLAND RATLROAD COMPANY Was
chartered by the Maryland Legislature, January,
1852, the extent of the road being from Relay, on
the Northern Central Railroad, to Hagerstown, a
distance of 81{%% miles. The work of construction
was begun in July, 1857, and the line completed as
far as Owings’ Mills, a distance of ten miles, in
July, 1858. In the following September it was ex-
tended to Reisterstown, a point five miles further;
and in June, 1860, to Finksburg, three miles further,
making an extent of eighteen miles. It was opened
through to Hagerstown on June 4, 1872, and is now
extending 6%7; (6-45) miles further to Williamsport,
on the Chesapeake and Ohio Canal. An indepen-
dent line is also being constructed from Baltimore to
a point on the present road called Owings’ Mills, by
which the use of the Northern Central Railroad will
be avoided. _

The distance by present line from Baltimore to
Hagerstown is 88:79 miles. The distance by the
independent line, when completed, will be about 83
miles.
