is a continuation of the Wicomico and Pocomoke
Railroad, running from Berlin in Worcester County,
to Snow Hill, a distance of about fourteen miles.
It is chiefly owned by the Wicomico and Pocomoke
Road.





DISERICT OF -COEUMBYA,

THE Act of Congress creating the District of
Columbia was passed July 16th, 1790. The
territory was exactly ten miles square, and was laid
oft diagonally, with reference to the points of the
compass; i e., its boundary lines bear north-east,
north-west, etc. Its southern angle was at Jones’
Point, just south of Alexandria, on the west side of
the Potomac. It comprised portions of the territory
of the States of Virginia and Maryland, which were
ceded by them to the General Government. The
portion which was derived from Virginia, lying south-
west of the river, was, however, ceded back to that
State in 1846, and the remaining portion, containing
sixty square miles, lies entirely on the north-eastern
side of the river, which forms the south-western
boundary of the District, separating it from Virginia.

The District is situated between Lat. 30° 51’ and

30° north, and Lon. 76° 58 and 77° 6’ west, three
hundred miles from the Ocean by the Potomac River
and Chesapeake Bay.
- It forms the county of Washington, and is divided
for election purposes into twenty-two election dis-
tricts, eighteen in the city of Washington, two in
Georgetown, and two which embrace all outside of
the limits of the two cities.

Up to a recent period the District has been entirely
under the jurisdiction of, and governed by the laws
of Maryland in force at the time of the cession of the
territory to the United States.

On the 21st of February, 1871, an Act of Congress
was passed, declaring that all that part of the terri-
tory of the United States, included within the limits
of the District of Columbia, should be created into a
government, by the name of said District, and that
the executive power and authority in and over the
same should be vested in a Governor, who should be
appointed by the President; and the legislative
power be vested in a legislative assembly. Under
this Act, the President appointed Henry D. Cook,
Esq., Governor.

Metzerott Hall, on Pennsylvania Avenue, has been
fitted up for the use of the territorial legislature.

The surface of the District is gently undulating,
and the soil naturally thin, sandy, and sterile. Cli-
mate is moist and warm, summer and autumn fevers

T





prevailing on the low grounds near the Potomac. Con-
siderable quantities of flour and other domestic pro-
duce are brought down the Potomac, but neither the
commerce nor shipping of the District are important.

There are two Colleges in the District: Georgetown
College (connected with which is a flourishing girls’
seminary) was founded in 1789, and is under the
direction of the Jesuits; and Columbia College,
founded in 1821, under the auspices of the Baptist
General Convention.

(a) Then in the District of Columbia, now in Virginia.

The city of WasniNeToN, capital of the United

States of America, occupies a nearly central position
in the District, on the left bank of the Potomac, one
hundred and sixty miles from its mouth. Latitude
(Capitol building) 38° 52’ 20”, Longitude 77° 0’ 15"
west from Greenwich. The natural situation of
‘Washington is pleasant, and it is laid out on a plan
which will render it, when the extensive system of
grading and sewerage now under way shall be com-
pleted, one of the most elegant and commodious
cities in the world.

The principal public buildings are: the Capitol,
the President’s House, the Departments of the



Treasury, Navy, Patent Office, Post Office, National
Observatory, Arsenal, Navy Yard, Smithsonian In-
stitute, Washington Monument, and City Hall.

The Capitol, situated in a commanding position,
surrounded by a park of 85 acres, was begun in
17983, burnt by the British in 1814, rebuilt and com-
pleted in 1825, and subsequently enlarged. The
centre is 352 by 101 feet, with a lofty dome, the wings

DISTRICT OF COLUMBIA.

25



land and Delaware Road was completed. In 1838,
the viaduct over the Schuylkill was completed, and
a connection was opened to Philadelphia by means
of the Southwark Road.

The PrrrspvrcH, WASHINGTON AND DBALTIMORE
Ramuroap CompaNy was chartered on the 3d of
April, 1837, under the name of the Pittsburgh and
Connellsville Railroad Company, with authority to
construct a road from Pittsburgh by the course of
the Monongahela and Youghiogheny rivers to some
suitable point at or near Connellsville. The charter
having lapsed, was revived by an Act passed on the
18th of April, 18438, and the company authorized to
extend their road beyond Connellsville to Smithfield
or any other point on the waters of the Youghi-
ogheny. In January, 1853, the company obtained a
charter from the State of Maryland, which conferred
authority for the extension of the road into that
State as far as Cumberland.

The necessary surveys were commenced on the
20th of July, 1853, and the contract for the work on
the division between West Newton and Connells-
ville, twenty-five miles, was given out on the 22d of
March, 1854. This portion of the road was com-
pleted and opened for business on the 13th of Sep-
tember, 1855. On the 26th of April of the same
year, that portion of the first division of the road,
between West Newton and Turtle Creek, was con-
tracted for, and the work immediately thereafter com-
menced ; and in the spring of 1856, the contract was
given out for the tunnel at Sand Patch Summit.



On the 10th of August, 1856, the road was opened
from West Newton to Guffey’s Station, eight miles,
and on the 14th of January, 1857, to the mouth of
Turtle Creek, fifteen miles.

Operations at the tunnel works were suspended on
the 1st of October, 1857. Early in 1859, the work of
construction was commenced between Turtle Creek
and Pittsburgh. The entire length of the road was
completed from Pittsburgh to Cumberland in April,
1870, a distance of 149-5 miles. Only about five
miles of the road lies within the State of Maryland.

The WasniNaToN BrancH RatLroap CoMPANY was
chartered by the Maryland Legislature on the 9th
of March, 1833, and authorized to construct a road
from a point on the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad to
Washington. Soon after, the work of construction
was commenced, and the road opened for traffic on
the 20th of July, from the Relay House, on the B.
& O. Railroad, to Bladensburg, a distance of twenty-
four miles; and on the 25th of August the remain-
der, a distance of six miles, was completed, opening
the road through to Washington in 1835. It was
constructed under the auspices of the B. & O. Rail-
road Co., which owns $1,016,800 of its share capital
of $1,650,000, and is also managed and operated by it.

The WasniNgroN CouNTY RAILROAD, extending
from Weverton, on the Baltimore and Ohio Rail-
road, through Washington County to Hagerstown,
a distance of twenty-four miles, was opened for
traffic on December 1, 1867. The road is princi-
pally owned by the Baltimore and Ohio Company.



The WESTERN MARYLAND RATLROAD COMPANY Was
chartered by the Maryland Legislature, January,
1852, the extent of the road being from Relay, on
the Northern Central Railroad, to Hagerstown, a
distance of 81{%% miles. The work of construction
was begun in July, 1857, and the line completed as
far as Owings’ Mills, a distance of ten miles, in
July, 1858. In the following September it was ex-
tended to Reisterstown, a point five miles further;
and in June, 1860, to Finksburg, three miles further,
making an extent of eighteen miles. It was opened
through to Hagerstown on June 4, 1872, and is now
extending 6%7; (6-45) miles further to Williamsport,
on the Chesapeake and Ohio Canal. An indepen-
dent line is also being constructed from Baltimore to
a point on the present road called Owings’ Mills, by
which the use of the Northern Central Railroad will
be avoided. _

The distance by present line from Baltimore to
Hagerstown is 88:79 miles. The distance by the
independent line, when completed, will be about 83
miles.

The Wicomico AND PocoMokE RAILR0OAD extends
from Salisbury on the Eastern Shore Railroad to
Berlin, a distance of twenty-three miles.

The WorcesTER RalLroap, completed in 1872,
is a continuation of the Wicomico and Pocomoke
Railroad, running from Berlin in Worcester County,
to Snow Hill, a distance of about fourteen miles.
It is chiefly owned by the Wicomico and Pocomoke
Road.





DISERICT OF -COEUMBYA,

THE Act of Congress creating the District of
Columbia was passed July 16th, 1790. The
territory was exactly ten miles square, and was laid
oft diagonally, with reference to the points of the
compass; i e., its boundary lines bear north-east,
north-west, etc. Its southern angle was at Jones’
Point, just south of Alexandria, on the west side of
the Potomac. It comprised portions of the territory
of the States of Virginia and Maryland, which were
ceded by them to the General Government. The
portion which was derived from Virginia, lying south-
west of the river, was, however, ceded back to that
State in 1846, and the remaining portion, containing
sixty square miles, lies entirely on the north-eastern
side of the river, which forms the south-western
boundary of the District, separating it from Virginia.

The District is situated between Lat. 30° 51’ and

30° north, and Lon. 76° 58 and 77° 6’ west, three
hundred miles from the Ocean by the Potomac River
and Chesapeake Bay.
- It forms the county of Washington, and is divided
for election purposes into twenty-two election dis-
tricts, eighteen in the city of Washington, two in
Georgetown, and two which embrace all outside of
the limits of the two cities.

Up to a recent period the District has been entirely
under the jurisdiction of, and governed by the laws
of Maryland in force at the time of the cession of the
territory to the United States.

On the 21st of February, 1871, an Act of Congress
was passed, declaring that all that part of the terri-
tory of the United States, included within the limits
of the District of Columbia, should be created into a
government, by the name of said District, and that
the executive power and authority in and over the
same should be vested in a Governor, who should be
appointed by the President; and the legislative
power be vested in a legislative assembly. Under
this Act, the President appointed Henry D. Cook,
Esq., Governor.

Metzerott Hall, on Pennsylvania Avenue, has been
fitted up for the use of the territorial legislature.

The surface of the District is gently undulating,
and the soil naturally thin, sandy, and sterile. Cli-
mate is moist and warm, summer and autumn fevers

T





prevailing on the low grounds near the Potomac. Con-
siderable quantities of flour and other domestic pro-
duce are brought down the Potomac, but neither the
commerce nor shipping of the District are important.

There are two Colleges in the District: Georgetown
College (connected with which is a flourishing girls’
seminary) was founded in 1789, and is under the
direction of the Jesuits; and Columbia College,
founded in 1821, under the auspices of the Baptist
General Convention.

(a) Then in the District of Columbia, now in Virginia.

The city of WasniNeToN, capital of the United

States of America, occupies a nearly central position
in the District, on the left bank of the Potomac, one
hundred and sixty miles from its mouth. Latitude
(Capitol building) 38° 52’ 20”, Longitude 77° 0’ 15"
west from Greenwich. The natural situation of
‘Washington is pleasant, and it is laid out on a plan
which will render it, when the extensive system of
grading and sewerage now under way shall be com-
pleted, one of the most elegant and commodious
cities in the world.

The principal public buildings are: the Capitol,
the President’s House, the Departments of the



Treasury, Navy, Patent Office, Post Office, National
Observatory, Arsenal, Navy Yard, Smithsonian In-
stitute, Washington Monument, and City Hall.

The Capitol, situated in a commanding position,
surrounded by a park of 85 acres, was begun in
17983, burnt by the British in 1814, rebuilt and com-
pleted in 1825, and subsequently enlarged. The
centre is 352 by 101 feet, with a lofty dome, the wings
142 by 238 feet; the entire building being 751 feet
long, by 324 feet deep, covering 3% acres,—the centre

nineteen miles above the city, discharging nearly
three times as much water as the Croton aqueduct
of New York.

Washington was founded in 1790 by the first Presi-
dent of the United States, whose name it bears. It
became the seat of the Federal Government in 1800.

west. It is situated on elevated ground, dotted with

gation of the Potomac River.

structed at a cost of $2,000,000.
